PREFACE
         This code of the County of Elko County, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 2024-04, passed August 7, 2024.
Ordinances of the County adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the County office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio

TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL COUNTY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alteration
1-1-5: Adoption
1-1-6: Effective Date
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the Board of County Commissioners, this County Code is
hereby declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official County Code
of the County of Elko, State of Nevada, and it is hereby published by authority
of the Board of County Commissioners 1  and shall be kept up to date as
provided in Section
1-1-3 under the direction of said Commissioners. Any reference to the number of
any Section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of
the same number, its appropriate Chapter and Title heading, and to the general
penalty clause relating thereto, as well as to the Section itself, when
reference is made to this County Code by title in any legal document.
 
Notes
1 1. N.R.S. 244.116 et seq.
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This County Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this State as the ordinances of the County of general and
permanent effect, except the excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this County Code shall set forth the Title, Chapter and
Section number of the Section or Sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this County Code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this County Code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
the County Code.
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATION:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any Section or any page of this County Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the County Board. The County official so designated by the County Board shall
see that the replacement pages are properly inserted in the official copies
maintained in the office of the Manager.
Any person having in his custody an official copy of this County Code shall
make every effort to maintain said Code in an up to date and efficient manner.
He shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such
are delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the County
Manager. Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and other
interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the County and shall be
returned when directed so to do by order of the County Board. (1976 Code)
1-1-5: ADOPTION:
As authorized by Section 244.116 through 244.119 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes, there is adopted the "COUNTY CODE, COUNTY OF ELKO, NEVADA - 1976" a
revision and codification of the general ordinances of the County of Elko.
1-1-6: EFFECTIVE DATE:
The County Code shall become effective on August 23, 1976. (Ord. 1976-T, 8-5-
76, Eff. 8-23-76)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Separability of Provisions
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the County passed prior to the adoption of this
County Code are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being
still in force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal
(subject to the saving clauses contained in the following Section), from which
are excluded the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: Tax levy
ordinances; appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and
annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights
to persons or corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the
execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances;
ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public
places; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to
elections; ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by
or from the County, and all special ordinances.
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this County Code or by
virtue of the preceding Section, excepting as this County Code may contain
provisions for such matters, in which case this County Code shall be considered
as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only.
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the County herein
repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code
shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
County under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this County Code.
1-2-4: SEPARABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
Each Section, paragraph, sentence, clause and provision of this Code is
separable and if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any
reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this Code nor any part
thereof, other than that part affected by such decision. (1976 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines of County Code
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any Section of this County Code importing the plural
number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons,
any single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this County Code by
words importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several
matters, parties or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate
shall be deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction
shall not be applied to any Section of this County Code which contains any
express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or
content may be repugnant thereto.
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: The word "agent" as used in this Code shall mean a person acting on
behalf of another.
BOARD: The word "Board", unless otherwise indicated, shall mean the Board of
County Commissioners of the County of Elko, State of Nevada.
CODE: The word "Code" shall mean the County Code of the County of Elko, and
amendments thereto.
COMMISSIONERS: The word "Commissioners" shall mean the County Commissioners of
the County of Elko.
COUNTY: The word "County" shall mean and refer to the County of Elko, State of
Nevada.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a County employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
County of Elko".
FEE: The word "fee" as used in this Code, shall mean a sum of money charged by
the County for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
FISCAL YEAR: The fiscal year for the County shall begin July 1 of each year. 1
KNOWINGLY: The word "knowingly" imports only a knowledge that the facts exist
which bring the act or omission within the provisions of this Code. It does not
require any knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The word "license" as used in this Code shall mean the permission
granted for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: The word "misdemeanor" shall mean any offense deemed a violation
of the provisions of this Code which is a lesser offense than a felony as
defined by State law. 2
NEGLIGENT: The word "negligent", as well as "neglect", "negligence" and
"negligently" imports a want of such attention to the nature of probable
consequences of the act or omission as a prudent man ordinarily bestows in
acting in his own concern.
NUISANCE: The word "nuisance" shall mean anything offensive or obnoxious to the
health and welfare of the inhabitants of the County; or any act or thing
repugnant to or creating a hazard to or having a detrimental effect on the
property of another person or to the County.
OCCUPANT: The word "occupant" applied to a building or land shall include any
person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
OFFENSE: The word "offense" shall mean any act forbidden by any provision of
this Code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this Code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a County officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the County of
Elko".
OFFICIAL TIME: Pacific Standard Time shall be the official time for the
transaction of the County business, except during applicable daylight savings
time set by National or State standards, when the official time shall be
advanced one hour. All clocks and other timepieces in or upon public buildings
or other premises maintained by or at the expense of the County shall be set
and run at the official time prescribed by this paragraph.
OPERATOR: The word "operator" as used in this Code shall mean the person who is
in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: The word "owner" applied to a building or land shall include any part
owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of
a part of such building or land.
PERSON: The word "person" shall mean any natural individual, firm, trust,
partnership, association or corporation in his or its own capacity or as
administrator, conservator, executor, trustee, receiver or other representative
appointed by the court. Whenever the word "person" is used in any Section of
this Code prescribing a penalty or fine as applied to partnerships or any such
word as applied to corporations, shall include the officers, agents or
employees thereof who are responsible for any violation of said Section.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: The term "personal property" shall include every description
of money, goods, chattels, effects, evidence of rights in action and all
written instruments by which any pecuniary obligation, right or title to
property is created, acknowledged, transferred, increased, defeated, discharged
or diminished and every right or interest therein.
RETAILER: The word "retailer" as used in this Code, unless otherwise
specifically defined shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods,
merchandise, articles or things in small quantities direct to the consumer.
STATE: The word "State", unless otherwise indicated, shall mean the State of
Nevada.
STREET: The word "street" shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards,
public squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: The word "tenant" applied to a building or land shall include any
person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
WHOLESALER: The words "wholesaler" and "wholesale dealer" as used in this Code,
unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to the
sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who
purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: The word "wilfully" when applied to the intent with which an act is
done or omitted, implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or
make the omission referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law,
or to injure another, or to acquire an advantage.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: The terms "written" or "in writing" may include printing
and any other mode of representing words and letters, but when the written
signature of any person is required by law to any official or public writing or
bond required by law, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such person, or
in case he is unable to write, by his proper mark.
 
Notes
1 1. Nevada Constitution, Article IX, sec. 1
2 2. N.R.S. 193.120
1-3-3: CATCHLINES OF COUNTY CODE:
The catchlines of the several Sections of this County Code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the Section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such Sections, nor as any part of the Section, nor unless
expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such Sections,
including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. (1976 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: License
1-4-3: Application
1-4-4: Liability of Officers
1-41: GENERAL PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any Section of this County Code shall be
fined in a sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any one
offense, and the person may be confined in the County jail for a period of not
more than six (6) months. 1
 
Notes
1 1. N.R.S. 193.120
1-4-2: LICENSE:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any Section of this County Code,
any license previously issued to him by the County may be revoked by the court
or by the County Commissioners.
1-4-3: APPLICATION:
The penalty provided in this Chapter shall be applicable to every Section of
this County Code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate
Section. Any person convicted of a violation of any Section of this County Code
where any duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is
of a continuing nature or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this County Code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or Sections of this County Code, the prosecuting officer may
elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had
against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of
a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar
any other penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any Section or provision of this County Code and there shall be no
fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this
Chapter shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each
day during or on which a breach or violation occurs or continues.
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
The failure of any officer or employee to perform any official duty imposed by
this Code shall not subject such officer or employee to the penalty imposed for
violation of this Code unless a penalty is specifically provided for. (1976
Code)
CHAPTER 5
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Meetings
1-5-2: Elections
1-5-1: MEETINGS:
The board of county commissioners of the county of Elko, state of Nevada, shall
meet to conduct the regular business before the board three (3) days per month,
each and every month of the year. The first regular meeting day shall be the
first Wednesday in each month. The second regular meeting day shall be the
first Thursday after the first Wednesday of each month. The third regular
meeting day shall be the third Wednesday of each month. Should any of such
regular meeting days fall on a holiday, the meeting day shall be on the first
nonholiday working day following the holiday. (Ord. 1985-C, 4-4-1985, eff. 4-
22-1985)
1-5-2: ELECTIONS:
   (A)   Election Districts: The County of Elko shall be, and the same hereby
is, divided into five (5) separate districts for the election of County
Commissioners to the Board of Elko County Commissioners, said districts to be,
and are, hereby identified as follows:
   DISTRICT I: District one shall consist of Elko County voting precincts 18,
19, 20, 21, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38 and 39. Population by
2020 census of 10,141.
   DISTRICT II: District two shall consist of Elko County voting precincts 01,
02, 03, 04, 05, 06, and 07. Population by 2020 census of 10,634.
   DISTRICT III: District three shall consist of Elko County voting precincts
08, 09, 10, 11, 13 and 14. Population by 2020 census of 11,326.
   DISTRICT IV: District four shall consist of Elko County voting precincts 12,
15, 16, 17, 32, 40 and 41. Population by 2020 census of 10,982.
   DISTRICT V: District five shall consist of Elko County voting precincts 22,
23, 24, 25, and 26. Population by 2020 census of 10,619.
   The district boundaries are more particularly established and identified in
the 2020 decennial census and voting precinct maps for the cities of Carlin,
Elko, Wells and West Wendover and County of Elko, which are on file in the
office of the Elko County Clerk, State of Nevada, and which are incorporated
herein by reference.
   Each of the districts shall be a single member district, and any candidate
for the office of Elko County Commissioner must be a bona fide resident of the
district which the candidate seeks to represent on the board.
   Each board member shall, however, be elected at large by a qualified
electorate of the entire county.
   A Commissioner shall be elected from District II at the General Election in
1994, and every four (4) years thereafter. Commissioners from Districts I and
III shall be elected at the General Election in 1992 and every four (4) years
thereafter. Commissioners from Districts IV and V shall be elected at the
General Election in 1992 with District IV initially being a two (2) year term
and District V initially being a four (4) year term. When the initial terms
expire for Districts IV and V the subsequent terms for each new position will
be four (4) years.
   (B)   Election Worker Compensation:
 
Election Training                                      $25.00 Per Attendance
Polling Place Setup                                    $25.00
Election Worker                                        $120.00 Full Day
                                                      $60.00 Half Day
Team Leader                                            $145.00 Full Day
Counting and Duplicating Boards and Additional Workers $11.00 Per Hour
Mileage: Mileage shall be paid at the current County reimbursement rate only
to those who reside 10 or more miles from the Polling Place, Counting Facility
or Training Facility.
 
(Ord. 2002-A, 2-7-2002; amd. Ord. 2021-05, 12-15-2021)
CHAPTER 6
COUNTY MANAGER
SECTION:
1-6-1: Establishment of Office
1-6-2: Appointment of County Manager
1-6-3: Removal of County Manager
1-6-4: Policies and Duties of County Manager
1-6-5: Bond of County Manager
1-6-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE:
There is hereby established the office of County Manager, pursuant to N.R.S.
244.125.
1-6-2: APPOINTMENT OF COUNTY MANAGER:
The County Manager shall be appointed by a majority vote of the County
Commissioners for an indefinite term.
He shall be chosen by the County Commissioners solely on the basis of his
executive and administrative qualifications, and need not be a resident of the
State or County to receive appointment, but during his tenure of office must
reside in the County.
No person who is or has been an elected officer of the County may be appointed
County Manager unless he has been out of office for at least one year prior to
such appointment.
1-6-3: REMOVAL OF COUNTY MANAGER:
The County Manager shall serve at the pleasure of the Board of County
Commissioners, and may be removed from office at any time by a majority vote of
its members.
1-6-4: POLICIES AND DUTIES OF COUNTY MANAGER:
The County Manager shall be the administrative head of the County government.
The Board of County Commissioners, acting as a Board, will express its policies
to the County Manager through its ordinances, minute orders, rules and
regulations, or through duly appointed committees of one or more Board members
specifically authorized to act on behalf of the Board.
The County Manager shall execute on behalf of the Board its administrative
control and supervision of the affairs of the County, and of all officers,
departments, institutions or districts for whom the Board is required by law to
adopt an annual budget, except elective officers or boards, commissioners or
institutions which have such administrative authority authorized by law or
County ordinance.
All such offices shall submit all matters requiring Board action or attention
to the County Manager who shall submit them to the Board with recommendations
as may be deemed necessary.
The County Manager, with the approval of the Board of County Commissioners, may
appoint such assistants and other employees as are necessary to the proper
functioning of his office. The salaries of such assistants and the employees
and the expenses of conducting the office of County Manager shall be fixed by
the County Manager, with the consent and approval of the Board of County
Commissioners.
The County Manager shall perform all other duties as may be specifically
directed and keep the Board informed as to the execution of its policies and
directives.
1-6-5: BOND OF COUNTY MANAGER:
The Board of County Commissioners may require bond of the County Manager, at
the discretion of the Board and in the amount set by the Board. Expense of such
bond shall be borne by the County. (Ord. 1966-B; 9-28-66)

COUNTY PERSONNEL

1-7-1: DEFINITION OF ACTUAL SERVICE:
For the purpose of determining sick leave and vacation earned, the term "actual
service" shall mean the number of days actually worked on the job and the major
portion of working days within a calendar month shall be deemed one month of
actual service; providing, however, that absence from work due to sick leave
with pay, vacation with pay, injury or illness occurring in County service, and
absence on temporary military duty shall be deemed actual service. (Ord. 1976-
P, 8-5-76, Eff. 8-26-76)
1-7-2: SALARY STEPS:
   (A)   STEP I. MINIMUM HIRING RATE FOR THE RANGE. New employees shall be
employed at the minimum rate for the range unless:
      1.   A qualified person cannot be hired at that rate;
      2.   The person to be employed possesses higher step qualifications;
A new employee shall not be allowed to start higher than the Third Step.
In any of the above actions, the elected officer will notify the County Manager
of the action that was taken regarding employee hiring. Department heads will
coordinate with the County Manager when hiring an employee above the beginning
Step.
   (B)   STEP II. INDICATES SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF PROBATIONARY PERIOD. No
employee shall spend less than four (4) full months at Step I commencing with
the date of hire or transfer from part-time to full-time at a designated range.
If the elected officer or department head feels that additional time is needed
for the employee to more adequately demonstrate his ability, a total of six (6)
months probationary period may be exercised at Step I. Step II advancement is
upon the recommendation of the elected officer or department head and recorded
in the Board of Commissioners minutes. (Ord. 1976-K, 5-5-76)
   (C)   STEP III, FIRST ANNIVERSARY ADVANCEMENT. The employee shall spend no
less than eight (8) months at a Step II commencing with date of hire or
advancement to said Step.
Effective June 1, 1978, advancement to Step Ill shall be accomplished on the
first day of the month following the fulfillment of Step II criteria and the
time in Step requirement. The anniversary date for all employees at Step III
and above shall be on the first day of a month. (Ord. 1978-G, 5-4-78, eff. 5-
18-78)
   (D)   STEPS IV, V, VI, VII, VIII, IX, AND X ANNUAL ADVANCEMENT FOR MERIT AND
CONTINUOUS SERVICE. Upon the completion of one full year of service beginning
with Step III, the employee is eligible for advancement to the next highest
step. The advancement shall be upon the recommendation of the elected officer
or department head and the action taken recorded in the Board of County
Commissioners' minutes. (Ord. 1976-K, 5-5-76; amd. Ord. 1978-G, 5-4-78, eff. 5-
18-78; Ord. 1987-A, 4-15-87, eff. retroactive 7-1-85)
1-7-3: PAY RATE COVERS FULL-TIME SERVICE:
The pay rate set forth shall be gross compensation for full- time service in
the several positions. By full-time service is meant the number of hours which
regularly constitutes the scheduled weekly period of service. This may involve
either an eight (8) hour work day or a seven (7) hour work day, depending on
position classification.
In instances when job functions are compensated for by more than one
jurisdiction, the total of the other salary or salaries will be deducted from
the rate established, and Elko County will be obligated for this difference.
1-7-4: MINIMUM RATE:
No person in the classified service shall be paid at a rate below the minimum
step in the range to which his position class is assigned.
1-7-5: NEW EMPLOYEES PAY RATE:
New County employees shall be employed at the minimum rate for the class,
unless it is impossible to recruit a qualified person at this rate or the
person being employed possesses higher qualifications, in which case the County
Manager may authorize hiring at a higher step upon recommendation of the
department head.
1-7-6: PROBATIONARY PERIOD:
At the completion of a probationary period of not less than four (4) months or
greater than six (6) months, an employee whose service has been certified as
satisfactory by the elected officer or department head may be advanced to the
Second Step. Should an employee be judged to require an additional probationary
period to more adequately determine the level of performance, the reasoning
shall be documented and made record.
1-7-7: ANNUAL AND BIANNUAL ADVANCEMENTS:
The employee, after completion of the probationary period, and upon reaching
the anniversary date in the present classification, may be eligible for
advancement to the next step and may be so advanced upon the recommendation of
the elected officer or department head and approval by the Board of County
Commissioners. (Ord. 1968-C, 8-8-68, Eff. 9-1-68)
1-7-8: CIVIC DUTY LEAVE OF ABSENCE:
A leave of absence with pay shall be granted to any County employee who serves
on a jury or as a witness for the Federal government, the State of Nevada, or a
political subdivision thereof. The employee shall be paid his regular salary
while on court leave and retain any witness or jury duty fees, when summoned
for jury duty or serving as a witness in any case. When an employee, serving in
his official capacity as a County employee and as part of his required duties,
serves as a witness in any case, he shall not receive witness fees. Per diem
and transportation costs may be paid by the requesting jurisdiction,
considering such variables as whether or not the case is a criminal or civil
matter, whether it is in State or out-of-state, the length of time the employee
is required to stay away from the job and who receives ultimate benefit from
the County employee's testimony. Court leave shall not be charged to any
employee's annual leave balance.
1-7-9: MILITARY LEAVE OF ABSENCE:
Any officer or employee of the County who is an active member of the United
States Army Reserve, the United States Air Force Reserve, the United States
Naval Reserve, the United States Marine Corps Reserve, the United States Coast
Guard Reserve, the United States Public Health Service Reserve or the Nevada
National Guard shall be relieved from his duties, upon request, to serve under
orders on training duty without loss of his regular compensation for a period
not to exceed fifteen (15) working days in any one calendar year. Any such
absence shall not be deemed to be such employee's annual vacation provided for
by law. (Ord. 1976-P, 8-5-76, eff. 8-26-76)
1-7-10: REDUCTION IN RATE FOR UNSATISFACTORY PERFORMANCE:
The County Commissioners, upon the request of the elected officer or department
head, may authorize reducing an employee from any step of the salary range,
other than the first step, to any appropriate lower step of the same range upon
failure of the employee to maintain a satisfactory standard of work for the
step of the salary range upon which the employee has been placed. In such
event, the employee may again be raised by the officials above designated to
any step not higher than that from which he was reduced without any time
requirement or other consent, if in the opinion of the officials, the
employee's standard of service has been re- established.
1-7-11: PAY PATTERN FOR CHANGE OF LEVEL AND TRANSFER:
When an employee is promoted to a position allocated to a higher pay range, he/
she shall receive the pay rate for the new range in the step that is
commensurate with date of hire. When an employee is transferred to a position
in another class allocated to the same salary range, the employee shall
continue at the then existing step rate. When an employee is demoted to a
position in a class allocated to a lower pay range, the employee shall receive
the rate of pay in the step of said range that is commensurate with the date of
hire.
1-7-12: RECLASSIFICATION REQUEST:
Any employee may request a job reclassification. Upon receiving a request for a
job reclassification, the elected officer or department head of the employee
requesting the reclassification may request authorization from the Board of
County Commissioners. An elected officer or department head may request a
reclassification of an employee from the Board of County Commissioners.
1-7-13: RIGHT TO APPEAL BY EMPLOYEE:
Any employee who, without satisfactory cause, has not been advanced upon his
anniversary date, has not been reclassified upon request, or who has been
reduced in pay rate, may appeal before the Board of County Commissioners at
their next regular meeting following such action. (Ord. 1975-C, 8-7-75, eff. 9-
1-75)
1-7-14: VACATION CREDITS:
   (A)   Elected Officials: All elected officers of Elko County shall be
entitled to vacation leave with pay of one and one- fourth (11/4) days for each
month of service which may be cumulative. Annual leave shall not be accumulated
to exceed thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year.
Amounts in excess of thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar
year shall be forfeited.
   (B)   Appointed Officials and Employees With Less than Five Years' Service:
      1.   All appointed officials and employees working on a full- time basis
shall be entitled to vacation leave with pay of five-sixths (5/6) working days
for each month of service which may be accumulative.
      2.   The time when annual leave is taken shall be determined by the
appointing authority after considering the needs of the service and the
seniority and wishes of the employees. Annual leave shall not be accumulated to
exceed thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year. Amounts
in excess of thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year
shall be forfeited. Annual leave shall not be granted in excess of the annual
leave credit earned.
      3.   During the first six (6) months of employment of any appointed
officer or employee, vacation leave shall accrue as provided in this Section,
but no vacation leave shall be taken during such period.
   (C)   Appointed Officials and Employees After Five Years' Service:
      1.   All appointed officials and employees working on a full- time basis
who have completed five (5) or more consecutive years of employment shall earn
vacation leave of one and one- fourth (11/4) working days for each month of
service which may be accumulative.
      2.   The time when annual leave is taken shall be determined by the
appointing authority after considering the needs of the service and the
seniority and wishes of the employees. Annual leave shall not be accumulated to
exceed thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year. Amounts
in excess of thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year
shall be forfeited. Annual leave shall not be granted in excess of the annual
leave credit earned.
   (D)   Appointed Officials and Employees After Fifteen Years' Service:
      1.   All appointed officials and employees working on a full- time basis
who have completed fifteen (15) or more consecutive years of employment shall
earn vacation leave of one and two-thirds (12/3) working days for each month of
service, which may be accumulative.
      2.   The time when annual leave is taken shall be determined by the
appointing authority after considering the needs of the service and the
seniority and wishes of the employees. Annual leave shall not be accumulated to
exceed thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year. Amounts
in excess of thirty (30) working days at the beginning of any calendar year
shall be forfeited. Annual leave shall not be granted in excess of the annual
leave credit earned. (Ord. 1976-P, 8-5-76, eff. 8-26-76)
1-7-15: PRORATED ALLOWANCE FOR PART-TIME EMPLOYEES:
Permanent employees who are regularly scheduled to work twenty (20) or more,
but less than thirty five (35) hours per week, are hereby designated as part-
time employees. Part-time employees earn prorated annual leave, sick leave and
holiday pay, based upon the applicable provisions of the Elko County General
Employees Collective Bargaining Agreement. The benefits provided for in this
Section do not apply to seasonal or temporary employees. (Ord. 1993-F, 8-5-93,
eff. 8-23-93)
1-7-16: EXTRA HELP:
Employees whose term of continuous employment is less than six (6) months or
who work less than fifty (50) hours per month, shall be designated as extra
help. Hiring of such employees shall be for such periods and at such salaries
or wages as may be approved by the Board of County Commissioners, but such
extra help shall not be entitled to any of the benefits provided by this
Chapter.
1-7-17: VACATION CREDIT UPON TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT:
   (A)   Upon termination of employment for any reason, an appointed officer or
employee who has earned vacation time may be granted a vacation for the time so
earned not to exceed the maximums specified in Section
1-7-14 of this Chapter. Such vacation must be taken prior to the effective date
of termination of employment, or in lieu of such vacation, the employee may be
granted a lump sum payment for vacation time accrued to his credit.
   (B)   No appointed officer or employee shall be paid for accumulated
vacation leave upon termination of his service unless he or she has been
employed six (6) months or more.
   (C)   No elected County officer shall be paid for accumulated vacation leave
upon the termination of his service.
1-7-18: RIGHTS OF HEIRS OF DECEASED OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE:
If an appointed officer or employee dies and was entitled to accumulated
vacation leave under the provisions of this Chapter, the heirs of such deceased
officer or employee, who are given priority to succeed to the assets of
decedent's estate under the laws of intestate succession of this State, or the
executor or administrator of the decedent's estate, upon submitting
satisfactory proof to the Board of County Commissioners of their right, shall
be paid an amount of money equal to the number of days of accrued vacation
leave multiplied by the daily salary or wages of such deceased officer or
employee. (Ord. 1976-P, 8-5-76, eff. 8-26-76)
1-7-19: SICK LEAVE:
   (A)   Elected and appointed officers and employees shall be entitled to sick
and disability leave with pay of one and one-fourth (11/4) working days for
each month of service, which shall be cumulative from year to year not to
exceed one hundred twenty (120) working days. Following the expiration of
allowed sick and disability leave, the County Commissioners may grant an
elected or appointed officer or employee up to an additional one hundred twenty
(120) days sick leave. The granting of such additional sick leave shall be at
the sole discretion of the Elko County Commissioners, based upon the best
interests of the County of Elko. (Ord. 1982-D, 4-8-82, eff. 5-1-82)
   (B)   Part-time employees may be allowed prorated sick leave on the basis of
one and one fourth (11/4) days of credit for each equivalent month of full-time
service.
   (C)   An elected official, appointed officer or employee separated from
service shall earn sick leave only through the last working day for which he is
entitled to pay. If this date is earlier than the last day of the month, the
sick leave with pay shall be prorated. No payment for unused sick leave shall
be made upon separation.
   (D)   An elected official, appointed officer or employee is entitled to use
sick leave only when incapacitated to perform the duties of his position due to
sickness or injury, when quarantined, or when receiving required medical or
dental service or examination, or illness or death in his immediate family.
      1.   In the event a serious illness in an elected official's, appointed
officer's or employee's immediate family requires his attendance, he may use
sick leave not to exceed five (5) days in any one calendar year. For this
purpose, immediate family is defined as the elected official's, appointed
officer's or employee's parents, spouse, children (natural, adopted or foster),
brothers, sisters, grandparents, great grandparents, uncles, aunts, nephews,
grandchildren, nieces, great grandchildren, step-parents and, if living in the
elected official's, appointed officer's or employee's household, shall include
father-in-law, mother-in-law, son- in-law or daughter-in-law, grandfather-in-
law or grandmother- in-law, great grandfather-in-law or great grandmother-in-
law, uncle-in-law or aunt-in-law, brother-in-law or sister-in-law, grandson-in-
law or granddaughter-in-law, nephew-in-law or niece-in-law, great grandson-in-
law or great granddaughter- in-law and step-children. With the approval of the
Board of County Commissioners, additional family sick leave may be granted.
The Board of County Commissioners may approve an exception to this limitation
where an elected official's, appointed officer's or employee's attendance is
required to provide, participate in or arrange for intensive care and/or
treatment or receive extensive training in the proper utilization of equipment,
techniques and supplies essential for continued maintenance of good health. In
this case, the elected official, appointed officer, or employee submits his
request for an exception of the limitation to the Board of County
Commissioners. The request must be accompanied by an individual certification
from a physician or other suitably qualified person as to the actual need for
the elected official's, appointed officer's or employee's participation. The
certificate of need must identify the immediate family member's illness and
contain an explanation as to:
         (a)   Relative seriousness of the illness and a projection of the
probable length of time the elected official's, appointed officer's or
employee's attendance will be required; and
         (b)   The exact role of the employee while in attendance.
The appointing authority or Board of County Commissioners may request the
submittal of supplemental information.
      2.   In the event of a death in the elected official's, appointed
officer's or employee's immediate family, he may use sick leave not to exceed
five (5) working days for each death. For this purpose, immediate family is
defined as the employee's parents, spouse, children, brothers, sisters,
grandparents, great grandparents, uncles, aunts, nephews, grandchildren,
nieces, great grandchildren, father-in-law or mother-in-law, son-in-law,
daughter-in-law, grandfather-in- law or grandmother-in-law, uncle-in-law or
aunt-in-law, brother-in-law or sister-in-law, grandson-in-law or granddaughter-
in-law, nephew-in-law or niece-in-law, great grandson-in-law or great
granddaughter-in-law, and step- parents or step-children.
   (E)   An elected official, appointed officer or employee is entitled to use
accumulated sick leave for adoption purposes or as maternity leave regardless
of the type of delivery or results of pregnancy, if the provisions below are
fully complied with:
      1.   A maternity leave may be taken prior to the expected birthdate of
the child.
      2.   If, after exhausting her accumulated sick leave, an elected
official, appointed officer or employee needs additional time off from work,
annual leave shall be granted. If additional time is required, leave without
pay may be granted by the Board of County Commissioners if the Board considers
it justifiable and for the good of the public service.
      3.   Pregnancy shall not jeopardize an elected official's, appointed
officer's or employee's job or merit status except for leave without pay
limitations. The elected official, appointed officer, or employee shall be
responsible for reporting the pregnancy as soon as it is an established fact so
that steps may be taken to protect the elected official's, appointed officer's
or employee's health or modify her working conditions and in order that any
necessary staffing adjustments may be planned.
1-7-20: LEAVE OF ABSENCE:
Upon good cause shown and upon approval of the Board of County Commissioners,
any appointed officer or employee may be granted a leave of absence without pay
for the period of time and upon the conditions determined by said Board.
1-7-21: HOLIDAYS:
When any holiday falls on Sunday, the next day, Monday is observed as the
holiday. Employees working other than the standard work week (that is Monday
through Friday) are entitled to the same number of holidays as employees
working the standard work week. An equivalent holiday will be allowed within
ten (10) working days of the officially designated holiday.
The following holidays are declared legal holidays for all officers and
employees of the County of Elko:
January 1                               New Year's Day
Third Monday in February                Washington's Birthday
Last Monday in May                      Memorial Day
July 4                                  Independence Day
First Afternoon of the Elko County Fair
First Monday in September               Labor Day
October 31                              Nevada Day
November 11                             Veteran's Day
Fourth Thursday in November             Thanksgiving Day
December 25                             Christmas Day
 
And any day designated by the President of the United States, by the Governor
of Nevada or the Board of County Commissioners. (Ord. 1976-P, 8-5-76, eff. 8-
26-76)
When any of the following holidays fall on a Saturday, the preceding Friday
shall be observed as a holiday:
 
January 1   New Year's Day
July 4      Independence Day
October 31  Nevada Day
December 25 Christmas Day
 
(Ord. 1976-Y, 12-9-76, eff. 1-1-77)
1-7-22: WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION:
When any elected or appointed officer or employee of the County is eligible at
the same time for benefits under Chapters 616 or 617 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes and for any sick leave benefit:
   (A)   The amount of sick leave benefit paid to such elected or appointed
officers, or employees for any pay period shall not exceed the difference
between his or her normal salary and the amount of any benefit received,
exclusive of reimbursement or payment of medical or hospital expenses under
chapters 616 or 617 of the Nevada Revised Statutes for that pay period.
   (B)   If the amount of the elected or appointed officer's or employee's sick
leave benefit is reduced pursuant to Section
1-7-19(A) below the amount normally payable, the amount of sick leave charged
such elected or appointed officer, or employee as taken during that pay period
shall be reduced in the same proportion.
   (C)   The elected or appointed officer, or employee of the County may
decline to use any or part of the sick leave benefit normally payable to him or
her while receiving benefits under chapters 616 or 617 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes. During such period of time, the elected or appointed officer or
employee shall be considered on leave of absence without pay. (Ord. 1976-K, 5-
5-76)
1-7-23: COMPENSATORY VACATION TIME AND OVERTIME PAY:
   (A)   Each County employee not exempted by the Federal Fair Labor Standards
Act, 29 U.S.C. 201 et seq., and the regulations applicable thereto, as may be
amend ed from time to time, except law enforcement employees and public safety
employees, who by prior authorization works any time in excess of his specified
work week and any law enforcement employee or public safety employee who works
overtime as herein-below defined during any scheduled work period, shall be
compensated for such work as follows:
      1.   Effective April 15, 1986, pursuant to the department policy then in
effect and on file with the County Auditor, the employee who works any overtime
will be compensated for the overtime either by compensatory vacation time equal
to one and one-half (11/2) times the amount of overtime worked or by payment of
wages at one and one-half (11/2) times the employee's regular rate of pay.
      2.   Effective April 1, 1986, at the discretion of the department head
under whose supervision any employee works, an employee who has worked more
than the designated hours in one work day, or more than the designated number
of hours in any one work week, may take time off on an equal, time for time,
basis during the same designated work period to avoid accruing overtime in the
designated work period.
      3.   Terms of a collective bargaining agreement applicable to any
employee or group of employees takes precedence over these general terms of
overtime compensation insofar as the cash payment for overtime work or the
accrual of compensatory time; provided, however, that any compensatory vacation
time accrued under such collective bargaining agreement after April 1, 1986,
shall be accrued and awarded at one and one- half (11/2) times the overtime
worked and pay for overtime accrued under such collective bargaining agreement
shall be awarded at one and one-half (11/2) times the regular rate of pay for
such employee for the overtime worked.
      4.   Any employee whose work week is thirty five (35) hours shall be
compensated for services rendered in excess of thirty five (35) hours, but not
more than forty (40) hours by compensatory vacation time of one and one-half
(11/2) times the amount of time worked in excess of thirty five (35) hours, but
not more than forty (40) hours.
      5.   Any employee compensated for overtime by compensatory vacation time
may accrue up to four hundred eighty (480) hours of such compensatory time if
the employee works in law enforcement, public safety, emergency response or
seasonal work and up to two hundred forty (240) hours of compensatory time for
all other employees. Hours accrued in excess of those stated limits must be
paid by the next issued paycheck or warrant at one and one-half (11/2) times
the employee's regular rate of pay.
      6.   All accrued compensatory vacation time shall be permitted to be
taken by the employee, at the employee's request, within a reasonable time
after it is accrued, provided that the requested time off will not unduly
disrupt the operation of the office, department or the County. In no event
shall the employee be deprived of taking the compensatory time within six (6)
months of the time it is accrued.
   (B)   Definitions Applicable to This Chapter:
      1.   Collective Bargaining Agreement: An agreement entered into pursuant
to NRS chapter 288, between Elko County, through its Board of Commissioners,
and a recognized employee organization, acting as a bargaining agent for a
specifically recognized bargaining unit which controls conditions of
employment.
      2.   Emergency Response Employees: Employees who respond to medical
emergencies or disasters and who are not volunteers, including but not limited
to, doctors, nurses, emergency medical technicians, ambulance crews and
drivers.
      3.   Hours Worked: Hours worked, for purposes of calculating whether or
not an employee is entitled to overtime pay, is all time during which an
employee is necessarily required to be on the employer's premises, or at a
prescribed place of work, or otherwise on duty; provided however, that hours
worked do not include the following:
         (a)   Meal periods during which the employee is relieved of duties.
         (b)   Travel time to and from work, unless there is a collective
bargaining agreement which controls and specifies otherwise or the employee is
required to travel from his normal daily workplace to another place to complete
his duties.
         (c)   Preparation time which is not an integral part of the principal
activity of the employee's employment; this includes, but is not limited to,
time for changing clothing before or after a work shift.
         (d)   Stand-by time where the employee is not restricted as to what he
can or cannot do, or as to where he can or cannot go, within a limited range,
during this time. This includes time during which the employee carries a beeper
call system or transmitter.
         (e)   Time worked in excess of the prescribed work week for which
prior authorization was not granted.
         (f)   Hours worked pursuant to a voluntary agreement between
employees, for the convenience of at least one of those employees, and not the
convenience of the County, including but not limited to, trading time or
switching shifts or tours of duty and coming in early to relieve another
employee.
         (g)   Time worked in excess of the designated work week by an employee
who works no more than seven (7) months per calendar year for the County or who
earns seventy six percent (76%) or more of his total earnings from the County
in six (6) months or less of a calendar year, provided, however, that such time
in excess of the work week in any designated work period shall be compensated
at straight time or compensatory vacation time, on an hour for hour basis at
the election of the department head and as set forth in written department
regulations prior to the time so worked.
         (h)   Time worked by fire, public safety, emergency response or law
enforcement employees in voluntary response to a call for help from a
neighboring jurisdiction.
         (i)   Time worked as a volunteer in a capacity different from the
employee's normal duties.
      4.   Law Enforcement Employees: Elko County Sheriff's Department
personnel, whose work is not exclusively clerical and who are not otherwise
exempted by statute or regulation.
      5.   Overtime: Overtime is:
         (a)   For all employees, except law enforcement employees, public
safety employees and emergency response employees, seasonal employees or
recreational employees, and others exempted by statute, all time worked in
excess of forty (40) hours during a designated work period.
         (b)   For law enforcement employees, public safety employees, seasonal
employees and emergency response employees, all time worked in excess of one
hundred seventy one (171) hours during a designated work period.
      6.   Part-time Employee: An employee who is regularly scheduled to work
less than thirty five (35) hours per work week.
      7.   Public Safety Employees: Employees whose duties consist primarily of
protecting public safety or providing services relating to public safety,
including but is not limited to, fire fighters, ambulance crews, ambulance
drivers, emergency medical technicians, employees of the Department of
Emergency Response.
      8.   Recreational Employees or Personnel: Any employee whose primary
duties relate to providing or supervising recreation or services related to
recreation, including but not limited to, groundskeepers for parks or golf
courses, professional athletic instructors, recreation counselors or leaders,
life guards, activity directors or supervisors, who work seven (7) or less
months in a calendar year for Elko County or earn seventy six percent (76%) or
more of their gross in come from Elko County in six (6) months, or less, of a
calendar year at recreational facilities in Elko County or instruct, supervise
or conduct recreational activities for Elko County.
      9.   Regular Rate of Pay: The regular rate of pay is the employee's rate
of pay, per hour, calculated by dividing the amount of pay for the employee's
class and step, per pay period by the number of hours in the employee's normal
designated work week. The amount of pay per period includes shift differential
pay, retroactive pay, incentive pay and pay for controlled standby time.
      10.   Seasonal Employee: Any employee who works for the County of Elko
seven (7) months or less in any calendar year or who earns seventy six percent
(76%) of his gross income from Elko County in six (6) months or less in any
calendar year.
      11.   Standby Time: Time during which an employee must be available to
work, i.e. either to go to work at his normal place of employment or otherwise
respond to a call to engage in prescribed duties of his employment.
      12.   Travel Time: Time spent getting from one location to another by
whatever means of transportation.
      13.   Volunteer: Any person who has agreed in advance to provide, at no
cost, time, services, work, advice or consultation, to benefit Elko County or
any department, or division, or any employee or employees thereof, or to
provide such time, service, work, advice or consultation to benefit the
community or members of the community or the public through the auspices of
Elko County or a department or division of County government. Provided,
however, that any person otherwise employed by the County is a volunteer only
if the services provided as a volunteer are in a distinct and different
capacity from the duties performed in his/her capacity as an employee of the
County.
      14.   Workday: This is the number of hours in each twenty four (24) hour
period as designated in department regulations, that an employee is regularly
scheduled to work or be on duty, excluding overtime; the specified number of
hours for each employee's position are set forth in department regulations and
in a resolution of the Elko County Board of Commissioners; any changes in the
workday for any employee or group of employees shall be made by resolution of
the Elko County Board of Commissioners and a written departmental regulation
which is given in advance to each employee affected and which is posted within
the department.
      15.   Work Week: The work week is the number of hours in each week, from
Sunday at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight through the following Sunday at
eleven fifty nine o'clock (11:59) P.M., that an employee is regularly scheduled
to be on the County premises or otherwise on duty and engaged in his designated
duties. Designated work weeks for each position are set forth in department
regulations and resolutions by the Board of County Commissioners. Any change in
the designated work week for any employee or group of employees shall be made
by resolution of the Board of County Commissioners and department regulations
in advance of such change. Each employee affected shall be given written notice
in advance of the effective change date.
      16.   Work Period: The work period for all employees, except law
enforcement personnel and public safety or emergency personnel, is a seven (7)
day period from Sunday at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight through the following
Sunday at eleven fifty nine o'clock (11:59) P.M. beginning with March 30, 1986.
The work period for law enforcement personnel is a twenty eight (28) day period
from Sunday at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight to eleven fifty nine o'clock
(11:59) P.M., of the twenty eighth day thereafter, beginning on March 30, 1986.
   (C)   Any and all overtime must be authorized in advance by the department
head, or in the case of law enforcement, public safety, emergency response
personnel or road department, overtime must be within the department guidelines
for working overtime, and must be approved by the employee's immediate super
visor prior to the overtime, or must result from acting as a witness in a
criminal action, pursuant to being serviced with subpoena.
   (D)   Any employee who works for the County no more than seven (7) months
per calendar year or earns seventy six percent (76%) of his total earnings in
six (6) months of a calendar year, shall not receive overtime pay at one and
one-half (11/2) times his regular rate of pay for any time he works in excess
of the specified number of hours for his designated work week for his job. Any
such employee who works time in excess of the designated work week shall be
paid straight time for those extra hours worked or accrue compensatory time on
an equal hour-for-hour basis.
   (E)   Each employee shall sign, at the end of such designated work period, a
record of the time he has worked during that work period, which record shall be
kept as part of the central record-keeping of the County for a period of at
least three (3) years. (Ord. 1986-B, 3-19-86, eff. 4-1-86)
1-7-24: RECORDS:
Department heads shall submit each month a record of: any reclassification,
leave requests, vacation credits, sick leave credits or leaves of absence to
the officer of the County Manager for proper central recording. (Ord. 1976-P,
8-5-76, eff. 8-26-76)
1-7-25: FAIR EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES; DISCRIMINATIONS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   All personnel actions taken by County departments, agencies, boards or
appointing officers shall be based solely on merit and fitness.
   (B)   County appointing officers shall not:
      1.   Refuse to hire a person because of such person's race, color, creed,
national origin, age, or sex, unless based upon a bona fide occupational
classification.
      2.   Discharge or bar any person from employment because of such person's
race, creed, color, national origin, sex, or age.
      3.   Discriminate against any person in recruitment, appointment,
compensation, training, promotion, retention, or any other personnel action
because of political or religious opinions or affiliations or because of race,
national origin, age, sex, or other non-merit factors.
1-7-26: PROHIBITIONS:
   (A)   Full-time Service Required. Each employee shall, during his hours of
duty as an employee and subject to such other laws, rules, or regulations as
pertain thereto, devote his full time, attention, and efforts to County
employment.
   (B)   Strikes Against County Service. The Legislature declares it to be the
public policy of the State of Nevada that strikes against the State or any
local government employer are illegal. Elko County shall be defined as a local
government employer.
1-7-27: DISMISSAL:
   (A)   Public Hearings for Dismissed Employees. When an employee of a County
other than a department head, County Manager or County Administrator who has
been employed by the County for twelve (12) or more months is dismissed from
employment, he may request within fifteen (15) days of the date of dismissal a
written statement specifically setting forth the reasons for such dismissal.
Within fifteen (15) days of the date of such request, he shall be furnished
such a written statement. Within thirty (30) days after receipt of such written
statement, the dismissed employee may, in writing, request a public hearing
before the Board of County Commissioners to determine the reasonableness of
such action. The Board of County Commissioners shall grant the dismissed
employee a public hearing within fifteen (15) days after receipt of the written
request. At the public hearing, technical rules of evidence shall not apply.
(Ord. 1976-K, 5-5-76)
1-7-28: COMPUTATION OF MONTHLY PAY:
When the rate for an employee under this Ordinance is on a monthly basis, such
salary shall be computed on a working day basis, and an employee who serves
less than a full number of working days in a month and such absence is not
compensated for by sick leave, vacation, etc., shall have his salary reduced by
one-twenty first (1/21) of his regular monthly pay for each day's absence.
1-7-29: COMPUTATION OF HOURLY PAY:
When the rate of an employee is on an hourly basis, any portion of an hour
worked up to one-half (1/2) hour (thirty [30] minutes) shall be credited as a
full one-half (1/2) hour. Any portion of an hour worked beyond the one-half (1/
2) hour shall be credited as a full hour worked.
1-7-30: NORMAL WORK WEEK:
The normal work week shall be considered as five (5) working days from Monday
through Friday. Departments requiring a seven (7) day coverage may require the
five (5) working days to include any five (5) days of the week. (Ord. 1976-P,
8-5-76, eff. 8-26-76)
1-7-31: CONFIDENTIAL RECORDS:
   (A)   The following records are confidential and not open to the public:
      1.   Any materials to be used in the development and administration of
examinations.
      2.   Names and identities of applicants, eligible and special examiners.
      3.   Test scores, individual rating sheets, and evaluations. However,
applicants or employees may receive notification of their own test results upon
request.
      4.   Employee personnel files.
      5.   Employee performance records or information, disciplinary records or
information and medical information.
      6.   Reports of employers and appointing authorities regarding
applicants, eligible or employees.
   (B)   Basic employee Information: Basic employee information may be released
consisting of job title, current salary, date of hire, salary history,
promotional history, date of separation, employment status, department
assignment and duties.
   (C)   Release of records:
      1.   Records under subsection “A” may be released by written approval of
the employee, in accordance with the law, subpoena or court order compelling
release, or in defense of claims or complaints against the County or its
employees by the employee or applicant.
      2.   Employees may obtain access to their own employment files by written
request. (Ord. 2022-03, eff. 10-15-2022)
CHAPTER 8
ADDITIONAL ADMINISTRATIVE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
1-8-1: Finance
1-8-2: Uses of County Motor Vehicles Restricted
1-8-3: Fees for Photocopying and Certifying Documents
1-8-4: Additional Compensation for Issuance of Marriage Licenses After Hours
1-8-5: (Rep. by Ord. 1980-N, 8-7-80, eff. 9-1-80)
1-8-6: Fund for Medical Assistance to Indigent Persons
1-8-1: FINANCE:
The method of transacting the business of the County of Elko shall be changed
from the "cash" basis to the "modified accrual" basis. (Res. dated 6-6-67)
1-8-2: USE OF COUNTY MOTOR VEHICLES RESTRICTED:
   (A)   At no instance may a County officer or County employee use a County
motor vehicle for purposes that are for his own benefit and which do not serve
in either a direct or indirect manner to benefit the County.
   (B)   Examples of uses that are prohibited are: Using the vehicle to
transport members of the family to their place of employment; transport
children whether they be the children of the employee or others to and from
school and similar activities. The above- noted activities are not to be held
inclusive but to merely serve as examples of conduct that is considered to be
prohibited by this Section.
   (C)   Any County official or County employee found to be in violation of any
of the provisions of this Section shall forfeit not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first violation of
said section, and up to six (6) months in jail or five hundred dollars
($500.00) fine for any subsequent offense. (Ord. 1975-F, 9-11-75, eff. 10-1-75)
1-8-3: FEES FOR PHOTOCOPYING AND CERTIFYING DOCUMENTS:
   (A)   Each and every County officer may charge a fee for copying,
photocopying and certifying any public record.
   (B)   Where the information has been requested by letter and where said
information is to be returned by mail, any County official may charge the party
requesting the information the cost of mailing the information to said party.
   (C)   This Section shall be deemed not to apply to any Federal, state,
county, city, district governmental subdivision and quasi-municipal
corporations which supply the same or similar type information to Elko County
free of charge. (Ord. 1975-G, 9-11-75, eff. 10-1-75)
1-8-4: ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION FOR ISSUANCE OF MARRIAGE LICENSES AFTER HOURS:
   (A)   Deputy County Clerks shall be entitled to a commission of two dollars
thirty cents ($2.30) for each marriage license personally issued after regular
hours at the office of the County Clerk. Such deputies shall submit a monthly
payroll claim setting forth the number of such licenses issued after hours by
each deputy. Compensation to each deputy shall be determined by multiplying the
total number of licenses issued personally by each deputy by two dollars thirty
cents ($2.30).
   (B)   The County Clerk shall adjust the hours of the deputies so as to
equalize compensation for additional work insofar as such equalization is
reasonably possible. Additionally, the County Clerk shall set the times that
the office of the County Clerk shall be open after regular hours. (Ord. 1979-U,
9-6-79, eff. 10-1-79)
1-8-5: (Rep. by Ord. 1980-N, 8-7-80, eff. 9-1-80)
1-8-6: FUND FOR MEDICAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIGENT PERSONS:
   (A)   There is hereby created a separate fund in the County Treasury
designated as Fund for Medical Assistance to Indigent Persons.
   (B)   The money in this said fund shall be used for reimbursement of any
unpaid charges for medical care furnished to an indigent person who falls sick
in the County of Elko, other than care furnished on account of an injury
suffered in a motor vehicle accident.
   (C)   All monies collected or recovered pursuant to Assembly Bill 422 are to
be deposited to the said Fund for Medical Assistance to Indigent Persons, and
any interest earned on the money in the said fund must be deposited for credit
to the fund. Any claims against the fund shall be paid only on approval by the
Board of County Commissioners. Any monies remaining in the fund at the end of
any fiscal year shall not revert to the County General Fund, but shall remain
in the Fund for Medical Assistance to Indigent Persons.
   (D)   For each fiscal year beginning on or after July 1, 1985, the Board of
County Commissioners shall, before the end of each fiscal year, remit to the
State Treasurer, from the money in the Fund for Medical Assistance to Indigent
Persons, an amount of money equivalent to three-tenths (3/10) of one percent
(1%) of each one hundred dollars ($100.00) of assessed valuation of all taxable
property in the County for credit to the "supplemental fund" as defined by
section 2 (2) of the act.
   (E)   Such fund, shall be funded and administered as set forth in Assembly
Bill 422, amending chapter 428 of Nevada Revised Statutes, enacted by the 65th
Nevada State Legislature, 1985, and as it may be hereafter amended. (Ord. 1985-
J, 8-8-85, eff. 7-1-85)

CHAPTER 10
COUNTY PUBLIC DEFENDER
SECTION:
1-10-1: Creation Of Office
1-10-2: Qualifications
1-10-3: Appointment Of Public Defender And Deputies
1-10-4: Compensation; Law Practice
1-10-5: Representation
1-10-6: Duties
1-10-7: Disclaimer Of County Code
1-10-8: Recoupment By County Of Expenses Incurred In Providing A Public
Defender For Indigent Defendants
1-10-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
In accordance with N.R.S. 260.010, the office of Public Defender is created in
Elko County. The office of Public Defender is a full-time position. (Ord. 03-
2019, 6-5-2019)
1-10-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Public Defender must be a qualified attorney licensed in the State of
Nevada for a minimum of five (5) years, with a minimum of three (3) years
practicing criminal defense. The Public Defender shall become a resident of
Elko County upon appointment. Before entering upon the duties of their offices,
the Public Defender and all deputies will take the constitutional oath of
office. (Ord. 03-2019, 6-5-2019)
1-10-3: APPOINTMENT OF PUBLIC DEFENDER AND DEPUTIES:
   (A)   The Public Defender will be appointed by the Board of County
Commissioners of Elko County at a regularly held commission meeting. The Public
Defender serves at the pleasure of the Board of County Commissioners.
   (B)   The Public Defender may appoint deputies necessary for the proper
operation of the office, subject to prior budgetary approval by the Board of
County Commissioners. All deputies shall be qualified attorneys licensed in the
State of Nevada or qualified to practice law in the State of Nevada under the
rules of the Supreme Court and the Nevada State bar. (Ord. 03-2019, 6-5-2019)
1-10-4: COMPENSATION; LAW PRACTICE:
The compensation of the Public Defender and all deputy public defenders will be
fixed by the Board of Commissioners. Neither the Public Defender, nor any
deputy, may engage in the private practice of law, either civil or criminal,
from the date of appointment, except as allowed under their collective
bargaining agreement or at the discretion of the County Manager. (Ord. 03-2019,
6-5-2019)
1-10-5: REPRESENTATION:
   (A)   Indigent Defendant: The Public Defender will act as counsel for
indigent persons charged with a criminal offense or alleged to be mentally ill
in all cases when ordered to do so by a court of competent jurisdiction.
   (B)   Delinquent Juvenile: The Public Defender will act as counsel for
indigent juveniles and non-indigent juveniles alleged to be delinquent or in
need of supervision, if a parent or guardian does not retain an attorney and is
not likely to retain an attorney for the child.
   (C)   Child Welfare: The Public Defender will act as counsel for indigent
persons responsible for the welfare of a child and/or children and is alleged
to have abused or neglected a child and/or children.
   (D)   Other Cases: The Public Defender will act as counsel for indigent
persons whenever ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction or by the County
Manager.
   (E)   Discretionary: Nothing in this section should be construed to limit or
otherwise devoid the Public Defender’s discretion to represent indigent persons
in matters not herein mentioned, if the Public Defender determines that such
representation is required by the United States Constitution, the Nevada State
Constitution, or Nevada State Law. (Ord. 03-2019, 6-5-2019)
1-10-6: DUTIES:
The Public Defender will perform all duties as described and directed by Nevada
Statute and this chapter. (Ord. 03-2019, 6-5-2019)
1-10-7: DISCLAIMER OF COUNTY CODE:
Nothing contained in this chapter may be interpreted or construed as a creation
of, or an acknowledgment of, any duty owed to persons represented by the County
of Elko other than those specific requirements levied upon the County of Elko
by the Nevada Legislature. (Ord. 03-2019, 6-5-2019)
1-10-8: RECOUPMENT BY COUNTY OF EXPENSES INCURRED IN PROVIDING A PUBLIC
DEFENDER FOR INDIGENT DEFENDANTS:
If a defendant for whom an attorney is appointed at the public’s expense on
account of indigence has property subject to execution or has acquired such
property within six (6) years after the termination of the attorney’s
representation, the Court will determine the value of the legal services
provided and will render judgement for that amount in favor of the county which
furnished the Public Defender or otherwise paid for the defense. (Ord. 03-2019,
6-5-2019)
