1-11-3: UNINCORPORATED TOWN OF JARBIDGE; FORMATION:
   (A)   Upon petition of a sufficient number of registered voters within the
proposed unincorporated Town of Jarbidge, the Board of Elko County
Commissioners finds that it is in the best interests of the residents of the
proposed unincorporated Town of Jarbidge to form an unincorporated town to
provide certain of those town services listed in NRS 269.575.
   (B)   Accordingly, the unincorporated Town of Jarbidge is hereby formed to
provide for water distribution to the residents of the unincorporated Town, and
to comply with State and Federal water quality standards.
   (C)   The boundaries of the unincorporated Town of Jarbidge shall be the
contiguous unincorporated area as shown on the Official Map of Jarbidge
Townsite, accepted and approved by Judge Taber as the trustee for the use and
benefit of the occupants of the townsite of Jarbidge on August 26, 1920, and
filed on November 5, 1921, in the office of the Elko County Recorder as
document number 31210.
   (D)   The Board of Elko County Commissioners has determined that it can best
be served by the appointment of a Town Advisory Board consisting of three (3)
members. The Citizen's Advisory Council, Jarbidge, Nevada, as it exists by
authority of Elko County Code Section
2-1D-1, shall serve as the first Town Advisory Board. Elko County Code Section
2-1D-1 shall be amended and the Citizen's Advisory Council as therein
designated shall be hereinafter known and referred to as the Town Advisory
Board. (Ord. 1993-E, 8-18-1993, eff. 9-1-1993)
CHAPTER 12
PUBLIC GUARDIAN'S OFFICE
SECTION:
1-12-1: Office Of Public Guardian Established
1-12-2: Vacancy
1-12-3: Powers, Duties, Rights, And Responsibilities
1-12-4: Caseload
1-12-5: Records
1-12-6: Retention Of Attorney
1-12-7: Subordinates, Consultants And Assistants
1-12-8: Qualifications Of Person For Whom Public Guardian May Be Appointed;
Petition For Appointment
1-12-9: Investigation Of Financial Status Of Person For Whom Public Guardian Is
Requested
1-12-10: Allocation Of Costs Incurred In Appointment Proceedings And
Administrative Costs
1-12-11: Value Of Guardian's Services Allowable As Claim Against Ward's Estate;
Deposit Of Money Received By Public Guardian
1-12-12: Termination Of Appointment
1-12-13: Revocation Of Previous Appointments And Designations For Public
Guardian
1-12-14: Conflict Between Nevada Revised Statutes And This Code
1-12-1: OFFICE OF PUBLIC GUARDIAN ESTABLISHED:
The Elko County board of commissioners (hereinafter board) hereby establishes
the office of the public guardian for Elko County, Nevada.
   (A)   The public guardian is appointed for a term of four (4) years and
serves at the pleasure of the board.
   (B)   The public guardian must be a qualified elector of Elko County.
   (C)   The board shall set the compensation for the public guardian, which
shall be payable from the general fund. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-2: VACANCY:
   (A)   If any vacancy occurs in the office of public guardian, the vacancy
must be filled promptly by the board, pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes
253.170.
   (B)   The district court may designate any qualified person to serve as
acting public guardian until the board fills the vacancy in the office. (Ord.
2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-3: POWERS, DUTIES, RIGHTS, AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The public guardian shall have all the powers and duties of the individual
guardianships created by appointments of previous public guardians for
particular wards.
In the administration of any guardianship, to which the public guardian is
appointed, the public guardian shall have all the powers, duties, rights and
responsibilities as required by the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-
2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-4: CASELOAD:
The public guardian caseload must be no more than twenty five (25) active cases
at one time.
   (A)   All referrals in excess of the authorized caseload must be placed upon
a waiting list. The public guardian shall have the discretion to accept
referrals from the waiting list based upon greatest need.
   (B)   The public guardian shall immediately inform the board if the waiting
list exceeds twenty five (25) referrals. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-
2004)
1-12-5: RECORDS:
The public guardian must keep financial and other appropriate records
concerning all cases in which he/she is appointed as an individual guardian.
(Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-6: RETENTION OF ATTORNEY:
For the proper administration of a guardianship, the public guardian may retain
an attorney to assist him/her, rotating this employment in successive
guardianships among the attorneys practicing in Elko County, Nevada, who are
qualified by experience and willing to serve. The attorney fees must be paid
from the assets of the ward, if available. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-
2004)
1-12-7: SUBORDINATES, CONSULTANTS AND ASSISTANTS:
The public guardian, with the consent of the board, may:
   (A)   Employ subordinates necessary for the proper performance of his/her
duties.
   (B)   Contract for the services of consultants or assistants. (Ord. 2004-B,
8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-8: QUALIFICATIONS OF PERSON FOR WHOM PUBLIC GUARDIAN MAY BE APPOINTED;
PETITION FOR APPOINTMENT:
   (A)   A resident of Elko County, Nevada, who is eighteen (18) years of age
or older is eligible to have the public guardian appointed as his/her
individual guardian if he/she:
      1.   Has no relative or friend in Nevada able and willing to serve as
guardian, due to illness or other circumstance which prevents their effective
performance of guardian.
      2.   Lacks sufficient assets to provide the requisite compensation to a
private guardian.
      3.   Has been exploited or neglected by friends or family members.
      4.   By reason of mental illness, mental deficiency, advanced age,
disease, weakness of mind, or any other cause, is unable, without assistance to
properly manage and take care of self.
   (B)   The public guardian is the guardian of last resort. A referral to the
public guardian must be submitted and will be evaluated by the public guardian
prior to acceptance. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-9: INVESTIGATION OF FINANCIAL STATUS OF PERSON FOR WHOM PUBLIC GUARDIAN IS
REQUESTED:
The public guardian must investigate the financial status of any person for
whom the appointment of the public guardian as is requested. In connection with
the investigation, the public guardian may require that person to execute and
deliver any written requests or authorizations necessary to provide the public
guardian with access to records, otherwise confidential, needed to evaluate
eligibility. The public guardian may obtain information from any public record
office of the state or any of its agencies or subdivisions upon request and
without payment of any fees. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-10: ALLOCATION OF COSTS INCURRED IN APPOINTMENT PROCEEDINGS AND
ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS:
The costs incurred in the appointment proceedings and the administrative costs
of the guardian's services are not chargeable against the income or the estate
of the ward unless the district court determines at any time that the ward is
financially able to pay all or part of the costs. The district court shall
measure the ward's ability to pay pursuant to the factors listed in Nevada
Revised Statutes 253.230(2). (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-11: VALUE OF GUARDIAN'S SERVICES ALLOWABLE AS CLAIM AGAINST WARD'S ESTATE;
DEPOSIT OF MONEY RECEIVED BY PUBLIC GUARDIAN:
The reasonable value of the public guardian's services rendered must be allowed
as a claim against the estate of the ward. Money received in payment of a claim
against the estate of the ward must be deposited by the public guardian to the
credit of the county general fund. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-12: TERMINATION OF APPOINTMENT:
The district court may, at any time, terminate the appointment of the public
guardian as an individual guardian upon petition by the ward, of any interested
person, or on the district court's own motion if the services of the public
guardian are no longer necessary. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-13: REVOCATION OF PREVIOUS APPOINTMENTS AND DESIGNATIONS FOR PUBLIC
GUARDIAN:
The board revokes all previous appointments and designations of public
guardians regardless of the means by which these appointments and designations
were made and which predate the effective date hereof. (Ord. 2004-B, 8-4-2004,
eff. 9-26-2004)
1-12-14: CONFLICT BETWEEN NEVADA REVISED STATUTES AND THIS CODE:
In the event of a conflict of Nevada Revised Statutes, as those sections may be
amended from time to time, the provisions of state statute will control. (Ord.
2004-B, 8-4-2004, eff. 9-26-2004)
CHAPTER 13
GOVERNMENTAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-13-1: Protection To Local Governmental Officers And Employees Against
Reprisal And Retaliation
1-13-2: Definitions
1-13-3: Procedure To Report Improper Governmental Action
1-13-4: Reprisal And Retaliation Prohibited
1-13-5: Procedure To Report Reprisal Or Retaliatory Conduct
1-13-6: Procedure For Selecting A Hearing Officer
1-13-7: Procedure For Hearing Appeal
1-13-8: Procedure For Appeal To The Board Of Review
1-13-9: Use Of Provisions For Harassment Prohibited
1-13-1: PROTECTION TO LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES AGAINST
REPRISAL AND RETALIATION:
The public policy of Elko County is that an officer or an employee of Elko
County is encouraged to disclose, to the extent not expressly prohibited by
law, improper governmental action, and it is the intent of the Elko County
Board of Commissioners to protect the rights of Elko County officers and
employees who make a disclosure of improper governmental actions. (Ord. 05-
2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-2: DEFINITIONS:
 
IMPROPER GOVERNMENTAL ACTION: The same meaning as indicated in NRS 281.611(1).
                              (Ord. 05-2020, 7-15-2021)
 
1-13-3: PROCEDURE TO REPORT IMPROPER GOVERNMENTAL ACTION:
   (A)   Any person, officer, or employee may report improper governmental
action to any or all of the following:
      1.   The Director of the Elko County Human Resources Department;
      2.   The Elko County District Attorney;
      3.   The Elko County Public Defender; or
      4.   The Elko County Sheriff's Office.
   (B)   The report of improper governmental action may be made by phone,
email, mail, letter or any other manner that clearly communicates the improper
governmental action, and may be made anonymously.
   (C)   The Director of Human Resources, District Attorney, Public Defender or
Elko County Sheriff's Office receiving the report shall insure that the report
is investigated. (Ord. 05-2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-4: REPRISAL AND RETALIATION PROHIBITED:
   (A)   An Elko County Officer or Employee:
      1.   Shall use official authority or influence of the officer or employee
to remedy any reprisal or retaliatory action of which the officer or employee
becomes aware.
      2.   Shall not:
         (a)   Directly or indirectly use or attempt to use the official
authority or influence of the officer or employee to intimidate, threaten,
coerce, command, influence or attempt to intimidate, threaten, coerce, command
or influence another Elko County officer or employee, or any other local
governmental officer or employee, in an effort to interfere with, or prevent
the disclosure of, information concerning improper governmental action,
including, without limitation, by intimidating, threatening, coercing,
commanding, influencing or attempting to intimidate, threaten, coerce, command
or influence the other officer or employee to take reprisal or retaliatory
action.
         (b)   Fail to use the official authority or influence of the officer
or employee to remedy any reprisal or retaliatory action of which the officer
or employee becomes aware.
      2.   For the purposes of this section, use of "official authority or
influence" includes taking, directing others to take, recommending, processing
or approving any personnel action such as an appointment, promotion, transfer,
assignment, reassignment, reinstatement, restoration, reemployment, evaluation
or other disciplinary action. (Ord. 05-2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-5: PROCEDURE TO REPORT REPRISAL OR RETALIATORY CONDUCT:
   (A)   If an alleged violation of
1-13-4 occurs or any alleged reprisal or retaliatory action is taken against an
Elko County officer or employee who discloses information concerning improper
governmental action within 2 years after the information is disclosed, the
officer or employee may file a written appeal with any of the following County
Officers:
      1.   The Director of Human Resources for Elko County or designee;
      2.   The Elko County District Attorney or designee;
      3.   The Elko County Public Defender or designee;
      4.   The Elko County Sheriff's Office or designee.
   (B)   The written appeal must be accompanied by a statement that sets forth
with particularity, as applicable:
      1.   The facts and circumstances relating to the alleged violation.
      2.   The facts and circumstances under which the disclosure of improper
governmental action was made and the reprisal or retaliatory action that is
alleged to have been taken against the County Officer or employee. (Ord. 05-
2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-6: PROCEDURE FOR SELECTING A HEARING OFFICER:
The hearing officer shall be selected as follows:
   (A)   The officer or designee receiving the appeal shall act as the hearing
officer, unless the officer or designee receiving the appeal was the officer or
designee or officer or designee's agency that received the original complaint
for improper governmental action.
   (B)   If the officer or designee receiving the appeal is the officer or
designee or officer or designee's agency that received the original complaint
for improper governmental action, the officer or designee shall select another
officer listed in section five of this Chapter to be the hearing officer.
   (C)   If the officer or designee receiving the appeal determines there is a
conflict or a perceived conflict with the officer or designee acting as the
hearing officer or the officer or designee's office, the officer or employee
shall select another agency listed in Section Five of this Chapter to be the
hearing officer. (Ord. 05-2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-7: PROCEDURE FOR HEARING APPEAL:
   (A)   After receiving the appeal, the hearing officer shall give notice to
the officer or employee who is the subject of the appeal.
   (B)   The notice shall include the following:
      1.   The written appeal and information submitted to the hearing officer.
      2.   That the officer or employee has thirty (30) days to supply a
written response to the written appeal and any additional information helpful
to the hearing officer.
      3.   That the officer or employee's employment may be terminated as a
result of the hearing.
      4.   The date, time, and place where the hearing will take place.
      5.   The following warning: Please be advised that any further
retaliatory or reprisals against the appealing employee or officer may result
in further disciplinary action by the hearing officer.
   (C)   The hearing officer, after receiving any response from the officer or
employee, will hold a hearing. At the hearing, the hearing officer shall review
all the material and any further information offered by the appealing officer
or employee and the officer and employee who is the subject of the appeal. The
hearing officer may render a decision at the hearing or may make a written
response after the hearing. The hearing officer may make one of the following
two orders:
      1.   The proper person to desist and refrain from engaging in such a
violation or action that violates the provisions of this chapter; or
      2.   The termination of the employment of the proper person. (Ord. 05-
2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-8: PROCEDURE FOR APPEAL TO THE BOARD OF REVIEW:
   (A)   If the hearing officer terminates employment, the officer or employee
subject to the termination may appeal the decision to a Board of Review. The
Board of Review shall review all records and make one of the following
determinations:
      1.   Sustain the decision of the hearing officer.
      2.   Vacate the decision of the hearing officer.
   (B)   If the Review Board vacates the hearing officer's decision, the Review
Board may make an order to desist and refrain from engaging in such violation
or action that violates the provisions of this chapter.
   (C)   The decision of the Review Board shall be final.
   (D)   The Review Board shall consist of the following:
      1.   One person from the Elko County Human Resources Department.
      2.   One person from the Elko County District Attorney's Office.
      3.   One person from the Elko County Public Defender's Office.
   (E)   The representative from each office shall be the appointed or elected
official, or a designee selected by the appointed or elected official. (Ord.
05-2020, 7-15-2021)
1-13-9: USE OF PROVISIONS FOR HARASSMENT PROHIBITED:
An Elko County officer or employee shall not use the provisions of this Chapter
to harass another officer or employee, as applicable.
The provisions of this Chapter, inclusive, do not prohibit an Elko County
officer or employee from initiating proper disciplinary procedures against
another officer or employee, as applicable, who discloses untruthful
information concerning improper governmental action.
(Ord. 05-2020, 7-15-2021)
CHAPTER 14
ELKO COUNTY REGIONAL COMMUNICATIONS CENTER
SECTION:
1-14-1: Purpose
1-14-2: Organization
1-14-3: Duties
1-14-4: Criminal Justice Information
1-14-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the Elko County Regional Communications Center is to perform the
functions of a Public Safety Answering Point (PSAP), provide and administer the
emergency communication and dispatch of law enforcement, fire, emergency
medical services, and other public safety within the incorporated and
unincorporated areas of Elko County, except for in West Wendover and Owhyee.
(Ord. 2024-02, 2-7-2024)
1-14-2: ORGANIZATION:
The Elko County Regional Communications Center is an Elko County agency within
Elko County Emergency Management. The Elko County Emergency Manager shall
direct the operation and administration of the Elko County Regional
Communications Center.
(Ord. 2024-02, 2-7-2024)
1-14-3: DUTIES:
The Elko County Regional Communications Center has the following duties:
   A.   Provide public safety dispatch services for emergency and non-emergency
purposes for the various agencies of Elko County, incorporated cities within
the county, and other public safety agencies based within Elko County including
those that contract with Elko County or an incorporated city within the county.
   B.   Receive, screen, and take appropriate action on all emergency and non-
emergency calls for service from the public including requesting law
enforcement, fire, EMS or other public safety entities
   C.   Enter emergency assistance call information into the computer-aided
dispatch (CAD).
   D.   Input, modify, confirm, and validate information into and from NCIC and
NCJIS systems for agencies.
   E.   Provide information, instructions, and assistance to the public within
the appropriate scope of authority.
   F.   Provide detailed call information to first responders as needed,
maintain status and awareness of unit locations and relays information as
required.
   G.   Receives and relays information regarding incidents and other
activities to the appropriate agencies and staff.
   H.   Performs inquiries and criminal history checks for law enforcement
staff through NCIC and NCJIS systems or successor systems.
   I.   Through Elko County enter into contracts to provide similar services to
other public safety agencies.
   J.   Provide internal and external training as required to employees and
affiliated public safety personnel. Provide internal quality assurance for the
performance of duties and key system components.
   K.   Serves as an alternate or backup Public Safety Answering Point for
other emergency dispatch centers or agencies when necessary.
(Ord. 2024-02, 2-7-2024)
1-14-4: CRIMINAL JUSTICE INFORMATION: 
The Elko County Regional Communications Center shall comply with all the laws,
regulations, and rules applicable to the use and dissemination of NCIC and
NCJIS or any successor system’s criminal justice information.
(Ord. 2024-02, 2-7-2024)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1A
CITIZEN'S ADVISORY COUNCIL MOUNTAIN CITY
SECTION:
2-1A-1: Citizen's Advisory Council Created
2-1A-1: CITIZEN'S ADVISORY COUNCIL CREATED:
   (A)   The Board of County Commissioners, acting as the Mountain City Town
Board, Town of Mountain City, State of Nevada, has determined the Town board
can best be served by the appointment of a Citizen's Advisory Council to act in
an advisory and liaison capacity.
   (B)   The provisions designating the powers and duties and providing the
qualifications of the members of said Citizen's Advisory Council shall be
substantially the same as those listed in NRS 269-0242.
   (C)   The Citizen's Advisory Council shall consist of not less than three
(3) nor more than five (5) members.
   (D)   Each member of the Advisory Council shall be a resident and qualified
elector in the Town of Mountain City.
   (E)   The members of the Advisory Council must be appointed by the Board of
County Commissioners from a list of a number of qualified persons, equal in
number to the number of positions on the Advisory Council which are to be
filled, elected at an informal election. Notice of the election must be posted
in accordance with NRS 241.020. The election must be held in the Town in
November of the year of the general election.
      1.   Any qualified person seeking election to the Advisory Council shall
submit his name to the Council not less than thirty (30) days prior to the next
Council meeting in the year of the election.
      2.   The Council shall post the names of all persons seeking election on
its agenda consistent with NRS 241.020.
      3.   An informal vote in a manner designated by the Council shall be held
for each member seeking election.
   (F)   The list of names of the persons elected must be presented to the
Board of County Commissioners at their first meeting in December of the year of
the general election. The persons appointed to the Advisory Council shall serve
their respective terms at the pleasure of the Board. (Ord. 1982-K, 9-8-82, eff.
10-1-82)
   (G)   The members of the Advisory Council first appointed by the Board of
County Commissioners shall serve until the first Monday in January following
the next general election, and thereafter the terms of office of the members of
the Advisory Council are for two (2) years and begin on the first Monday in
January following each general election. If a vacancy occurs in the membership
of the Citizen's Advisory Council due to removal by the Board of County
Commissioners, resignation of a member, death of a member or other cause, the
Board of County Commissioners shall appoint a qualified resident of the Town to
fill the vacancy and become a regular member of the Citizen's Advisory Council
for the unexpired term. (Ord. 1982-K, 9-8-82, eff. 10-1-82; amd. Ord. 1984-H,
9-13-84, eff. 10-1-84)
   (H)   The Advisory Council shall assist the Board of County Commissioners in
governing the Town by acting as liaison between the residents of the Town and
the Board. The Advisory Council and the Board shall cooperate to inform each
other of all matters of interest to the Town and its residents. The Advisory
Council shall not expend or contract any Town money for any purpose.
   (I)   The members of the Advisory Council shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 1982-K, 9-8-82, eff. 10-1-82)
   (J)   Should the population of the Town of Mountain City exceed one thousand
(1,000) persons, then, in that event, members of the Advisory Council shall not
be elected officials or elected members of any other governmental entity or
body, or any public or quasi-public corporation organized under the laws of
this State, including, without limitation, counties, cities, unincorporated
towns, school districts, hospital districts, general improvement districts and
other special districts. (Ord. 1987-J, 12-16-87, eff. 1-21-88)
CHAPTER 1B
TOWN ADVISORY BOARD, MONTELLO
SECTION:
2-1B-1: Town Advisory Board Created
2-1B-1: TOWN ADVISORY BOARD CREATED:
   (A)   The Town Advisory Board shall have the powers and duties and require
for membership the qualifications described in chapter 269 of the Nevada
Revised Statutes.
      1.   The unincorporated Town of Montello shall include all of the portion
of Section 17, Township 39 North, Range 69 East, MDB & M, which lies
northwesterly of a line parallel with and two hundred feet (200') distant from,
in a northwesterly direction measured at right angles, the original center line
of the Southern Pacific Transportation Company's main line track between
Sacramento, California and Ogden, Utah; which area includes, but is not limited
to, the original townsite of Montello as described in the "Map of the Town of
Montello" recorded in the office of the Elko County Recorder with file Number
107470, filed September 15, 1977.
      2.   The unincorporated Town of Montello shall also include the "certain
buildings and property known as the Culver House and the Burton House situated
in the Town of Montello, County of Elko, State of Nevada, which buildings are
on a parcel of land one hundred sixty nine feet by one hundred feet (169' x
100') north of the southeast corner of the NE1/4 of Section 18, in T. 39 N. R.
69 E. MDB & M and running thence first, west a distance of one hundred sixty
nine feet (169') to a point, then north a distance of one hundred feet (100')
to a point; then at right, angles east a distance of one hundred sixty nine
feet (169') to a point; thence right angles south a distance of one hundred
feet (100') to the place of beginning. (Ord. 1982-K, 9-8-82, eff. 10-1-82)
   (C)   The Town Advisory Board shall be composed of five (5) members who
shall be selected by and serve at the pleasure of the Elko County Board of
Commissioners. Each member of the Advisory Board shall be a resident and
qualified elector in the Town of Montello. (Ord. 1982-K, 9-8-82, eff. 10-1-82;
amd. Ord. 1984-H, 9-13-84, eff. 10-1-84)
   (D)   The terms of office of the Town Advisory Board members shall be two
(2) years. The terms shall expire on the first Monday in January of each odd
numbered year. If a vacancy occurs in the membership of the Town Advisory
Board, due to removal by the Board of County Commissioners, resignation of a
member, death of a member, or other cause, the Board of County Commissioners
shall appoint a qualified resident of the Town to fill the vacancy and become a
regular member of the Town Advisory Board for the unexpired term. (Ord. 1984-H,
9-13-84, eff. 10-1-84)
   (E)   The Town Advisory Board of the unincorporated Town of Montello shall
specifically have the power to manage the water distribution and sewage
collection services; subject to the limitation that no expenditure shall exceed
the amount budgeted for such expenditures in an annual budget previously
approved by the Elko County Board of Commissioners.
   (F)   The members of the Town Advisory Board shall serve without
compensation.
   (G)   The Advisory Board shall assist the Board of County Commissioners in
governing the Town by acting as liaison between the residents of the Town and
the Board and by keeping the Board advised as to all matters of interest to the
Town and the residents thereof; but, the Advisory Board shall not expend or
contract any Town funds for any purpose. (Ord. 1982-K, 9-8-82, eff. 10-1-82)
   (H)   Should the population of the Town of Montello exceed one thousand
(1,000) persons, then, in that event, members of the Town Advisory Board shall
not be elected officials or elected members of any other governmental entity or
body, or any public or quasi-public corporation organized under the laws of
this State, including, without limitation, counties, cities, unincorporated
towns, school districts, hospital districts, general improvement districts and
other special districts. (Ord. 1987-J, 12-16-87, eff. 1-21-88)

2-1C-1: TOWN ADVISORY BOARD CREATED:

   (H)   Should the population of the Town of Jackpot exceed one thousand

CHAPTER 1D
TOWN ADVISORY BOARD, JARBIDGE, NEVADA
SECTION:
2-1D-1: Town Advisory Board Created
2-1D-1: TOWN ADVISORY BOARD CREATED:
   (A)   The Town Advisory Board: The Board of Elko County Commissioners has
determined that it can best be served by the appointment of a Town Advisory
Board representing the unincorporated Town of Jarbidge, to act in an advisory
and liaison capacity with respect to governing the affairs of such
unincorporated town.
   (B)   Membership: The Town Advisory Board shall consist of three (3)
members.
   (C)   Requirements: Each member shall be a resident and qualified elector of
the unincorporated Town of Jarbidge.
   (D)   Appointment: The members of the Town Advisory Board shall be appointed
by the Board of Elko County Commissioners from a list of a number of qualified
and interested persons.
      1.   Any qualified and interested person seeking appointment to the Town
Advisory Board shall submit his or her name to the Board of Elko County
Commissioners at their first meeting in December of the year of appointment.
      2.   The persons appointed to the Town Advisory Board shall serve at the
pleasure of the Board of Elko County Commissioners.
   (E)   Terms: The terms of the members of the Town Advisory Board shall be
for two (2) years, and begin on the first Monday in January following each
general election. If a vacancy occurs in the membership of the Town Advisory
Board due to removal of a member by the Board of Elko County Commissioners,
resignation of a member, death of a member, or other cause, the Board of Elko
County Commissioners shall appoint a qualified resident of the unincorporated
Town to fill the vacancy and become a regular member of the Town Advisory Board
for the unexpired term.
   (F)   Assistance to County Commissioners: The Town Advisory Board shall
assist the Board of Elko County Commissioners in governing the unincorporated
town by acting as liaison between the residents of the unincorporated town and
the Board of Elko County Commissioners. The Town Advisory Board and the Board
of Elko County Commissioners shall cooperate to inform each other of all
matters of interest to the unincorporated town and its residents. The existence
and activities of the Town Advisory Board shall in no way diminish the
responsibility of the Board of Elko County Commissioners in performing its
duties, but that the Town Advisory Board shall bring to bear on the problems of
the unincorporated town the knowledge of a representative group of residents
thereof.
   (G)   Expenditures: The Town Advisory Board shall not expend or contract to
expend any money for any purpose.
   (H)   Rules and Regulations: The Town Advisory Board shall elect officers
from within its membership, fix such time and place of meetings, adopt such
rules and procedures, and keep such minutes and records as it shall determine
consistent with the purposes of this Chapter.
   (I)   Quorum: A majority of the Town Advisory Board shall be necessary to
constitute a quorum, and a vote of the majority of the whole Advisory Board
shall be necessary to carry any question.
   (J)   Compensation: The members of the Town Advisory Board shall serve
without compensation.
   (K)   Open Meetings: The meetings of the Town Advisory Board shall be
subject to the Open Meeting Law - NRS 241.010 et. seq.
   (L)   Growth: Should the population of the unincorporated Town of Jarbidge
exceed one thousand (1,000) persons, then in that event, members of the Town
Advisory Board shall not be elected officials or elected members of any other
governmental entity or body, or any public or quasi-public corporation
organized under the laws of this State, including, without limitation,
counties, cities, unincorporated towns, school districts, hospital districts,
general improvement districts, and other special districts. (Ord. 1993-R, 12-
12-93, eff. 12-20-93)

2-2-2: Duties Of County Clerk

(Ord., 8-6-1963)
CHAPTER 3
DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
SECTION:
2-3-1: Department Created
2-3-2: Powers And Duties
2-3-3: Creation Of Separate Positions
2-3-4: Parcel Maps; Authority Of Department
2-3-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created the Elko County Department of Community Development
with the following Divisions included: Public Works, Building and Safety,
Planning and Zoning and County Engineer. (Ord. 1996-N, 2-6-1997, eff. 2-24-
1997)
2-3-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (A)   The Department of Community Development shall perform or supervise the
following functions and shall perform all related duties as required in this
Chapter or by operation of the laws of the State or as hereinafter required by
future ordinances or future Nevada State laws and as required by Chapter 8 of
Title 5 of this County Code:
      1.   Supervise or perform all the duties of the County Surveyor as
provided in the Nevada Revised Statutes 255.110.
      2.   Supervise or perform all County water right surveying and comply
with the provisions of the Nevada Revised Statutes 533.080.
      3.   Supervise or perform all County engineering services as defined by
the Nevada Revised Statutes 254.040.
      4.   Supervise or perform all duties of drafting, blue printing, and
similar professional or technical work for all County offices including, but
not limited to, the County Commissioners, the County Assessor, the County
Manager, the County District Attorney, the County Recorder, and the County
Planning Commission.
      5.   Supervise or perform all inspections, plan checking and code
enforcement of the County.
      6.   Aid in the enforcement of all State subdivision laws and County
subdivision ordinances.
      7.   Aid in the enforcement of all State zoning laws and County zoning
ordinances.
   (B)   The County Commissioners expressly reserve herein the powers and
rights granted in chapters 254 and 255 of Nevada Revised Statutes.
   (C)   The Department of Community Development shall advise on a regular
basis with the County Commissioners, reporting to that body as periodically
required by the Commissioners on matters coming within the duties of that
office as herein defined or as hereinafter provided in future ordinances or
State laws.
   (D)   The Department of Community Development shall lend full cooperation
and advice upon request to all County agencies including, but not limited to,
the County Road Supervisor, the County Planning Commission, the County District
Attorney, and any other local governmental agencies and offices which
hereinafter may be created for the purpose of dealing with the use,
development, subdivision, zoning classification, variance requests, building
permits of and on lands within the County.
   (E)   The Department of Community Development shall also advise upon request
any commission, group, or body, comprised of the various local government
entities in the County who have been duly and lawfully formed to deal with the
use, development, subdivision, zoning classification, variance request,
building permit and structure approval, concerning lands within the County.
   (F)   The Department of Community Development is designated to execute, when
needed, a certificate approving a boundary line adjustment. (Ord. 1996-N, 2-6-
1997, eff. 2-24-1997)
2-3-3: CREATION OF SEPARATE POSITIONS:
Nothing in this Chapter shall prevent the County Commissioners from creating
separate County positions to undertake any of the duties as they are defined
for the Department of Community Development and at their discretion fix the
compensation for the same. (Ord. 1996-N, 2-6-1997, eff. 2-24-1997)
2-3-4: PARCEL MAPS; AUTHORITY OF DEPARTMENT:
   (A)   The Department of Community Development shall have the power and
authority to approve a parcel map, or waive the requirements of a parcel map or
survey for a parcel map, without further action by the Planning Commission or
the Board of Commissioners.
   (B)   All parcel maps shall comply with the requirements of chapter 278 of
Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 1996-N, 2-6-1997, eff. 2-24-1997)
CHAPTER 4
PLANNING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-4-1: Members of Planning Commission; Appointment, Compensation, Term,
Removal, Vacancies
2-4-2: Meetings and Records of County Planning Commission
2-4-3: Chairman; Election Term
2-4-4: Employees
2-4-5: Expenditures
2-4-6: Master Plan; Adoption
2-4-7: Subject Matter of Master Plan
2-4-8: School Board Notified of Master Plan
2-4-9: Commission to Promote Public Interest in Master Plan; Powers
2-4-10: Form of Master Plan
2-4-11: Notices, Hearing on Adoption of Master Plan
2-4-12: Governing Body to Put Adopted Master Plan Into Effect
2-4-13: Acquisition and Abandonment of Property; Construction of Public
Buildings
2-4-14: Land Use, Classification and Districts; Regulations
2-4-15: Changes of Land Use Classifications; Notice and Hearing
2-4-16: Jurisdiction of Planning Commission
2-4-17: Definitions
2-4-1: MEMBERS OF PLANNING COMMISSION; APPOINTMENT, COMPENSATION, TERM,
REMOVAL, VACANCIES:
   (A)   The Elko County Planning Commission shall consist of seven (7)
members. The members of the Planning Commission shall be appointed by the
Chairman of the Board of County Commissioners, with the approval of the
governing body. The members shall hold no other public office, except that one
such member may be a member of the Zoning Board of Adjustment.
   (B)   All members of the Commission shall serve as such without
compensation, except reasonable travelling expenses made necessary in the
fulfillment of their duties.
   (C)   The term of each member appointed after the date of passage of this
Ordinance shall be four (4) years, or until his successor takes office, except
that the term of two (2) of the members of the first Commission shall be three
(3) years and the respective terms of two (2) members of the first Commission
shall be one and two (2) years..
   (D)   Members may be removed, after public hearing, by a majority vote of
the Board of County Commissioners for inefficiency, neglect of duty or
malfeasance of office.
   (E)   Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term
shall be filled for the unexpired term.
2-4-2: MEETINGS AND RECORDS OF COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION:
   (A)   The Commission shall hold at least one regular meeting in each month.
   (B)   It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a
record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which
records shall be a public record. (Ord. 1976-H, 4-5-76)
2-4-3: CHAIRMAN; ELECTION, TERM:
The Planning Commission shall elect its chairman from among the appointed
members. The term of chairman shall be one year with eligibility for re-
election.
2-4-4: EMPLOYEES:
   (A)   In addition to electing its chairman, the Commission shall create and
fill such other of its offices as it may determine.
   (B)   The Commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for
its work, whose appointment, promotion, demotion and removal shall be subject
to the same provisions of law as govern other corresponding civil employees of
the County.
   (C)   The Commission may also contract with city and County planners,
engineers, architects and other consultants for such services as it may
require.
2-4-5: EXPENDITURES:
The expenditures of the Commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the
amounts appropriated for the purpose by the Board of County Commissioners,
which shall provide the funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the
Commission's work.
2-4-6: MASTER PLAN; ADOPTION:
   (A)   The Planning Commission shall prepare and adopt a comprehensive, long-
term, general plan for the physical development of the County, which in the
Commission's judgment bears relation to the planning thereof.
   (B)   The plans shall be known as the Master Plan and shall be so prepared
that all or portions thereof may be adopted by the Board of County
Commissioners, as provided in this Chapter, as a basis for the development of
the County for such reasonable period of time next ensuing after the adoption
thereof as may practically be covered thereby. (Ord. dated 8-8-61)
2-4-7: SUBJECT MATTER OF MASTER PLAN:
   (A)   The Master Plan, with the accompanying charts, drawings, diagrams,
schedules and reports, shall include each of the following subject matter or
portions thereof as are appropriate to the County of Elko and as may be made
the basis for the physical development thereof:
      1.   COMMUNITY DESIGN. Standards and principles governing the subdivision
of land and suggestive patterns for community design and development.
      2.   CONSERVATION PLAN. For the conservation, development and utilization
of natural resources, including water and its hydraulic force, underground
water, water supply, forests, soils, rivers and other waters, harbors,
fisheries, wildlife, minerals and other natural resources. The Plan shall also
cover the reclamation of land and waters, flood control, prevention and control
of the pollution of streams and other waters, regulation of the use of land in
stream channels and other areas required for the accomplishment of the
conservation plan, prevention, control and correction of the erosion of soils
through proper clearing, grading and landscaping, beaches and shores, and
protection of water sheds. The Plan shall also indicate the maximum tolerable
air pollution level.
      3.   ECONOMIC PLAN. Showing recommended schedules for the allocation and
expenditure of public funds in order to provide for the economical and timely
execution of the various components of the plan.
      4.   HOUSING. Survey of housing conditions and needs and plans and
procedure for improvement of housing standards and for the provision of
adequate housing.
      5.   LAND USE PLAN. An inventory and classification of natural land types
and of existing land cover and uses, and comprehensive plans for the most
desirable utilization of land.
      6.   POPULATION PLAN. An estimate of the total population which the
natural resources of the County will support on a continuing basis without
reasonable impairment.
      7.   PUBLIC BUILDINGS. Showing locations and arrangement of civic centers
and other public buildings, including the architecture thereof and the
landscape treatment of the grounds thereof.
      8.   PUBLIC SERVICES AND FACILITIES. Showing general plans for sewage,
drainage and utilities, and rights-of-way, easements and facilities therefor.
      9.   RECREATION PLAN. Showing a comprehensive system of recreation areas,
including natural reservations, parks, parkways, reserved river bank strips,
beaches, playgrounds and other recreation areas, including when practicable the
locations and proposed development thereof.
      10.   SEISMIC SAFETY PLAN. Consisting of an identification and appraisal
of seismic hazards such as susceptibility to surface ruptures from faulting, to
ground shaking or to ground failures.
      11.   SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL PLAN. Showing general plans for disposal of
solid waste.
      12.   STREETS AND HIGHWAYS PLAN. Showing the general locations and widths
of a comprehensive system of major traffic thoroughfares and other traffic ways
and of streets and the recommended treatment thereof, building line setbacks,
and a system of street naming or numbering, and house numbering, with
recommendations concerning proposed changes.
      13.   TRANSIT PLAN. Showing a proposed system of transit lines, including
rapid transit, streetcar, motorcoach and trolley coach lines and related
facilities.
      14.   TRANSPORTATION PLAN. Showing a comprehensive transportation system,
including location of rights-of-way, terminals, viaducts and grade separations.
The plan may also include port, harbor, aviation and related facilities.
   (B)   The Commission may prepare and adopted, as part of the Master Plan,
other and additional plans and reports dealing with such other subjects as may
in its judgment be related to the physical development of the County of Elko.
and nothing contained in this Ordinance shall be deemed to prohibit the
preparation and adoption of any such subject as a part of the Master Plan.
(Ord. 1976-H, 4-8-76)
2-4-8: SCHOOL BOARD NOTIFIED OF MASTER PLAN:
The Planning Commission shall, during the formulation of plans for community
design and public buildings, notify the Board of Trustees of the Elko County
School District of the preparation of such plans to the end that adequate and
properly located school sites may be provided for. (Ord. dated. 8-8-61)
2-4-9: COMMISSION TO PROMOTE PUBLIC INTEREST IN MASTER PLAN; POWERS:
   (A)   The Commission shall endeavor to promote public interest in an
understanding of the Master Plan and of official plans and regulations relating
thereto. As a means of furthering the purpose of a Master Plan, the Commission
shall annually make recommendations to the Elko County Board of Commissioners
for the implementation of the Plan.
   (B)   It shall also consult and advise with public officials and agencies,
public utility companies, civic, educational, professional and other
organizations, and with citizens generally with relation to the carrying out of
such plans.
   (C)   The Commission and its members, officers and employees, in the
performance of their functions, may enter unto any land and make examinations
and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon.
   (D)   In general, the Commission shall have such power as may be necessary
to enable it to fulfill its functions and carry out the provisions of this
Ordinance.
2-4-10: FORM OF MASTER PLAN:
The Master Plan shall be a map, together with such charts, drawings, diagrams,
schedules, reports, ordinances or other printed or published material, or any
one or a combination of any of the foregoing as may be considered essential to
the purposes set forth in this Ordinance. (Ord. 1976-H; 4-8-76)
2-4-11: NOTICES, HEARINGS ON ADOPTION OF MASTER PLAN:
   (A)   Adoption of Master Plan and Amendments by the Commission; Notice,
Hearings, Resolutions, Attested Copies:
      1.   Before adopting the Master Plan or any part of it, or any
substantial amendments thereof, the Planning Commission shall hold at least one
public hearing thereon, notice of the time and place of which shall be given at
least by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the County,
at least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing.
      2.   The adoption of the Master Plan, or of any amendments, extensions or
additions thereof, shall be by resolution of the Commission carried by the
affirmative votes of not less than two- thirds (2/3) of the total membership of
the Commission.
The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps, descriptive matter and other
matters intended by the Commission to constitute the Plan or any amendment,
addition or extension thereof, and the action taken shall be recorded on the
map and plan and descriptive matter by the identifying signatures of the
secretary and chairman of the Commission.
      3.   No plan or map, hereafter, shall have indicated thereon that it is a
part of the Master Plan until it shall have been adopted as part of the Master
Plan by the Commission as herein provided for the adoption thereof, whenever
changed conditions or future studies by the Commission require such amendments,
extensions or additions.
      4.   An attested copy of any part, amendment, extension of or addition to
the Master Plan adopted by the Planning Commission shall be certified to the
Board of County Commissioners.
   (B)   Adoption of Master Plan by Governing Board; Notice, Hearings,
Procedure for Changes in Plan:
      1.   Upon receipt of a certified copy of the Master Plan, or of any part
thereof, as adopted by the Planning Commission, the Board of County
Commissioners may adopt such parts thereof as may practicably be applied to the
development of the County for a reasonable period of time next ensuing.
      2.   The parts shall thereupon be endorsed and certified as Master Plans
thus adopted for the territory covered, and are hereby declared to be
established to conserve and promote the public health, safety and general
welfare.
      3.   Before adopting any plan or part thereof, the Board of County
Commissioners shall hold at least one public hearing thereon, notice of the
time and place of which shall be published at least once in a newspaper of
general circulation in the County at least ten (10) days before the date of the
hearing.
      4.   No change in or additions to the Master Plan or any part thereof, as
adopted by the Planning Commission, shall be made by the Board of County
Commissioners in adopting the same until the proposed change or additions shall
have been referred to the Planning Commission for a report thereon. An attested
copy of the report shall have been filed with the Board of County
Commissioners. Failure of the Planning Commission to so report within forty
(40) days, or such longer period as may be designated by the Board of County
Commissioners, after such reference shall be deemed to be approval of the
proposed change or addition.
2-4-12: GOVERNING BODY TO PUT ADOPTED MASTER PLAN INTO EFFECT:
   (A)   When the Board of County Commissioners shall have adopted a master
plan or part thereof for the County of Elko, or any major section or district
thereof, the Board of County Commissioners shall, upon recommendation of the
Planning Commission, determine upon reasonable and practical means for putting
into effect the master plan or part thereof, in order that the same will serve
as a pattern and guide for that kind of orderly physical growth and development
of the County of Elko which will cause the least amount of natural resource
impairment and will conform to the adopted population plan, where required, and
as a basis for efficient expenditure of funds thereof relating to the subjects
of the Master Plan.
   (B)   The Board of County Commissioners may adopt and use such procedures as
may be necessary for this purpose. (Ord. 1976-H, 4-8-76)
2-4-13: ACQUISITION AND ABANDONMENT OF PROPERTY; CONSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC
BUILDINGS:
   (A)   Whenever the Board of County Commissioners shall have adopted a Master
Plan or one or more subject matters thereof for the County or for any major
section or district thereof, no street, square, park or other public way,
ground or open space shall be acquired by dedication or otherwise except by
bequest, and no street or public way shall be closed or abandoned and no public
building or structure shall be constructed or authorized in the area for which
the Master Plan or one or more subject matters thereof shall have been adopted
by the Board of County Commissioners until the location, character and extent
thereof shall have been submitted to and shall have been approved by the
Planning Commission.
   (B)   In case of disapproval thereof by the Planning Commission, the
Planning Commission shall communicate its reasons to the Board of County
Commissioners which may overrule the disapproval by a majority vote of its
entire membership.
   (C)   If the authorization, acquisition, financing or acceptance of such
public street, square, park or other public way, grounds or open space or the
construction or authorization of such public building or structure be vested by
law or charter provisions in some governmental body, commission or board other
than the Board of County Commissioners, then such governmental body, commission
or board having jurisdiction shall first submit to the Planning Commission the
location, character and extent of the proposed public improvement for its
approval. In the event that the Planning Commission shall disapprove the same,
its disapproval may only be overruled by such other governmental body, board or
commission by a vote of not less than two-thirds (2/3) of its entire
membership.
   (D)   Failure of the Commission to act upon such submission within forty
(40) days from and after the date of the official submission to the Commission
by the Board of County Commissioners or by such other governmental body, board
or commission, shall be deemed approval by the Planning Commission. (Ord. dated
8-8-61)
2-4-14: LAND USE, CLASSIFICATIONS AND DISTRICTS; REGULATIONS:
   (A)   For any and all of the purposes of this Ordinance, the Board of County
Commissioners may divide the County of Elko into districts of such number,
shape and area as may be deemed best suited to carry out the purposes of this
Ordinance. Within such districts it may regulate and restrict the erection,
construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair or use of the buildings,
structures or land.
   (B)   Such regulations shall be made in accordance with the Master Plan for
land use and shall be designated:
      1.   To preserve the quality of air and water resources.
      2.   To promote the conservation of open space and the protection of
other natural and scenic resources from unreasonable impairment.
      3.   To provide for recreational needs.
      4.   To protect life and property in areas subject to floods, landslides
and other natural disasters.
      5.   To conform to the adopted population plan, if required by this
Ordinance.
      6.   To develop a timely, orderly and efficient arrangement of
transportation and public facilities and services.
      7.   To insure that the development on land is commensurate with the
character and the physical limitations of the land.
      8.   To take into account the immediate and long-ranged financial impact
of the application of particular land to particular kinds of development, and
the relative suitability of such land for such development.
      9.   To promote health and the general welfare.
   (C)   Such regulations shall be made with reasonable consideration, among
other things, to the character of the district and its peculiar suitability for
particular uses, and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and
encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the County of Elko.
2-4-15: CHANGES OF LAND USES CLASSIFICATIONS; NOTICE AND HEARING:
The Board of County Commissioners shall provide for the manner in which such
regulations and restrictions and the boundaries of such districts shall be
determined, established and enforced, and from time to time amended,
supplemented or changed.
However, no such regulation, restriction or boundary shall become effective
until after a public hearing in relation thereto, at which parties in interest
and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard. At least ten (10) days'
notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be published in an official
newspaper, or a newspaper of general circulation, in the County of Elko. (Ord.
1976-H, 4-8-76)
2-4-16: JURISDICTION OF PLANNING COMMISSION:
The jurisdiction of the Planning Commission shall be Countywide except within
the limits of the incorporated cities and towns wherein a city or town planning
commission has been formed and is acting. (Ord. dated 8-8-61)
2-4-17: DEFINITIONS:
Words and terms used herein are as defined by N.R.S. 278.010, as amended from
time to time. (Ord. 1976-H, 4-8-76)
CHAPTER 5
ADVISORY COMMITTEES
SECTION:
2-5-1: Advisory Committees Created
2-5-1: ADVISORY COMMITTEES CREATED:
   (A)   The Board of County Commissioners may create advisory committees by
resolution for any purpose relating to the County about which the Board desires
study or advice.
   (B)   The resolution shall provide for:
      1.   The size of the committee,
      2.   The qualifications of the committee members,
      3.   The selection of the committee members,
      4.   The exact purpose of the committee,
      5.   Any other requirements or procedures as the Board of County
Commissioners deems appropriate.
   (C)   Any County advisory committee formed under this Chapter shall be
subject to the Nevada Open Meeting Law. (Ord. 1997-C, 3-19-1997, eff. 4-3-1997)
CHAPTER 6
ADVISORY BOARD ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE
SECTION:
2-6-1: Advisory Board Created
2-6-2: Qualifications
2-6-3: Duties of Board
2-6-4: Duties of Advisory Board
2-6-1: ADVISORY BOARD CREATED:
There shall be an Advisory Board on Domestic Violence. Such a Board shall
consist of three (3) members appointed by the Elko County Commissioners.
2-6-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
   (A)   At least one member will be a representative of Elko County, or
District Health Department, or the Rural Mental Health Center; and
   (B)   The other two (2) members shall be persons familiar with the problems
associated with domestic violence, such as former victims of domestic violence,
representatives of organizations which assist such victims, attorneys
experienced in domestic relations, social workers, counselors, teachers and
ministers.
   (C)   The terms of each member shall be as follows:
      1.   One member shall be designated by the Elko County Commissioners to
serve the duration of 1982. The subsequent appointed member shall serve a term
of three (3) calendar years.
      2.   One member shall be designated by the Elko County Commissioners to
serve through the calendar year of 1983. The subsequent appointed member shall
serve a term of three (3) calendar years.
      3.   One member shall be designated by the Elko County Commissioners to
serve through the calendar year of 1984. The subsequent appointed member shall
serve a term of three (3) calendar years.
2-6-3: DUTIES OF BOARD:
The Advisory Board on Domestic Violence shall advise the Elko County
Commissioners on how best to distribute funds collected for victims of domestic
violence.
2-6-4: DUTIES OF ADVISORY BOARD:
The Advisory Board on domestic violence shall:
   (A)   Examine the quarterly and annual reports as provided by each
organization receiving a grant from the Board of County Commissioners for the
assistance to victims of domestic violence; and
   (B)   Evaluate the effectiveness of the respective organizations in aiding
victims of domestic violence; and
   (C)   Report its conclusions and recommendations to the Board of County
Commissioners. (Ord. 1982-F, 4-19-82, eff. 5-11-82)
CHAPTER 7
CENTRAL NEVADA REGIONAL WATER AUTHORITY
SECTION:
2-7-1: Agreement To Join
2-7-2: Directors Appointed
2-7-3: Effective Date Of Membership
2-7-1: AGREEMENT TO JOIN:
Elko County agrees to join the central Nevada regional water authority as
outlined in the cooperative agreement approved by the Elko County board of
commissioners on August 4, 2005. (Ord. 08-2005, 10-6-2005, eff. 10-7-2005)
2-7-2: DIRECTORS APPOINTED:
Elko County shall appoint three (3) directors of the central Nevada regional
water authority.
   (A)   The qualifications of each director shall be determined by the Elko
County board of commissioners.
   (B)   Each director shall serve a two (2) year term. Each director may be
appointed to two (2) additional two (2) year terms.
   (C)   The Elko County board of commissioners may remove a director by a
majority vote before the director's term expires. (Ord. 08-2005, 10-6-2005,
eff. 10-7-2005)
2-7-3: EFFECTIVE DATE OF MEMBERSHIP:
Elko County's membership in the central Nevada water authority shall be
effective when the cooperative agreement is approved by another member and the
cooperative agreement is approved or deemed approved by the Nevada attorney
general, pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 277.140. (Ord. 08-2005, 10-6-2005,
eff. 10-7-2005)
CHAPTER 8
BOARD ATTENDANCE POLICY
SECTION:
2-8-1: Short Title
2-8-2: Purpose And Intent
2-8-3: Application
2-8-4: Policy
2-8-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the ELKO COUNTY BOARD ATTENDANCE POLICY. (Ord.
03-2009, 5-6-2009, eff. 7-28-2009)
2-8-2: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
Elko County boards, commissions and committees have had problems in getting
quorums present at meetings. The lack of a quorum creates a burden on staff and
attending board members. The lack of a quorum causes needless expense to the
county for payment of travel expenses, and meeting advertising. (Ord. 03-2009,
5-6-2009, eff. 7-28-2009)
2-8-3: APPLICATION:
This policy applies to any Elko County appointed board, commission, or
committee now or hereinafter existing, unless the Nevada Revised Statutes
provide otherwise. (Ord. 03-2009, 5-6-2009, eff. 7-28-2009)
2-8-4: POLICY:
   (A)   Any member of an Elko County appointed board, commission, or committee
shall notify staff of an absence prior to the meeting. Staff shall notify the
Elko County manager if a board, commission or committee member is absent from
three (3) regularly scheduled meetings in a row or is absent from five (5)
meetings within one calendar year without notifying staff.
   (B)   Any member missing three (3) regularly scheduled meetings in a row or
misses five (5) meetings within one calendar year without notifying staff prior
to the meeting shall be deemed to have resigned from the board, commission or
committee. (Ord. 03-2009, 5-6-2009, eff. 7-28-2009)
TITLE 3
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODES
SECTION:
3-1-1: Codes Adopted
3-1-2: Future Editions Adopted
3-1-3: Definitions
3-1-4: Amendments And Modifications To Building Codes
3-1-5: Restrictions
3-1-6: Hazardous Wastes, Storage Or Disposal Permits Prohibited
3-1-7: Penalties
3-1-1: CODES ADOPTED:
In all construction hereafter to be made within Elko County, the same shall be
in accordance with what is now known as the International Codes (I-codes), as
published by the International Code Council, the Uniform Codes, as published by
the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials. The
following codes are hereby adopted as a revision to this chapter:
   (A)   The Administrative Code as adopted by Elko County, includes the
administration chapter in the following codes: International Building Code
(IBC), International Residential Code (IRC), National Electrical Code (NEC),
Uniform Mechanical Code (UMC), Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC), Uniform Swimming
Pool, Spa, and Hot Tub Code, Uniform Solar, Hydronics and Geothermal Code, and
the International Existing Building Code (IEBC); excluding fee schedules as
adopted by resolution, and hereinafter referred to as the administrative code.
   (B)   The 2018 edition of the International Building Code (IBC) and building
code standards with changes, modifications, and supplements, including the
appendix chapters, hereinafter referred to as the building code.
   Appendix chapters included:
   C - Group U Agricultural Buildings.
   E - Supplementary Accessibility Requirements.
   G - Flood Resistant Construction (excluding section G601).
   H - Signs, except the following:
      1.   Ground signs under section H109.1 constructed entirely of
noncombustible material shall not be erected to a height greater than 50 feet
(15 240 mm) above the ground, unless a variance is approved by the Elko County
Planning Commission.
      2.   Roof signs under section H110.4 which the uniform open area is not
less than 40 percent of total gross area shall not exceed a height of 40 feet
(12 192 mm) on buildings of Type 1 or Type 2 construction. On buildings of
other construction types, the height shall not exceed 25 feet (7 620 mm).
      3.   Roof signs under section H110.5 A close roof sign shall not be
erected to a height greater than 40 feet (12 192 mm) above the roof of the
buildings of Type 1 or 2 construction or more than 25 feet (7 620 mm) above the
roof of buildings or Type 3, 4 or 5 construction.
   I - Patio Covers.
   J - Grading.
   K - Administrative Provisions.
   (C)   The 2018 edition of the International Residential Code (IRC)
[excluding the plumbing and mechanical sections; refer to the 2018 UPC and UMC
for general requirements] and building code standards with changes,
modifications and supplements, including appendix chapters, hereinafter
referred to as the residential code.
   Appendix chapters:
   H - Patio Covers.
   J - Existing Building and Structures.
   K - Sound Transmission.
   Q - Tiny House.
   (D)   The 2017 National Electrical Code (NEC), standard for electrical
wiring and apparatus as recommended by the National Fire Protection
Association, hereinafter referred to as the electrical code.
   (E)   The 2018 Uniform Mechanical Code (UMC), as recommended by the
International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, hereinafter
referred to as the mechanical code,
   (F)   The 2018 Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC), as recommended by the
International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials, hereinafter
referred to as the plumbing code.
   (G)   The 2018 Uniform Swimming Pool, Spa, and Hot Tub Code, as recommended
by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials,
hereinafter referred to as the Uniform Swimming Pool, Spa, and Hot Tub Code.
   (H)   The 2018 edition of the International Existing Building Code (IEBC)
and standards with changes, modifications and supplements as recommended by the
International Code Council, hereinafter referred to as the existing building
code.
   (I)   The 2018 Uniform Solar, Hydronics and Geothermal Code, as recommended
by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials,
hereinafter referred to as the Uniform Solar, Hydronics and Geothermal Code.
   (J)   The 2018 edition of the International Energy Conservation Code (IECC)
in accordance with the state of Nevada energy conservation standards for new
building construction, promulgated by the state of Nevada public works board,
shall be adopted for reference unless used in the design of a structure by a
design professional, contractor, or owner-builder.
   (K)   The 2018 editions of the International Mechanical (IMC) and Plumbing
(IPC) Codes shall be adopted for cross reference only. (Ord. 05-2005, 9-7-2005,
eff. 10-7-2005; amd. Ord. 03-2020, 7-17-2021; Ord. 2021-06, 1-19-2022)
3-1-2: FUTURE EDITIONS ADOPTED:
Revisions of the hereinbefore mentioned codes are hereby expressly adopted as
they appear in the future except as to amendments and modifications contained
in this chapter. Within one hundred twenty (120) days after the receipt by the
county building official of a code edition intended by the promulgators (ICC)
thereof to replace one of the before mentioned codes, unless said replacement
edition is specifically disapproved by the county commission pursuant to this
section, the county building official shall:
   (A)   Post a notice at his office and in the Elko County courthouse that the
replacement code is the code governing all matters to which it pertains with
regard to any building for which a building permit is thereafter issued until
that code itself is replaced pursuant to this chapter.
   (B)   The building official shall provide each person or entity to which a
building permit is thereafter issued with such notice.
With regard to any code intended by its promulgators to replace one of the
before mentioned codes, such code shall govern with regard to the subject
matter thereof all building pursuant to building permits issued after such
notice and posting until that code itself is replaced pursuant to this chapter.
All previous adoptions of editions of the hereinbefore mentioned codes are
hereby specifically repealed. (Ord. 05-2005, 9-7-2005, eff. 10-7-2005)
3-1-3: DEFINITIONS:
All references in any of the foregoing codes to "city" or "municipality" shall
be deemed to refer to Elko County. (Ord. 05-2005, 9-7-2005, eff. 10-7-2005)
3-1-4: AMENDMENTS AND MODIFICATIONS TO BUILDING CODES:
   (A)   Adoption of the 2018 Northern Nevada Amendments as modified are
applicable to Elko County.
      1.   The following structures are excluded from the applicability of any
permit requirements:
         (a)   Agricultural structures not used for human habitation containing
less than four hundred (400) square feet, when used for agricultural use as
defined by NRS 361A.030.
         (b)   All one-story detached accessory structures used as tool and
storage sheds, animal shelters, play houses and similar uses, and not used for
human habitation containing less than two hundred (200) square feet and not
exceeding a 10 foot eave wall height. (IBC & IRC section 105.2.1.)
         (c)   Non-structural cosmetic remodeling valued at less than five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00), including material and labor, which does not
change the existing floor plan or the use or occupancy of the structure.
         (d)   Sidewalks, driveways and uncovered decks (when deck is not used
as the primary exit from a residence) not more than 30 inches above adjacent
grade and not over any basement or story below. (IRC section 105.2.5)
         (e)   Private stairways 30 inches (762mm) or less in height may have a
handrail on one side only.
         (f)   Agricultural Hoop House/High Tunnel: A "Hoop House" or "High
Tunnel" is defined as an enclosure that is used exclusively for the production
or storage of live plants and is designed to cover and protect crops from the
sun, wind, excessive rainfall, or cold, to extend the growing season in an
environmentally safe manner. The covering for these enclosures utilize
transparent/semi-transparent, flexible, non-rigid materials having a life span
of approximately 5 years.
Agricultural Hoop Houses or High Tunnels are used exclusively for the
production or storage of live plants. Note: the installation of Electrical,
Mechanical, and Sanitary Plumbing are not exempt from permits. The installation
of hoop houses/high tunnels may be subject to Elko County zoning codes.
      2.   Section 309.1 (1997 UBC): Use Or Occupancy.
         (a)   No building or structure of groups A, B, E, F, H, I, M, R, S or
U, all divisions of those occupancies, shall be used or occupied, and no change
in the existing occupancy classification of a building or structure, or portion
thereof, shall be made until the building official has issued a certificate of
occupancy therefor, as provided herein.
         (b)   The designation of R-3 shall be for a one (1) and two (2) family
dwelling unit and U-1 for residential garages (attached and detached) as listed
in the 2003 IBC.
      3.   Section 304: Permit Fees.
Permit fees shall be set by resolution by the Elko County board of
commissioners. A copy of the most current resolution is located at the office
of the Elko County community development. Fees and/or valuations shall be
adjusted every other year based on the U.S. department of labor, bureau of
labor statistics, western urban consumer price index as published in the month
of January.
Section 304 of the 1997 uniform administrative code as adopted in section
3-1-1 of the Elko County code is hereby amended by adding the following
paragraph: Any property requiring a permit located in zones 1, 2, and 3 as
described in the approved travel zone map posted in the Elko County community
department shall be assessed a travel fee. The base fee for zone 1 shall be
twenty dollars ($20), for zone 2 shall be forty dollars ($40) and for zone 3
shall be sixty dollars ($60). Zone fees shall be adjusted every other year
based on the U.S. department of labor, bureau of labor statistics, western
urban consumer price index as published in the month of January.
      4.   Section 304.3: Plan Review Fee.
Section 304.3 of the 1997 uniform administrative code as adopted in section
3-1-1 of the Elko County code is amended to provide that the plan review fee
for a review of a plan of a residential dwelling required to be submitted by
section 106.3.2 of the international building code, shall be thirty five
percent (35%) of the cost of the building permit fee as shown on table no. 3-A.
      5.   Section R309.2: Separation Required.
The garage shall be separated from the residence and its attic area by not less
than 5/8" type "X" gypsum applied to the garage side. Where the separation is a
floor-ceiling assembly, the structure supporting the separation shall also be
protected by not less than 5/8" type "X" gypsum or equivalent.
   (B)   All editions of the Uniform Mechanical Code, present and future, are
hereby amended and modified as follows:
      1.   Table 3-C - Mechanical Permit Fees, the following is added:
System fee schedule (note: the following do not include permit issuing fee)
shall be set by resolution adopted by the Elko County commission.
   (C)   All editions of the Uniform Plumbing Code, present and future, are
hereby amended and modified as follows:
      1.   Table 3-D - Plumbing Permit Fees, the following is added:
System fee schedule (note: the following do not include permit issuing fee)
shall be set by resolution adopted by the Elko County commission.
   (D)   Service Equipment - Electrical Disconnecting Means:
The 2002 national electrical code (NEC), article 230 - VI, section 230.70 (A)
(1) shall be amended as followed for the protection of emergency service
personnel:
An exterior service disconnecting means shall be located within 30 feet of the
structure it serves for all structures with electricity including manufactured
homes.
   (E)   When a governmental entity or utility is providing water and/or sewer
services to a project in the County, no building permit for construction shall
be issued unless evidence of paid water and sewer connection fees for the
particular type of construction being considered, if applicable, is produced at
the time of the permit application.
   (F)   All persons and political subdivisions that are statutorily required
to proceed through the State Public Works Board shall also apply to the
Building and Safety Division of the Community Development Department for a
permit. The issuance of a building permit pursuant to this subsection shall be
without charge or fee, and shall not be subject to the County plan check or
building inspection procedure. The County shall not be liable or responsible
for any deficiencies, errors, or omissions in the plans or the building
inspection procedure, for plans approved by the State Public Works Board. (Ord.
05-2005, 9-7-2005, eff. 10-7-2005; amd. Ord. 2016-02, 4-6-2016, eff. 2-25-2017;
Ord. 2017-03, 4-5-2017, eff. 2-11-2018; Ord. 03-2020, 7-17-2021)
3-1-5: RESTRICTIONS:
   (A)   Building Permit Fees: All editions of the International Building and

   Table 109 - International Building Code and Table 108 - International

plan review fee for a review of a residential dwelling required to be submitted

percent (35%) of the cost of the building permit fee as shown on table no. 3-A.
   (C)   Travel Zones: Shall be set by resolution by the Elko County board of
Commissioners.
   The following fees shall remain in effect until change by resolution: Any
property requiring a permit located in zones 1, 2, and 3 as described in the
approved travel zone map posted in the Elko County community department shall
be assessed a travel fee. The base fee for zone 1 shall be twenty dollars
($20), for zone 2 shall be forty dollars ($40) and for zone 3 shall be sixty
dollars ($60).
   (D)   Electrical Permit Fees: All editions of the National Electric Code,

   Table K112 - Electrical Permit Fees, the following is added:

   (E)   Mechanical Permit Fees: All editions of the Uniform Mechanical Code,

   Table 104.5 - Mechanical Permit Fees, the following is added:
   System fee schedule (note: the following do not include permit issuing fee)
shall be set by resolution adopted by the Elko County commission.
   (F)   Plumbing Permit Fees: All editions of the Uniform Plumbing Code,
present and future, are hereby amended and modified as follows:
   Table 104.5 - Plumbing Permit Fees, the following is added:
   System fee schedule (note: the following do not include permit issuing fee)
shall be set by resolution adopted by the Elko County commission.
   (G)   Swimming Pool, Spa and Hot Tub Permit Fees: All editions of the
Uniform Plumbing Code, present and future, are hereby amended and modified as
follows:
   Table 104.5 - Swimming Pool, Spa and Hot Tub Permit Fees, the following is
added:
   System fee schedule (note: the following do not include permit issuing fee)
shall be set by resolution adopted by the Elko County commission.
   (H)   Solar, Hydronics and Geothermal Code Fees: All editions of the Uniform
Plumbing Code, present and future, are hereby amended and modified as follows:
   Table 104.5 - Solar, Hydronics and Geothermal Code Fees, the following is
added:
   System fee schedule (note: the following do not include permit issuing fee)
shall be set by resolution adopted by the Elko County commission.
   (I)   When a governmental entity or utility is providing water and/or sewer
services to a project in the County, no building permit for construction shall
be issued unless evidence of paid water and sewer connection fees for the
particular type of construction being considered, if applicable, is produced at
the time of the permit application.
   (J)   All persons and political subdivisions that are statutorily required
to proceed through the State Public Works Board shall also apply to the
Building and Safety Division of the Community Development Department for a
permit. The issuance of a building permit pursuant to this subsection shall be
without charge or fee, and shall not be subject to the County plan check or
building inspection procedure. The County shall not be liable or responsible
for any deficiencies, errors, or omissions in the plans or the building
inspection procedure, for plans approved by the State Public Works Board. (Ord.
05-2005, 9-7-2005, eff. 10-7-2005; amd. Ord. 03-2020, 7-17-2021)
3-1-6: HAZARDOUS WASTES, STORAGE OR DISPOSAL PERMITS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   No building permit shall issue for the construction, alteration,
improvement, repair, moving or installation of a structure for hazardous waste
disposal, incineration or treatment or for use in the storage or management of
hazardous wastes for treatment, disposal or incineration for which use a permit
to operate such a facility is required from the State of Nevada or the United
States.
      1.   Hazardous waste is defined as it is defined at Nevada Revised
Statutes 459.430 and includes any hazardous waste or constituents of hazardous
waste which are subject to regulation under 40 CFR 251, as in effect on July 1,
1984.
   (B)   This section shall remain in full force and effect until the earlier
of the State issuing regulations for operation of hazardous waste disposal and
treatment and ending the moratorium on the issuance of State permits to operate
facilities for the disposal, treatment and incineration of such hazardous
wastes, or repeal of this section. (Ord. 05-2005, 9-7-2005, eff. 10-7-2005)
3-1-7: PENALTIES
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the International,
National, and Uniform codes hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who
shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall
build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans
submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued
thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken or who shall fail to comply
with such an order as affirmed or modified by the county fire commission or by
a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall
severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be
guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, or by
both such fine and imprisonment. The imposition of one penalty for any
