9-7B-25: Appendix A - Sewer Fee Schedule
9-7B-1: SEWER REVENUE SYSTEM:
The Town of Montello sewer revenue system shall be responsible for the fiscal
operations of the Montello wastewater treatment facilities. The sewer revenue
system shall consist of two (2) discrete programs; the capitalization system
and the user charge system, with separate accounts being maintained for each.
9-7B-2: THE CAPITALIZATION SYSTEM:
The capitalization system shall provide funding for capital expenditures, debt
service, including the redemption of principle and payment of interest on debt
issues, and all other nonoperating, maintenance, and replacement costs as the
Board may consider appropriate, including redemption of the principle and
payment of the interest on sewer bonds. Components for the capitalization
system shall include:
   (A)   Capitalization Charges: Assessed customers to recover non-OM&R costs
(for which the use of the user charge system is not appropriate) including late
payment fees and other penalties; the sewer connection fees; and the monthly
capitalization charge portion of the sewer fee. The rate of the capitalization
charge shall be established by the Board and customers shall be notified
annually of the charge as a portion of their annual/monthly sewer fee schedule.
   (B)   Sewer Connection Charges: Funds generated through fees charged to new
users of the system for the privilege of connection to and use of the system as
defined in Section
9-7B-3 below.
   (C)   Fees, Penalties, and Special Charges: Special fees collected by the
Town and not related to regular OM&R expenses shall accrue to the
Capitalization Fund.
   (D)   Capitalization Fund: Shall be created in the Treasury of Elko County
in the name of the Town of Montello a special Fund to be known as the Montello
Sewer Capitalization Fund to which capitalization revenues shall accrue and
from which funds shall be disbursed for the aforementioned purposes.
9-7B-3: SEWER CONNECTION CHARGES:
   (A)   For each initial or new connection made to the sewer system, there
shall be an initial charge in the form of a connection fee in accordance with
the following schedules:
      1.   Each separate residential unit, or other individual housing unit
within a multi-family dwelling, apartment house or trailer court, shall be
considered one equivalent dwelling unit. (See sewer fee schedule, Appendix A.)
The connection charge shall apply to all parcels and lots which have not
previously been served by the Montello sewer system, and each lot of any new
subdivision to be served by the sewer system.
      2.   For all initial or new commercial and industrial sewer connections,
the connection charge shall be charged per SFU. The number SFUs is determined
by using the schedule for commercial and industrial buildings as set forth in
Section
9-7B-23 of this Chapter. The minimum SFU count for commercial and industrial
buildings shall be twenty five (25).
      3.   Modification and Expansion of Facilities: If a commercial or
industrial service is expanded, and the expansion results in a sewer fixture
unit (SFU) count above twenty five (25), the connection charge shall be the
current rate times the net increase in SFUs above the twenty five (25) minimum.
In converting a residential building to commercial use or developing a
commercial use on a lot with previous sewer service, the applicant shall pay
the connection charge based upon the net increase in fixture units. In the
event there is no record of the fixture units in the original structure, the
applicant will be credited with twenty five (25) fixture units. In no case will
a refund be granted for a reduction in fixture units. (See Appendix "A".)
      4.   Determination of Sewer Fixture Unit Count: The Department will
conduct a fixture unit survey at the time a building permit is requested. This
will be done through an assessment of the construction plans provided by the
applicant. The final count will be based upon the final inspection of the
completed structure.
   (B)   Payment: The sewer connection charge shall be payable on demand to the
Town at the time the Building Inspector issues a building permit. Funds
received through connection charges shall accrue to the Capitalization Fund.
Any additional charges incurred due to increased fixture unit count upon
completion of the facility shall be paid prior to issuance of a certificate of
occupancy.
   (C)   Until further resolution of the Board, the rate for sewer use and
connection to the sewer system for residences shall be calculated at one
equivalent dwelling unit (EDU) per dwelling unit. One EDU is the equivalent of
twenty five (25) sewer fixture units.
   (D)   Home occupations shall be charged for one-half (1/2) of an equivalent
dwelling unit (1/2 EDU, 13 fixture units) at the commercial rate, in addition
to the residential rate. Additional sewer fixture units shall be assessed for
sewer fixtures which are occupation specific, see Section
9-7B-23, the Sewer Fixture Value Table.
   (E)   All sewer users not specifically identified in subsections (C) or (D)
above shall be classified as commercial or industrial users and SFUs shall be
determined on the basis of the "Sewer Fixture Value Table" contained in Section
9-7B-23. The minimum SFU count for the purposes of calculating the monthly
capitalization charge for commercial/industrial users shall be twenty five (25)
SFUs equal to one equivalent dwelling unit (1 EDU).
9-7B-4: THE USER CHARGE SYSTEM:
The user charge system shall be used to determine the user charge rate. The
user charge rate shall be based on actual use of the Town of Montello
wastewater treatment facilities. Each user shall pay his proportionate share of
operation, maintenance and replacement costs based upon his estimated
contribution (expressed as an equivalent dwelling unit) to the total flow
volume and loading of the plant, thereby assuring the fiscal self-sufficiency
of the facility over its useful (design) life. The user charge system shall
include the financial management system, user charge rates, and user charge or
OM&R Fund.
9-7B-5: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:
The financial management system shall prescribe accounting budgetary procedures
to accurately depict revenue requirements and procedures to generate revenue
sufficient to operate and maintain the wastewater collection and treatment
system.
9-7B-6: SEPARATE ACCOUNTS:
Separate accounts shall be maintained for the user charge system and the
capitalization system.
9-7B-7: OPERATION, MAINTENANCE, AND REPLACEMENT (OM&R) COSTS:
Operation, maintenance and replacement (OM&R) costs of the treatment system
shall be enumerated through a line item budget including the following
categories:
   (A)   Salaries and wages.
   (B)   Indirect salary and wage costs.
   (C)   Contractual services.
   (D)   Materials and supplies.
   (E)   Utilities.
   (F)   Equipment replacement.
   (G)   Administrative expenses.
OM&R costs shall include the costs required to achieve and maintain compliance
with discharge permits.
9-7B-8: REVENUE GAINED THROUGH SALE OF TREATMENT BY-PRODUCTS:
Revenue gained through the sale or use of treatment related by-products shall
be credited to the user charge system.
9-7B-9: USER CHARGE RATE:
The user charge rate shall generate revenue sufficient to meet OM&R costs
thereby assuring the facility's fiscal operational viability, through charges
to customers which are proportionate to their usage (both volume and loading).
The user charge rate shall be recalculated annually based upon actual and
projected OM&R expenses.
9-7B-10: EQUIVALENT DWELLING UNIT (EDU):
The equivalent dwelling unit shall form the basis for the user charge system.
Residential equivalent dwelling units shall be calculated according to the
following scale:
 
Single-family dwelling    1 unit per dwelling unit
Multiple-family dwelling  1 unit per dwelling unit
Apartment or rental units 1 unit per dwelling unit
Trailer court             1 unit per dwelling unit
 
Commercial and industrial equivalent dwelling units shall be calculated
according to the fixture unit value table in Section
9-7B-23. Each commercial or industrial facility shall pay at a minimum for one
EDU, which shall include up to twenty five (25) fixture units as listed in
Section
9-7B-23. Any additional fixture units shall be charged at the rate of four one-
hundredths (0.04) EDU per fixture unit (25 fixture units per EDU), and the
facility may have partial EDUs. The user charge rate will be calculated based
upon the total number of EDUs.
9-7B-11: EQUIVALENT DWELLING UNIT BENCHMARKS:
   (A)   Loading Levels:
 
Parameter Domestic Wastewater
         Strength   Loading
BOD5      250 mg/l   0.65 lbs/day
SS        250 mg/l   0.46 lbs/day
Pp        11.0 mg/l  0.03 lbs/day
Nn        26.0 mg/l  0.07 lbs/day
 
   (B)   Volume: An equivalent dwelling unit shall be the equivalent volume of:
350 gallons per day; 10,500 gallons per month, and 126,000 gallons per year.
   (C)   Sewer Fixture Units: 25 sewer fixture units = 1 EDU.
9-7B-12: ANNUAL USER CHARGE RATE (UCR):
The annual user charge rate per equivalent dwelling unit (EDU) shall be based
on the following formula:
 
Annual User Charge Rate (per EDU) = (OM&R)
                                    (Total EDU)
 
9-7B-13: SURCHARGES:
   (A)   High-Strength Discharges: A surcharge shall be levied upon customers
whose discharge loadings exceed those listed in Section
9-7B-11. The surcharge shall be based on treatment costs of additional loading
above standard loading levels, expressed as additional EDUs or fractions
thereof.
   (B)   Discharge Permit Fees/Toxic Pollutants: All commercial and industrial
dischargers must obtain a discharge permit at time of service application. All
dischargers whose anticipated discharge level of toxic pollutants will increase
the cost of treating the wastewater shall pay for such increased costs.
9-7B-14: RESIDENTIAL USER CHARGE RATE:
A uniform rate shall be assessed based upon the average discharge volume and
strength of the predominant user class (residential) and as further specified
above (Section
9-7B-11). This fee shall be recalculated annually based upon the adopted budget
for OM&R expenses.
9-7B-15: COMMERCIAL/INDUSTRIAL (C/I) USER CHARGE RATE:
All sewer users not specifically identified above shall be classified as
commercial/industrial users and their user charge rate shall be based upon the
total number of equivalent dwelling units (EDUs) for the facility, with the
addition of appropriate surcharges for wastewater characteristics which exceed
the benchmarks identified in Section
9-7B-11.
   (A)   The minimum commercial/industrial (C/I) user charge rate (UCR) shall
be one EDU (25 SFU), with the addition of four one-hundredths (0.04) of an EDU
for each additional SFU.
   (B)   Combination of Charges: Where sewer service is provided for a
combination of businesses or a combination of a business and a residence, there
shall be a cumulative sewer charge for all types of businesses and residences
so served at said location.
   (C)   Commercial and Industrial User Rate: The commercial and industrial
user rate shall be the current rate. This charge shall be recalculated annually
based upon the annual budget for OM&R expenses.
9-7B-16: ANNUAL NOTIFICATION:
Annual notification shall be given to each customer with the annual sewer fee
schedule of the anticipated OM&R costs, number of EDUs and the user charge rate
(and capitalization charge) per EDU.
9-7B-17: INFILTRATION/INFLOW:
Infiltration/inflow costs shall be included with operation, maintenance and
replacement (OM&R) expenses and shall be distributed among customers
proportionate to their usage of the treatment facilities.
9-7B-18: BIENNIAL REVIEW OF OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE CHARGES:
The Board shall review not less often than every two (2) years the contribution
of users and user classes, the total cost of operation and maintenance of
treatment works and its approved user charge system. The Board shall revise the
charges for users or user classes to accomplish the following:
   (A)   Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance
costs among users and user classes as required herein.
   (B)   Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and maintenance
costs necessary for the proper operation and maintenance (including necessary
equipment replacement) of the treatment works.
   (C)   Apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the costs of
operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year and
adjust the rate accordingly.
9-7B-19: TERMINATION OF SERVICE PROCEDURE FOR NONPAYMENT:
   (A)   Each billing for sewer service shall indicate the date due for payment
of that billing. If payment is not received within fifteen (15) days of the
date due, the payment shall become past due. In the event that payment becomes
past due, the Director shall mail a notice to the legal owner or the applicant
for service and the occupant at the address receiving service that the sewer
and water service will be terminated on a specific date, which date shall be
ten (10) days after the date of mailing of such delinquent notice.
   (B)   The owner or applicant applying for service or occupant of the
premises may request to present his position concerning termination of sewer
services to the Board and the Board's action shall be final.
   (C)   Failure of the owner, customer or occupant to appear before the Board
after having requested such right, as provided above, will cause the sewer and
water service to be terminated on the next working day.
   (D)   On the date of termination of sewer and water services, or any date
thereafter, the Director may cause to be filed with the Elko County Recorder a
statement of the amount due and unpaid for sewer services and a description of
the property to which the services were rendered to perfect a lien against the
property.
   (E)   Upon vacating the premises, all customers desiring to discontinue
sewer service shall notify the Department two (2) days prior to vacating the
premises. Unless discontinuance of service is ordered, the customer shall be
liable for charges whether or not the sewer is used.
9-7B-20: APPEALS:
The Board shall review any decision made by the Director or his representatives
or agents in interpreting, applying or enforcing the provisions of this
Chapter, upon the receipt of an application or petition in writing, requesting
a review of such decision. In exercising its powers on review the Board may, in
conformity with the provisions of the law, reverse or affirm wholly or partly,
or may modify the order, requirements, decision or determination of the
Director. The Board may also initiate a review of the Director's interpretation
of the provisions of this Chapter by a motion and by a vote of a majority of
the quorum or a majority of the members present, if such number exceeds a
quorum. In all cases, the decision of the Board shall be final.
9-7B-21: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this Chapter
shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor and be punished by
imprisonment in the Elko County jail for a term not to exceed six (6) months,
or by a fine of not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by both such
fine and imprisonment. Each day's violation of the provisions of this Chapter
may be deemed a separate offense.
9-7B-22: CREDIT AND PAYMENT:
   (A)   Establishment and Maintenance: Each applicant for service shall
establish and maintain credit to the satisfaction of the Department before
service will be rendered.
   (B)   Loss and Re-Establishment of Credit: Any amount due for sewer service
that remains unpaid for twenty (20) days after presentation of a bill during
the depositor's first year of service, may be deducted from the guarantee
deposit and service shall be subject to discontinuance until the deposit is
again restored to the original amount. Any such unpaid amount accruing
subsequently to the depositor's first year of service, where the premises are
owned by the depositor, may also be deducted from any guarantee deposit
remaining in the Department's possession.
   (C)   Bills and Collections:
      1.   All bills for sewer services or for having sewer services available
shall be rendered monthly on the last day of the month in which the services
were used or available. In the event any such bill is not paid in full within
fifteen (15) days after the date when rendered, sewer service as well as water
service may be immediately discontinued and shall be shut off, as provided by
the laws of the State and the ordinances of the County.
      2.   In the event any service is so discontinued, a penal charge of ten
dollars ($10.00) together with all costs and expenses incurred by the Town,
including, but not limited to, the prorated portion of the employee or
employees' salaries required to effect the discontinuance and reconnection, a
reasonable sum for use of machinery and equipment required, and the expense of
any valves, faucets, or other plumbing fixtures required. Service shall not be
resumed until all legal charges for water service, sewer service, or facilities
up to the time of the disconnection, and all penalty charges, or the costs and
expenses incurred in causing the discontinuance and the resumption of the water
and sewer services, have been paid in full to the Town.

9-7B-24: PRECEDENCE:
This user charge system shall take precedence over the terms or conditions of
any agreements or contracts which the Town is party to which are inconsistent
with the requirements of the Water Quality Act (as amended 1986) and the
regulation of the United States EPA (40 CFR parts 35.2005 - 35.2208). (Ord.
1990-Q, 6-20-90, eff. 7-3-90)

CHAPTER 8
CABLE TELEVISION
SECTION:
9-8-1: Title
9-8-2: Definitions
9-8-3: Compliance with Applicable Laws and Ordinances
9-8-4: Franchise; Provisions, Conditions
9-8-5: Franchise Termination
9-8-6: Construction and Facilities
9-8-7: Service and Operation
9-8-1: TITLE:
This Chapter may be cited as the "Unincorporated Town of West Wendover, Nevada,
Cable Television System Chapter".
9-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the following
terms and their derivatives shall have the meaning herein given (and when not
inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the
future, words in the plural number include the singular, and words in the
singular number include the plural):
BASIC CATV SERVICE: The distribution of broadcast television signals by the
grantee.
BASIC SUBSCRIBER REVENUES: All remuneration received directly by the grantee
from subscribers in payment for regularly furnished basic CATV service, but
shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the grantee imposed on any
subscriber or user by any government, governmental unit, political subdivision,
agency or instrumentality, and collected by the grantee.
BOARD: The governing body of the Unincorporated Town of West Wendover, Nevada,
which is the Board of County Commissioners of the County of Elko, Nevada.
CATV A cable television system.
CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEM: A system composed of, without limitation, antenna,
cables, wires, lines, towers, wave guides, or any other conductors, converters,
equipment or facilities, designed, constructed or wired for the purpose of
producing, receiving, amplifying and distribution by coaxial cable radio,
television or other electronic or electrical signals to and from persons,
subscribers and locations in the franchise area.
COUNTY: The County of Elko, Nevada.
FRANCHISE AREA: That area within the Unincorporated Town of West Wendover,
Nevada, as now or hereafter constituted.
GRANTEE: MISCO, Inc., its successors and assigns, the grantee of rights under
this Chapter.
PERSON: Any natural person, company or entity of any kind.
PROPERTY OF GRANTEE: All property owned, installed or used by the grantee in
the conduct of a CATV business in the Town.
STREET: The surface of and the space above and below any public street, way,
place, right of way, road, highway, freeway, bridge, tunnel, lane, path, bike
path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, drive, communications or utility
easement, by whatever name called, now or hereafter existing as such within the
franchise area.
SUBSCRIBER: Any person or entity receiving and paying for basic CATV service.
TOWN: The Unincorporated Town of West Wendover, Nevada.
9-8-3: COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND ORDINANCES:
The grantee shall, at all times during the life of this franchise, be subject
to all lawful exercise of the police power by the Town or County. The Board
reserves the right to adopt, from time to time in addition to the provisions
herein contained, such ordinances as may be necessary to the exercise of police
power. Such regulation shall be reasonable and not in derogation of the rights
herein granted, nor in conflict with the laws of the State or other local or
Federal laws or regulations.
9-8-4: FRANCHISE; PROVISIONS, CONDITIONS:
   (A)   Grant of Authority: The grantee shall file a written acceptance of the
franchise with the Board within twenty (20) days after the date of adoption of
this Chapter. The franchise shall go into effect only when such acceptance has
been filed, and when the performance bond and evidence of general comprehensive
liability insurance provided for hereinafter have been filed and approved. Upon
grantee complying with such provisions, there shall be granted by the County to
the grantee the right and privilege to engage in the business of operating and
providing a CATV system in the Town, and for that purpose to erect, install,
construct, repair, replace, reconstruct, maintain and retain in, on, over,
under, upon, across and along any street or streets laid out or dedicated and
all extensions thereof and additions thereto in the franchise area, such poles,
wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduit, vaults, manholes, pedestals,
amplifiers, appliances, attachments and other property as may be necessary and
apparent to the CATV system; and in addition, so to use, operate and provide
similar facilities or properties rented or leased from other persons,
including, but not limited to, any public utility or other grantee franchised
or permitted to do business in the Town.
   (B)   Nonexclusive Grant: The right to use and occupy said streets for the
purposes herein set forth shall not be exclusive to the grantee.
   (C)   Term of Franchise: The franchise and rights herein granted shall
commence twenty (20) days from the final passage hereof, contingent upon
grantee's compliance with subsection (A) herein, and shall continue in force
and effect for ten (10) years after said effective date. Upon application by
the grantee to the County, the franchise may be renewed for a subsequent ten
(10) year term.
   (D)   Franchise Payments: The grantee shall pay the County on or before each
March 31, a franchise fee of three percent (3%) of basic subscriber revenues
received for cable television operations in the Town for the preceding calendar
year, and no other fee, charge or consideration. Sales tax or other taxes
levied on a per subscription basis and collected by the grantee shall be
deducted from the gross annual basic subscriber revenues in computing any sums
due the Town. The grantee shall provide an annual summary report showing gross
annual basic subscriber revenues received during the preceding year.
   (E)   Indemnification of County and Town:
      1.   The grantee shall, at all times, protect and hold the Town and
County harmless from all claims, actions, suits, liability, loss, expense or
damages of every kind and description, including investigation costs, court
costs and reasonable attorney fees which may accrue to or be suffered or
claimed by any person or persons arising out of the negligence of the grantee
in the ownership, construction, repair, replacement, maintenance and operation
of said cable television system, and by reason of any license copyright, cable
television system, and by reason of any license, copyright, property right or
patent of any article or system used in the construction or use of said system;
provided the Town and/or County gives the grantee prompt notice of any such
claims, actions and suits, without limitation, in writing. The grantee shall
maintain in full force and effect during the life of any franchise, public
liability and property damage insurance for an amount of at least three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) single limit liability from the time of
commencement of construction of the CATV system. The Unincorporated Town of
West Wendover, Nevada and the County of Elko, Nevada, shall be named as
insured. A copy of the policies and proof of premium payments shall be filed as
issued with the County Manager.
      2.   The Board may require that any and all investigation of claims made
by any person against the Board arising out of any use or misuse of privileges
granted to the grantee hereunder shall be made by, or at the expense of, the
grantee or its insurer. The grantee may bring its obligations to carry any
insurance required hereby within the coverage of any so-called blanket policy
or policies of insurance now or hereafter carried by appropriate amendment,
endorsement or otherwise; provided, however, the interests of the Town and
County shall be as fully protected thereby as if the grantee had obtained
individual policies of insurance.
   (F)   Performance Bond:
      1.   Grantee shall, within twenty (20) days after the date of adoption of
this Chapter, file with the County Manager, and at all times thereafter
maintain in full force and effect for the entire term of the franchise, at its
expense, a faithful performance bond executed by a surety company approved by
the Board and in form satisfactory to the Board, in the amount of twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00), renewable annually, and conditioned on the
faithful performance by grantee of all the terms, conditions and covenants
contained in the franchise. if grantee fails to comply with any one or more of
the provisions of the franchise, there shall be recoverable jointly and
severally from the principal and surety of such bond any damages or losses
suffered by grantor as a result thereof. Such bond shall provide that thirty
(30) days' prior written notice of cancellation, material change, or intention
not to renew such bond be given to grantor.
      2.   Neither the provisions of any bond accepted by grantor pursuant
hereto, nor any damages recovered by grantor thereunder, shall be construed to
excuse faithful performance by grantee or limit the liability of grantee under
the franchise or for damages, either to the full amount of the bond or
otherwise, or preclude exercise of any other right or remedy given to grantor
by law, whether exercised concurrently or subsequently.
   (G)   Miscellaneous Provisions:
      1.   When not otherwise prescribed herein, all matters herein required to
be filed with the Town, Board or County shall be filed with the County Clerk.
      2.   The grantee shall assume the cost of publication of this franchise
Chapter when such publication is required by law. A bill for publication costs
shall be presented to the grantee by the County Manager.
      3.   The grantee shall provide without charge, one outlet of basic CATV
service to one governmental office building, fire station, police station and a
public school building that is passed by its cable. The distribution of the
cable facility inside such buildings and the extent thereof shall be at the
option, duty and expense of the building owner.
      4.   In the case of any emergency or disaster, the grantee shall, upon
request of the Town, make available its facilities to the Town for emergency
use during the emergency or disaster period.
9-8-5: FRANCHISE TERMINATION:
   (A)   Procedures to Terminate:
      1.   The Board may terminate this franchise if after the hearing
hereinafter provided for, the Board finds that any representation or warrant of
the grantee set out in this Chapter is false or has been breached, or that the
grantee has defaulted in the performance of any of the provisions of this
Chapter on its part to be performed and such default has not been cured within
thirty (30) days after a written copy of the Board's decision has been served
on the grantee by mail or personal service on any officer or employee of the
grantee.
      2.   Any hearing, proceeding, or other action to be taken or proposed to
be taken by the County in regard to the operations of the grantee's cable
television system, or to terminate this franchise shall be taken only after:
         a.   A copy of such action or proposed action is served directly on
the grantee by mail or service on any officer or employee of the grantee; and
         b.   The grantee has been given an opportunity to respond in writing;
         c.   Any hearing which may be specified by the Board shall be only
after ten (10) days' public notice of such hearing, proceeding, action or
proposed action is published in a local daily or weekly newspaper having
general circulation in the Town.
      3.   The public notice required by this Section shall state clearly:
         a.   The action or proposed action to be taken; and
         b.   The time provided for response and the person or persons in
authority to whom such responses should be addressed; and
         c.   Such other procedures as may be specified by the Board.
      4.   If a hearing is to be held, the public notice shall:
         a.   Give the date and time of such hearing; and
         b.   Whether public participation will be allowed; and
         c.   The procedures by which such participation may be obtained.
      5.   The grantee shall be a necessary party to any hearing conducted in
regard to its operation.
   (B)   Procedure Upon Termination: Upon expiration of the franchise, or upon
termination as otherwise provided herein, if the grantee shall not have
acquired an extension renewal thereof and accepted the same, it may have, and
it is hereby granted, the right to enter upon the streets or other property of
the Town, for the purpose of removing therefrom any or all of its property or
otherwise. In so removing said property, the grantee shall refill, at its
expense, any excavation that it shall make, and shall leave said streets in as
good condition as that prevailing prior to the grantee's removal of its
property.
   (C)   Assignment: The grantee shall not sell or transfer its plant or system
to another, other than a person controlling, controlled by, or under common
control with the grantee, nor transfer any rights under this franchise to
another without the Board's written approval. No sale or. transfer of the
grantee's assets used in the performance of this franchise shall be effective
until the vendee, assignee or lessee has filed in the office of the County
Clerk, an instrument duly executed, reciting the fact of such sale, assignment
or lease, accepting the terms of the franchise, and agreeing to perform all the
conditions thereof. Such Board approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, and
neither this Section, nor any other sections of this franchise shall preclude
the mortgaging, hypothecating or assigning the rights in the system, or the
pledge of stock by the grantee for the purpose of financing.
9-8-6: CONSTRUCTION AND FACILITIES:
   (A)   Conditions of Street Occupancy:
      1.   All transmission and distribution structures, poles, lines and
equipment installed or erected by the grantee within the franchise area shall
be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets
and with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin
any of said streets. The CATV system shall be constructed and operated in
compliance with applicable governmental construction and electrical codes.
      2.   In case of disturbance of any street or paved area, the grantee
shall, in its expansion and in a manner approved by the Board, replace and
restore such street or paved area in as good condition as theretofore.
      3.   The grantee shall, at its expense, protect, support, temporarily
disconnect, relocate in the same street or other public place, or remove from
the street or other public place, any property of the grantee when lawfully
required by the Board by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street
vacation, freeway and street construction, change or establishment of street
grade, installation of sewers, drains, gas or water pipes, or any other type of
structures or improvements by the Board; but, the grantee shall, in all cases
have the right of abandonment of its property, subject to County ordinances,
and, if public funds are available to any utility company for the purpose of
defraying the cost of any of the foregoing, such funds shall also be made
available to the grantee.
      4.   The grantee shall, on the request of any person holding a building
moving permit issued by the County, temporarily raise or lower its wires to
permit the moving of buildings; provided:
         a.   The expense of such temporary raising or lowering of wires is
paid by said person, including, if required by the grantee, making such payment
in advance; and
         b.   The grantee is given not less than seven (7) business days'
advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes.
      5.   The grantee shall have the authority to trim trees overhanging any
streets in the franchise area so as to prevent branches from coming in contact
with the grantee's wires and cables, except that at the option of the Board,
such trimming may be done by it or under its supervision and direction at the
grantee's expense.
      6.   Subject to any applicable State or Federal regulations or tariffs,
the Town shall have the right to make additional use, for any public purpose,
of any poles or conduits controlled or maintained exclusively by or for the
grantee in any street; provided:
         a.   Such use by the Town does not interfere with the use by the
grantee; and
         b.   The Town holds the grantee harmless against and from all claims,
demands, causes of actions, suits, actions, proceedings, damages, costs or
liabilities of every kind and nature whatsoever arising out of such use of said
poles or conduits.
   (B)   Safety Requirements:
      1.   The grantee shall, at all times, employ ordinary care and shall
install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for
preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries or
nuisances to the public.
      2.   All structures and all lines, equipment and connections, in, over,
under and upon all streets of the franchise area shall be kept and maintained
in a safe and suitable condition and in good order and repair.
   (C)   System Construction and Extension:
      1.   The grantee is hereby authorized to extend the system within the
franchise area to the extent that such extension is or may become technically
and economically feasible.
      2.   For all residential structures hereinafter erected which are to be
served by underground utilities, the developer of the subdivision or
development may acquire CATV service for this development under the following
conditions; but, otherwise, the grantee shall not be obligated to construct
CATV system in new development Developer shall perform all trenching and
backfilling necessary for the provision of cable television service, including
furnishing of any imported backfill material required, and will furnish and
install for the grantee any necessary distribution conduit and substructures,
including pedestals, required in accordance with the grantee's plans and
specifications.
      3.   In addition to providing plans and specifications to the developer,
the grantee shall inspect the facilities required hereunder and certify to the
County, or its designated County Agent, prior to the final approval of the
subdivision or development that the facilities required herein are properly
installed. The Town shall have the right to review and require its approval of
the maps and specifications provided by the grantee. The cost of that portion
of an extension to a subdivision or development from the grantee's existing
facilities in excess of forty five (45) meters (one hundred fifty feet [150'])
outside the boundaries of the subdivision or development shall be borne by the
developer. Facilities installed hereunder shall be owned, operated and
maintained by grantee.
   (D)   Line Severing: If at any time the grantee's cable and/or other
equipment is disturbed, damaged or severed, the cost of repair shall be paid by
the party responsible for said damage. The grantee may charge the responsible
party for the time and materials expended for repair of said damage. The Town
will cooperate with the grantee to assist in enforcing any charge or penalty
arising from cable severing, or other damage to grantee's property.
9-8-7: SERVICE AND OPERATION:
   (A)   Operational Standards; Force Majeure:
      1.   The grantee shall operate and maintain its cable television system
in full compliance with the standards set forth by the Federal Communications
Commission.
      2.   The grantee shall have no obligation to construct or extend the
system, nor to provide, repair, replace, maintain or operate CATV service, for
any cause beyond grantee's control, including, without limitation, acts of God,
fire, flood, earthquakes, hurricane, unavoidable casualty, extraordinary delays
in transportation, strikes, lockouts, picketing, boycotts, embargoes government
orders or other requirements, acts of civil or military authorities,
governmental restrictions, regulations or controls, enemy or hostile
governmental action, civil commotion, energy shortages, acts or omissions of
carriers or activities or other emergency conditions, including weather
conditions incompatible with good quality workmanship.
   (B)   Local Office; Complaints: The grantee shall maintain a local business
office or agent which subscribers may telephone during regular business hours
without incurring added message or toll charges, so that complaints regarding
cable television operations may be promptly reported to the grantee.
   (C)   Rates: The grantee shall maintain on file with the County Manager a
schedule setting forth all rates and charges to be made to subscribers for
basic CATV service, including connection and service charges. Notice of changes
in rates and charges shall be filed with the County Manager at least thirty
(30) days in advance of the effective date thereof. (Ord. 1982-H, 6-10-82, eff.
6-29-82)
CHAPTER 9
MOUNTAIN CITY SEWER SYSTEM
SECTION:
9-9-1: Definitions
9-9-2: General Provisions
9-9-2-1: Rules and Regulations
9-9-2-2: Purpose
9-9-2-3: Violation Unlawful

9-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
APPLICANT The person making application for a permit for sewer installation and
shall be the owner of premises to be served by the sewer for which a permit is
requested or his authorized agent.
BOD Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and shall mean the quantity of oxygen
utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees (20°) centigrade,
expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l).
BOARD The Board of Directors of the Mountain City Water and Sewer Users, Inc.,
(MCW&SU). A nonprofit corporation organization to manage and control the
Municipal sewer system of Mountain City, Nevada, under contract with the County
to so operate the system.
BUILDING Any structure used for human habitation.
COMBINED SEWER A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage.
CONTRACTOR An individual, firm, corporation, partnership or association duly
licensed by the State of Nevada to perform the type of work to be done under
the permit and shall be the owner or his agent.
COUNTY The County of Elko, owner of the Mountain City sewer system.
FLOW Q The volume of sewage being discharged into the sewage system.
GARBAGE Solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and
from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
HOUSE SEWER Any sewer or drain beginning at the plumbing or drainage outlets of
any buildings and running to the property line.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES The liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from
sewage and shall mean the waste discharged by industrial users as defined by
EPA rules and regulations, section 35.905, and excludes all domestic wastewater
and uncontaminated water.
INFILTRATION Any water that enters a sewerage system (including sewer service
connections) from the ground through such means as defective pipes, pipe
joints, connections or manhole walls. Infiltration does not include, and is
distinguished from, inflow.
INFLOW Any water other than wastewater that enters a sewerage system (including
sewer service connections) from sources such as roof leaders, cellar drains,
yard drains, area drains, foundation drains, drains from swampy and spring
areas, manhole covers, cross connections between storm sewers and sanitary
sewers, catch basins, cooling towers, storm waters, surface runoff, street wash
waters or drainage. Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from
infiltration.
LATERAL SEWER The portion of the side sewer within a public street.
MOUNTAIN CITY SEWER SYSTEM The system of conduits, pumps, treatment plants and
structures used for the purpose of conveying from their source, treating in any
manner and conveying to final points of disposal all wastes of any nature
permit ted by this Chapter to enter said system. Specifically included as
integral parts of the system are all conduits of any nature forming a part of
the general network; all pumps, treatment plants and structures of any kind
used in connection with the collection, treatment and disposal of the wastes
handled by the system and all appurtenances of any of the above, either
physically or functionally connected therewith. Storm, sanitary and combined
sewers, as defined below, are all included as parts of the sewer system.
MULTIPLE BUILDING DEVELOPMENT The various types of developments that would have
common or joint ownership areas such as condominiums, townhouses, mobile home
parks or courts, shopping centers, etc.
OUTSIDE SEWER A private sewer beyond the limits of the unincorporated town of
Mountain City, Nevada.
OWNER A person owning real estate which is, or proposes to be connected to the
sewage system.
pH The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per
liter of solution with a pH value of seven (7) being neutral.
PERMIT Any written authorization required pursuant to this or any other rule,
regulation or resolution of the Board for the installation of any sewage works.
PERSON Any human being, firm, company, partnership, association and private,
public or Municipal corporation, the United States of America, the State of
Nevada, districts and all political subdivisions and governmental agencies
thereof.
PLUMBING SYSTEM All plumbing fixtures and traps, or soil, waste, special waste
and vent pipes, and all sanitary sewage pipes within the building on the
premises.
PRIVATE SEWER One which has an independent sewage disposal system not connected
with a public sewer and which accommodates one or more houses.
PUBLIC SEWER A sewer lying within a street or easement and which is controlled
by or under the jurisdiction of the MCW&SU. All owners of abutting properties
have equal rights.
SANITARY SUPERINTENDENT The inspector acting for and appointed by the Board.
SERVICE CONNECTION The point at which the side sewer connects to the public
sewer.
SEWAGE A combination of water-carried wastes from buildings and industrial
establishments connected to sewage works or from any private sewer.
SEWER A pipe or conduit which carries sewage and/or industrial wastes to which
storm, surface and ground waters are not intentionally admitted.
SEWER USER Any individual, firm, company, association, society or corporation
or group who has connected to the sewage system.
SHALL/MAY "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
SIDE SEWER The part of the horizontal piping beginning at the foundation wall
of any building and terminating in the public sewer.
SLUG Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration
of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of
duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes for more than five (5) times the
average twenty four (24) hour concentrations or flows during normal operation.
STORM DRAIN Sometimes termed "storm sewer", is a sewer which carries storm and
surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other
than unpolluted water such as cooling water.
STREET Any public highway, road, street, avenue, alley, easement or right of
way.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS Solids, organic or inorganic, that either float on the surface
of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are
removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the
Examination of Water and Waste Water" and referred to as a nonfilterable
residue.
TOWN The Town of Mountain City, Elko County, Nevada.
USER CHARGE A charge levied on users of treatment works for the use of
operation and maintenance (and replacement of equipment) of such works.
WASTEWATER The spent water of the community. It may be a combination of the
liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings,
industrial plants and institutions. Wastewater shall specifically exclude
uncontaminated water such as groundwater, rainwater and surface drainage.
9-9-2: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
9-9-2-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations governing sewer construction and disposal
of sewage and drainage of buildings and connection to the sewage works in
Mountain City are hereby adopted, and all work in respect thereto shall be
performed as herein required and not otherwise.
9-9-2-2: PURPOSE:
This Chapter is intended to provide certain minimum standards, provisions and
requirements for design, methods of construction and use of materials in
sanitary sewage facilities in lateral sewers hereafter installed, altered or
required. This Chapter shall not apply retroactively and, in the event of an
alteration or repair hereafter made, it shall apply only to the new materials
and methods used herein.
9-9-2-3: VIOLATION UNLAWFUL:
This Chapter shall be effective upon the date of adoption and thereafter. The
further maintenance or use of cesspools or other local means of sewage disposal
constitutes a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person to
connect to, construct, install or provide, maintain and use any other means of
sewage disposal from any dwelling place, provided the dwelling to be connected
is within four hundred feet (400') of an existing public sewer, in which
connection to in the usual manner is possible.
9-9-2-4: RELIEF FROM PROVISIONS OF CHAPTER:
   (A)   When any person, by reason of special circumstances, is of the opinion
that any provision of this Ordinance is unjust or inequitable as applied to his
premises, he may make written application to the County Board of Commissioners,
stating the special circumstances, citing the provision complained of, and
requesting suspension or modification of the provision as applied to his
premises.
   (B)   There will be a hearing on such application at the next regularly
scheduled meeting of the County Board of Commissioners or a noticed special
meeting. If, upon such hearing, the Board of Commissioners finds that the
provisions are unjust or inequitable as applied to the subject premises, the
County Board of Commissioners may, by resolution, suspend or modify the
provision complained of, as applied to such premises, to be effective as of the
date of the application and continuing during the period of the special
circumstances. Any such resolution shall be transmitted by the Clerk of the
Board of County Commissioners to the Mountain City Water and Sewer Users Board.
   (C)   The County Board of Commissioners may not suspend or modify the sewer
user fee, in any circumstances, unless the applicant shows clear and convincing
evidence of reduced inflow or inflow substantially below similarly classified
users.
9-9-2-5: RELIEF ON OWN MOTION:
The County Board of Commissioners, on its own motion, may find that by reason
of special circumstances, any provision of this Chapter should be suspended or
modified as applied to particular premises and may, by resolution, order such
suspension or modification for such premises during the period of such special
circumstances, or any part thereof. No suspension or modification of the sewer
use fee may be made unless there is a clear showing of reduced inflow or inflow
substantially below similarly classified users, and in all circumstances, the
use fee must remain reflective of proportional share of the inflow. Any such
resolution shall be transmitted by the Clerk of the County Board of
Commissioners to the Mountain City Water and Sewer Users, Inc. for its action.
9-9-2-6: PLUMBING, INSPECTION, COMPENSATION:
The Board shall employ the Sanitary Superintendent or such other person as may
be designated by the Board to perform the duties of inspecting the
installation, connection, maintenance and use of all lateral sewers and
plumbing, sewerage, sanitary drainage work and facilities in connection
therewith in Mountain City, Nevada. He shall receive as compensation for his
services for making inspections required to be made by the ordinances, and
orders and regulations from time to time enacted and ordered by the County and/
or Board a sum to be fixed by the Board. He shall serve during the pleasure of
the Board.
9-9-2-7: MATTER EXCLUDED FROM ALL SEWERS:
All surface drainage water or connection to inflow sources shall be excluded
from all parts of the sewer system designed as the sanitary sewer system.
9-9-2-8: PLANT CAPACITY AND DESIGN CRITERIA:
The new wastewater treatment plant (1983) is designed for a twenty (20) year
population of one hundred fifty (150) and a total average daily flow of forty
eight thousand (48,000) gallons. To accommodate more flow than the design flow
could damage the system or cause operational difficulties, therefore, the
system shall be protected accordingly by the City.
9-9-2-9: ANNUAL NOTIFICATION:
The Board shall notify each user, at least annually, the rate and that portion
of the user charges or ad valorem taxes which are attributable to wastewater
treatment services. Notification shall be in conjunction with a regular bill or
other means acceptable to the Regional Administrator of Environmental
Protection Agency.
9-9-3: FEES AND RATES:
9-9-3-1: SEWER USER CHARGES:
   (A)   The user of each dwelling unit within the Town of Mountain City
discharging sewage into the sewerage system, shall pay the Mountain City Water
and Sewer Users Board, Inc., for the use and right of use of the Mountain City
sewage facility. The use charge shall be determined by the following formulas:
 
Rate =        Total O & M and Debt Retirement
              Total units of contribution to the system
User Charge = Rate x user's units of contribution
 
The use charge (a unit) is based on the volume of sewage discharged from a
single-family residential unit. The unit volume of flow is 470 gallons per day
per residence.
The user charge for premises within the Town limits shall be $9.00 per unit per
month.
   (B)   When B.O.D., suspended solids or other pollutant concentrations from a
user exceed the range of concentration of these pollutants in normal domestic
sewage, a surcharge added to the base charge, calculated above, will be levied.
The surcharge will be computed by the model below:
Cs =   [Bc (B) = Sc (S) + Pc (P)] Vu
The unit of time shall be one year based upon the following:
Cs =   A surcharge for wastewater of excessive strength
Vu =   Volume contribution from a user per unit
Bc =   O & M cost for treatment of a unit of biochemical oxygen demand (B.O.D)
B =   Concentration of B.O.D. from a user above a base level
Sc =   O & M cost for treatment of a unit of suspended solids
S =   Concentration of suspended solids from a user above a base level
Pc =   O & M cost for treatment of unit of any pollutant
P =   Concentration of any pollutant from a user above a base level
   (C)   Where a sewer is provided for a combination of business or a
combination of a business and a residence, there shall be cumulative sewer
charge for all types of businesses and residences so served at said location.
   (D)   Charges herein set forth shall be payable while the user is actually
using the system. If a vacancy occurs, a use charge will not be assessed.
   (E)   The County shall review not less than every two (2) years the
wastewater contribution of users and user classes, the total cost of operation
and maintenance of the treatment work, and its approved user charge system. The
County shall revise the charges for users or user classes to accomplish the
following:
      1.   Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance
costs among users and user classes as required herein;
      2.   Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and
maintenance costs necessary to the proper operation and maintenance (including
replacement) of the treatment works; and
      3.   Apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the costs
of operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year and
adjust the rate accordingly.
   (F)   Each user will be notified, at least annually, in conjunction with a
regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the user charges or ad valorem
taxes which are attributable to wastewater treatment services.
   (G)   The Board may have pre-existing agreements which address: 1) the
reservation of capacity in the Mountain City Water and Sewer Users Board
Treatment Works; or 2) the charges to be collected by the Mountain City Water
and Sewer Users Board in providing wastewater treatment services or reserving
capacity. This use charge system shall take precedence over any terms or
conditions of agreements or contracts between the Mountain City Water and Sewer
Users Board and users (including industrial users, special districts, other
municipalities, or Federal Agencies or installations) which are inconsistent
with the requirements of section 204(b)(1)(A) of the Act and the regulations of
the U.S. EPA, September 27, 1978.

9-9-3-3: DWELLING UNIT OR RESIDENTIAL PRIVILEGE CONNECTION FEE:
The sewer connection fee is at a flat rate for each residential unit and shall
be in accordance with the following schedule:
 
Type of Residential Unit                                  Connection Fee
Single-family unit                                        $300.00  
Apartment house (per each apartment)                      $300.00  
Mobile home estates and parks (per each mobile home unit) $300.00  
Multiple-family residential unit (per unit)               $300.00  
Rooming house                                             $300.00 + 150/room
 
9-9-3-4: INDUSTRIAL/COMMERCIAL/INSTITUTIONAL PRIVILEGE CONNECTION FEE:
The sewer connection fees will be based on the number of weighted fixture units
which are being connected times ten dollars ($10.00) per weighted fixture unit.
The number of weighted fixture units shall be in accordance with the weighted
fixture unit schedule in Section
9-9-3-6 of this Chapter. The connection charge shall not be less than three
hundred dollars ($300.00) per connection.
9-9-3-5: CHARGES FOR OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE (O&M) COSTS FOR EXTRANEOUS
FLOWS:
The O&M costs attributable to infiltration and/or inflow will be apportioned
among all users in the same manner that the sewer user charges are apportioned.

9-9-3-7: PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES:
The following are the various classes and associated fees for permits and
inspections on the sewer system:
Classification Permit and Inspection Fee
Classification                          Permit and Inspection Fee
Single-family resident                  $25.00
Multiple-family units                   $25.00

Sewer main relocation (inspection only) No fee
Repairs, disconnects                    No fee
Alteration, additions                   No fee
