9-10-26: Applicability, Compliance With Laws and Requirements
9-10-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Elko County Cable
Television Ordinance.
9-10-2: PURPOSE AND AUTHORITY:
The Board of Elko County Commissioners finds that the development of cable
television and communications systems has the potential of having great benefit
and impact upon the residents of Elko County, Nevada. Because of the complex
and rapidly changing technology associated with cable television, the Board
further finds that the public convenience, safety and general welfare can be
best served by establishing regulatory powers which should be vested in the
County or such persons as the County shall designate. It is the intent of this
Chapter and subsequent amendments to provide for and specify the means to
attain the best possible public interest and public purpose in these matters
and any franchise issued pursuant to this Chapter shall be deemed to include
this finding as an integral part thereof.
Pursuant to the power granted the Board by chapter 711 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes, nonexclusive franchises are hereby created for the purpose of
operating a cable television system and the right and privilege to use County
property or that portion of the County dedicated for public use for the
installation and maintenance of cables, wires, poles or any other underground
or overhead devices for the transmission of television signals in any area of
the County which may be designated for such cable television service by the
Board.
9-10-3: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section, and when not inconsistent with the context,
words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural
include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural:
BASIC SUBSCRIBER REVENUES: All remuneration received directly by the franchisee
from subscribers in payment for regularly furnished cable television service,
but shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the franchisee imposed
on any subscriber or user by any government, governmental unit, political
subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, and collected by the franchisee.
BOARD: The Board of County Commissioners of Elko County.
CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEM, SYSTEM: A facility consisting of a set of closed
transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control
equipment that is designed to provide cable service, which includes producing,
receiving, transmitting, amplifying and distributing audio, video, and other
forms of electronic or electrical signals, to multiple subscribers within the
unincorporated areas of the County.
COUNTY: The County of Elko, State of Nevada, and all of the unincorporated area
within its boundaries over which the County exercises jurisdiction.
FRANCHISE: The right granted through a contractual agreement between the County
and a person by which the County authorizes such person to erect, construct,
reconstruct, operate, dismantle, test, use or maintain a cable television
system within the unincorporated areas of the County. Prior to January 1, 1987,
the term "franchise" shall mean a combination of the authorization to operate a
cable television system by the State of Nevada and authorization by the County
to use public rights of way for that purpose.
STREET: The surface of and the space above and below any public street, way,
place, right of way, road, highway, freeway, bridge, tunnel, lane, path, bike
path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, drive, communications or utility
easement, by whatever name called, now or hereafter existing as such.
9-10-4: APPLICATION FOR FRANCHISE; CONTENTS:
   (A)   Any person desiring to apply for a franchise shall submit an
application in writing to the County Manager. The application must include at a
minimum:
      1.   A clear description of the identity of the applicant, including but
not limited to the name of the applicant, the address of the applicant, the
nature of the business entity, and evidence of compliance by the business
entity with all applicable law;
      2.   The applicant's background, business references and financial
statements for the last two (2) years;
      3.   The proposed rates, service charges, or other fees to be charged
subscribers;
      4.   An estimate of the cost for installation of the system, and how the
cost will be financed;
      5.   The number and description of television channels the applicant will
distribute in the County immediately after the service is in operation and the
channels contemplated for future distribution;
      6.   Detailed plans and specifications for the proposed system, including
the physical location of cables, wires, poles and other equipment, as well as
their relationship to public property and/or rights of way;
      7.   The precise boundaries of the geographic area in the County for
which the franchise is sought and must have attached to the application a map
or maps which clearly depict that geographic area; and
      8.   A schedule of construction and a timetable for completion of the
proposed system, which shall be reflected on the map(s) required by Section
9-10-4(A)7.
   (B)   The Board, or the County Manager or his designee, may demand that the
applicant submit any additional relevant information deemed helpful to the
consideration of the application.
9-10-5: GRANTING OF FRANCHISE; PROCEDURE:
   (A)   The Board may grant a franchise for all or any defined portion of the
County. The service area shall be the entire area defined in the franchise
agreement.
   (B)   In the event that the Board shall grant a nonexclusive, revocable
franchise to construct, operate, maintain, and reconstruct, a cable television
system within the County, or a renewal of an existing franchise, said franchise
shall constitute both a right and an obligation to provide the services of a
cable television system as required by the provisions of this Chapter and the
franchise agreement.
   (C)   Any franchise granted under the terms and conditions of this Chapter
shall be consistent with Federal laws and regulations, and State general laws
and regulations. In the event of conflict between the terms and conditions on
which the Board may grant a franchise, the general law and/or statutory
requirements shall, without exception, control.
   (D)   Nothing in the franchise shall be deemed to waive the requirements of
all other applicable codes, ordinances, regulations or laws regarding permits,
fees to be paid, or manner of construction.
   (E)   No cable television system shall be allowed to occupy or use the
streets in the County or be allowed to operate without having entered into a
franchise agreement in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.
   (F)   The Board may establish by resolution appropriate requirements for new
franchises or franchise renewals, and may modify these requirements from time
to time to reflect changing conditions and state of art in the cable industry.
Such requirements shall not be retroactive to franchises then in effect, but
shall become applicable when the franchise is renewed.
   (G)   Any franchise granted pursuant to this Chapter shall be nonexclusive.
The Board specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such
additional franchises for a cable television system as it deems appropriate.
   (H)   After an application is received, the County Manager or his designee
shall conduct an investigation of the applicant and the feasibility of its
proposal.
   (I)   After the investigation is completed, the County Manager shall
schedule one or more public hearings on the application at regularly-held or
special meetings of the Board. The Board may consider competing franchise
applications at the hearing. The hearing must be noticed in accordance with
Nevada's Open Meeting Law, and, additionally, by publication of one notice in a
newspaper of general circulation which serves the area of the County to be
included in the proposed franchise.
   (J)   At the time of the hearing, the Board shall consider all relevant
evidence and hear comments from the public. At the hearing the applicant must
insure that:
      1.   The safety, functioning and appearance of property and the
convenience and safety of other persons will not be adversely affected by the
installation or construction of facilities necessary for the system.
      2.   The cost of the installation, construction, operation or removal of
the facilities will be borne by the applicant or subscribers, or a combination
of both.
      3.   The owners of any property affected by the installation, operation,
maintenance or removal of the system will be justly compensated for any damages
caused by the installation, operation, maintenance or removal of the system.
      4.   Access to cable service will not be denied to any group of potential
residential cable subscribers based upon their income level.
      5.   The applicant will be able to provide adequate service to the
potential subscribers.
   (K)   A decision shall be made by the Board not later than ninety (90) days
after the conclusion of all such public hearings, and based upon the evaluation
of the application(s), the hearings and any other information the Board deems
relevant, the Board may grant one or more franchises for any service area, or
may decline to grant any franchise.
   (L)   Any franchise granted pursuant to this Chapter shall not become
effective until a written franchise agreement is entered into between the
successful applicant and the County, and the performance bond and certificates
of insurance required by Sections
9-10-10 and
9-10-11 have been filed. The written franchise agreement must be executed
within ninety (90) days of the granting of the franchise and shall contain such
provisions and conditions which are deemed by the Board to be reasonable and
necessary to insure quality service and compliance with all applicable laws,
rules, and regulations. If agreement cannot be reached on the terms and
conditions of a written franchise agreement as required by this Section, the
franchise may be declared by the County to be void.
9-10-6: PERIOD OF FRANCHISE; RENEWAL:
   (A)   A franchise granted pursuant to this Chapter is a franchise for the
maintenance and operation of a cable television system within the County for a
period of up to fifteen (15) years after the date the franchise becomes
effective.
   (B)   During the three (3) year period immediately preceding the expiration
of a franchise, the Board may commence proceedings which afford the public in
the franchise area appropriate notice and participation for the purpose of:
      1.   Identifying the future cable-related community needs and interests;
and
      2.   Reviewing the performance of the franchisee under the franchise
during the then current franchise term.
   (C)   During the three (3) year period immediately preceding the expiration
of a franchise, a franchisee seeking renewal of a franchise may on its own
initiative or at the request of the Board, submit a proposal for renewal.
Subject to applicable Federal law, any such proposal shall address such issues
as the Board may direct, including proposals for an upgrade of the cable
system. The Board may establish a date by which such proposal shall be
submitted.
   (D)   Upon submittal by a franchisee of a proposal to the Board for the
renewal of a franchise, the Board may commence an administrative proceeding,
after providing notice to the franchisee and the public of such proceeding, to
consider whether:
      1.   The franchisee has substantially complied with the material terms of
the existing franchise and with applicable law;
      2.   The quality of the franchisee's service, including signal quality,
response to consumer complaints, and billing practices, has been reasonable in
light of community needs;
      3.   The franchisee has the financial, legal, and technical ability to
provide the services, facilities, and equipment as set forth in the
franchisee's proposal; and
      4.   The franchisee's proposal is reasonable to meet the future cable-
related community needs and interests, taking into account the cost of meeting
such needs and interests.
   (E)   In any proceeding under subsection (D) above, the franchisee, the
public, and the Board or its designee, shall be afforded fair opportunity for
participation, including the right to offer testimony and introduce evidence,
including testimony and evidence related to issues raised in a proceeding under
subsection (B) above and any other matters relevant to the issue of franchise
renewal.
   (F)   At the completion of a proceeding under subsection (D) above, the
Board shall issue a written decision granting or denying the proposal for
renewal based upon the record of such proceeding, and transmit a copy of such
decision to the franchisee. Such decision shall state the reasons therefor.
9-10-7: EXPANSION OF FRANCHISE AREA:
   (A)   Due to the development of new areas within the County, expansion of
franchise areas may be necessary to provide service to such newly developed
areas. Application for expansion of existing franchise areas shall be made as
follows:
      1.   Any person desiring to provide service to an area not previously
covered by a franchise agreement shall submit an application to the County
Manager. The application shall contain all relevant details required by Section
9-10-4 of this Chapter.
      2.   The Board shall schedule a public hearing at which public comment on
the proposal will be received and considered. The Board may also consider
proposals submitted prior to the hearing by other persons to service the
unfranchised area.
      3.   Within a reasonable time after the hearing the Board may grant one
or more franchises for the previously unfranchised area. If the franchise is
granted to an existing franchisee, the boundaries of the existing franchise
will be automatically expanded to include the newly franchised area.
9-10-8: FRANCHISE FEES:
   (A)   The franchisee shall pay the County a franchise fee of not more than
five percent (5%) of basic subscriber revenues received for cable television
operations. Sales tax or other taxes levied on a per subscription basis and
collected by the franchisee shall be deducted from the gross annual basic
subscriber revenues in computing any sums due the County. The franchisee shall
provide the County with quarterly and annual reports showing gross basic
subscriber revenues received during the applicable period.
   (B)   The franchisee shall pay in quarterly installments. All payments are
due thirty (30) days after the end of a quarter. Any franchise fees which
remain unpaid after the date specified in this Section shall be delinquent and
shall thereafter accrue interest at the maximum legal rate until paid.
   (C)   The fee requirements under this Section shall apply to new franchises
granted or existing franchises which are renewed after the effective date of
this Chapter.
   (D)   No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as an accord that the
amount paid is, in fact, the correct amount, nor shall acceptance be construed
as a release of any claim which the County may have for additional sums payable
under the provisions of this Section.
9-10-9: RATES:
The franchisee shall maintain on file with the County Manager a schedule
setting forth all rates and charges to subscribers for cable television
service, including connection and services charges. Notice of changes in rates
and charges shall be filed with the County Manager at least thirty (30) days in
advance of the effective date thereof.
9-10-10: BOND:
   (A)   Franchisee shall, within twenty (20) days after the date of the
granting of a franchise, file with the County Manager, and at all times
thereafter maintain in full force and effect for the entire term of the
franchise, at its expense, a faithful performance bond executed by a surety
company approved by the Board, and in form satisfactory to the Board, in the
amount of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) renewable annually, and
conditioned on the faithful performance by the franchisee of all the terms,
conditions, and covenants contained in the franchise. If the franchisee fails
to comply with any one or more of the provisions of the franchise, there shall
be recoverable jointly and severally from the principal and surety of such bond
any damages or losses suffered by the County as a result thereof.
   (B)   Neither the provisions of any bond accepted by County pursuant hereto,
nor any damages recovered by County thereunder, shall be construed to excuse
faithful performance by franchisee or limit the liability of franchisee under
the franchise or for damages, or preclude the exercise of any other right or
remedy given to County by law.
9-10-11: COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS, REGULATIONS; PAYMENT OF COST OF REPAIRS;
INSURANCE:
Every franchisee shall:
   (A)   Construct, install and maintain or cause to be constructed, installed
and maintained all lines, wires, cables, and appurtenances in accordance with
any and all of the ordinances, rules and regulations heretofore or hereafter
adopted by the Board in the exercise of its police powers and in accordance
with the general laws and regulations relating to the location and maintenance
of such facilities.
   (B)   Pay to County, on demand, the reasonable cost of all repairs to public
property made necessary by any operations under the franchise.
   (C)   Maintain in full force and effect throughout the term of the franchise
the following insurance in a form and with insurer(s) satisfactory to the
County:
      1.   Worker's compensation insurance in compliance with the laws of the
State of Nevada;
      2.   Bodily injury liability insurance with limits of five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per person, and one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; and
      3.   Property damage liability insurance with limits of one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per occurrence.
   (D)   The County must be named as an additional insured on each policy of
insurance set forth in subparagraphs (C)2 and 3 above.
   (E)   File and maintain with the County Manager a current certificate of
insurance evidencing the insurance coverage required by subparagraphs (C)2 and
3 above.
9-10-12: AUTHORITY FOR USE OF STREETS:
   (A)   For the purposes of operating and maintaining a cable television
system in the County, the franchisee may erect, install, construct, repair,
replace, reconstruct and retain in, on, over, under, upon, across and along the
streets within the County such lines, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits,
vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, pedestals, attachments and other
property and equipment as are necessary and appurtenant to the operation of the
system, provided that all applicable permits are applied for and granted, all
fees paid, and all other County Code provisions otherwise complied with.
   (B)   Prior to construction or alteration of the system, the franchisee
shall in each case file plans with all appropriate County agencies and utility
companies and receive written approval of such plans, which approval shall not
be unreasonably withheld. Franchisee shall provide a monthly progress report to
County through the completion of construction or alteration.
   (C)   Franchisee shall construct and maintain the system so as not to
interfere with other uses of streets. Franchisee shall make use of existing
poles and other facilities available to it. Franchisee shall individually
notify all residents affected by proposed construction prior to the
commencement of that work.
   (D)   Notwithstanding the above grant to use streets, no street shall be
used by franchisee if County, in its sole opinion, determines that such use is
inconsistent with the terms, conditions or provisions by which such street was
created or dedicated, or presently used.
9-10-13: CONDITIONS OF STREET OCCUPANCY:
   (A)   All structures, lines, and equipment erected or maintained by the
franchisee within the County shall be so located as to cause minimum
interference with the proper use of streets, alleys, and other public ways and
places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable
convenience of property owners who abut any of the said streets, alleys or
other public ways and places.
   (B)   In case of disturbance of any street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or
paved area, the franchisee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner
approved by the Elko County Engineering Department, replace and restore such
street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or paved area in as good a condition as
before the work causing such disturbance was done.
9-10-14: ERECTION OF POLES:
No franchise shall be deemed to expressly or impliedly authorize the franchisee
to construct or install poles or wire-holding structures within streets for the
purpose of placing cables, wires or lines without the written consent of the
Board. Such consent shall be given upon such terms and conditions as the Board
in its sole discretion may prescribe, and which shall include a requirement
that the franchisee perform, at its sole expense, all acts required to maintain
the poles clear of obstructions.
9-10-15: UNDERGROUNDING:
Unless permission of the Board to do otherwise is obtained, in all areas of the
County where the cables, wires, and other like facilities of a public utility
or public utility district are placed underground, each franchisee shall
construct and install its cables, wires, and other facilities underground.
9-10-16: CONDITION OF PLANT:
All structures and all lines, equipment and connections, in, over, under, and
upon all streets of the franchise area shall be kept and maintained in a safe
and suitable condition and in good order and repair by the franchisee.
9-10-17: REMOVAL, RELOCATION OF FACILITIES:
   (A)   The franchisee shall, at its expense, protect, support, temporarily
disconnect, relocate in the same street or other public place, or remove from
the street or other public place any property of the franchisee when required
by the Board by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street vacation,
freeway and street construction, change or establishment of street grade,
installation of sewers, drains, gas, or water pipes, or any other type of
alteration or improvement by the Board.
   (B)   The franchisee shall, upon request, temporarily raise or lower its
wires to permit the moving of buildings, provided:
      1.   The expense of such temporary raising or lowering of wires is paid
by the person moving such building, including, if required by the franchisee,
making such payment in advance; and
      2.   The franchisee is given not less than seven (7) business days
advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes.
9-10-18: NOTICE OF SALE, TRANSFER, ASSIGNMENT, LEASE:
The person receiving each franchise shall, thirty (30) days before the
transaction is to become effective, file with the County Clerk written notice
of any contemplated sale, transfer, assignment or lease of the franchise or any
part thereof, or of any of the rights or privileges granted thereby. No such
sale, transfer, assignment or lease of the franchise, or any part thereof,
shall be effective until first approved by the Board.
9-10-19: FORFEITURE:
If any person securing a franchise fails, neglects or refuses to comply with
any of the provisions or conditions of this Chapter, and does not within ten
(10) days after written demand for compliance begin the work of compliance, or
after such beginning does not prosecute the work of compliance with due
diligence to completion, then the Board may declare such franchise forfeited.
9-10-20: PROCEDURE UPON TERMINATION:
Upon expiration of the franchise, or upon termination as otherwise provided
herein, if the franchisee shall not have perfected a renewal thereof, it may
have, and it is hereby granted, the right to enter upon the streets or other
property of the County for the purpose of removing therefrom any or all of its
property. In so removing said property, the franchisee shall refill, at its
expense, any excavation that it shall make, and shall leave said streets in as
good condition as that prevailing prior to the franchisee's removal of its
property.
9-10-21: COMPLAINTS: REPORTS AND PROCEDURES:
   (A)   Each franchise agreement shall contain a procedure for hearing and
resolution of subscriber complaints.
   (B)   The franchisee shall submit a monthly report to the County Manager
describing in general categories the types and numbers of complaints received
from subscribers. If requested by the County Manager or his designee, the
franchisee will supply names and addresses of the complainants.
   (C)   The complaints will be listed in two (2) categories:
      1.   Those involving reception or service; and
      2.   Others such as billing disputes.
   (D)   The report shall state which complaints were resolved and how and when
they were resolved.
   (E)   Each franchise agreement will contain provisions allowing reduction of
bills for periods of service failure.
   (F)   All customer complaints shall be promptly resolved by the franchisee.
9-10-22: INDEMNIFICATION BY GRANTEE:
   (A)   Each franchisee shall, at its sole expense, fully indemnify, defend
and hold harmless the County, and in their capacity as such, the officers,
agents and employees thereof, from and against any and all claims, suits,
actions, liability and judgments for damages or otherwise:
      1.   For actual or alleged injury to persons or property, including loss
of use of property due to an occurrence, whether or not such property is
physically damaged or destroyed, in any way arising out of or through or
alleged to arise out of or through the acts or omissions of the franchisee or
its officers, agents, employees, or contractors or to which the franchisee's or
its officer's, agent's employees' or contractor's acts or omissions in any way
contribute;
      2.   Arising out of or alleged to arise out of any claim for damages for
invasion of the right of privacy, defamation of any person, firm or
corporation, or the violation or infringement of any copyright, trademark,
trade name, service mark or patent, or of any other right of any person, firm
or corporation; and
      3.   Arising out of or alleged to arise out of franchisee's failure to
comply with the provisions of any statute, regulation, or ordinance of the
United States, State of Nevada, or any local agency applicable to the
franchisee in its business.
   (B)   Nothing herein shall be deemed to prevent the parties indemnified and
held harmless herein from participating in the defense of any litigation by
their own counsel at the franchisee's sole expense. Such participation shall
not under any circumstances relieve the franchisee from its duty of defense
against liability or of paying any judgment entered against such party.
9-10-23: ALTERNATIVE REMEDIES:
No provision of this Chapter shall be deemed to bar the right of the County to
seek or obtain judicial relief from a violation of any provision of the
franchise or any rule, regulation, requirement or directive promulgated
thereunder. Neither the existence of other remedies identified in this Chapter
nor the exercise thereof shall be deemed to bar or otherwise limit the right of
the County to recover monetary damages for such violation by the franchisee, or
judicial enforcement of the franchisee's obligations by means of specific
performance, injunction relief or mandate, or any other judicial remedy at law
or in equity.
9-10-24: AUDITING AND FINANCIAL RECORDS:
   (A)   The auditor of the County may, from time to time during the term of a
franchise prescribe standards governing the nature, extent and type of
accounting system and accounting procedures utilized by a franchisee and
require changes in accounting standards or procedures utilized by a franchisee,
for the purpose of promoting the efficient administration of the franchise fee
requirements of this Chapter. Any such standards shall be in writing, shall be
filed with the County Manager and shall be mailed to the franchisee to whom
directed. A franchisee shall promptly comply with all such standards.
   (B)   During the term of each franchise, the County may, not more frequently
than once each year, conduct an audit of the books, records, and accounts of
the franchisee for the purpose of determining whether the franchisee has paid
the appropriate franchise fee. The audit may be conducted by the auditor of the
County or by an independent certified public accounting firm retained by the
County and shall be conducted at the sole expense of the County. The party
conducting the audit shall prepare a written report containing its findings,
and the report shall be filed with the County Manager and mailed to the
franchisee.
   (C)   Each franchisee shall make available for inspection by authorized
representatives of the County, its books, accounts, and all other financial
records at reasonable times and upon reasonable advance notice for the purpose
of permitting exercise of the authorities conferred by this Section.
9-10-25: NONENFORCEMENT:
A franchisee shall not be relieved of any obligation to comply with any of the
provisions of the franchise or any rule, regulation, requirement or directive
promulgated thereunder by reason of any failure of the County or its officers,
agents or employees to enforce prompt compliance.
9-10-26: APPLICABILITY, COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS AND REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   In Public Law 98-549, known as the Cable Communications Policy Act of
1984, the United States Congress began the process of deregulation of cable
television systems by states and local governments. By amendment to chapter 711
of NRS effective July 1, 1985, the Nevada Public Service Commission was removed
from the field of cable television regulation and the regulatory responsibility
was shifted to counties and cities. The effect of such legislation was not
immediate, and a number of existing laws and regulations were left in effect
for varying periods of time. To the extent that such laws and regulations
allow, the State laws and Public Service Commission rules and regulations in
effect on July 1, 1985, shall be applicable to any franchise granted under the
provisions of this Chapter.
   (B)   A franchise issued by the County prior to July 1, 1985, and any
extensions thereof allowing the use of public property for the installation of
cable television facilities will remain effective for the term of such
franchise to the extent of the authority granted by such franchise. Provided,
however, that in order to continue operation of an existing franchise after the
expiration of the term thereof, the franchisee shall be required to secure a
new or supplemental franchise subject to the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord.
1988-B, 4-7-88, eff. 4-25-88)
CHAPTER 11
MIDAS WATER DISTRICT
SECTION:
9-11-1: District Created; Boundaries; Name
9-11-2: Basic Purpose and Power of District
9-11-3: Public Convenience and Necessity; Economic Feasibility
9-11-4: Designation of Trustees
9-11-5: Adoption of Provisions
9-11-6: Incorporation by Reference
9-11-7: Recital of Protests filed
9-11-1: DISTRICT CREATED; BOUNDARIES; NAME:
This Chapter is enacted pursuant to the terms and provisions of chapters 308
and 318 of the Nevada Revised Statutes in order to create the Midas Water
District for the purpose of supplying, storing, and distributing water for
public and private purposes.
The boundaries of the Midas Water District are as follows:
The East half (E1/2) of the East half (E1/2) of Section 20 of T. 39 N., R. 46
E., M.D.B. & M.; and
The Southwest quarter (SW1/4) of the Northwest quarter (NW1/4), and the
Northwest quarter (NW1/4) of the Southwest quarter (SW1/4) of Section 21 of T.
39 N., R. 46 E., M.D.B. & M.
The specific contiguous unincorporated area described above shall include the
original townsite of Gold Circle as described in the "Map of Gold Circle" filed
for record in the office of the Elko County Recorder, official records of Elko
County, on November 5, 1907, and the original Moffat Addition to the town of
Gold Circle as described in the "Map of the Moffat Addition to the Town of Gold
Circle" filed for record in the office of the Elko County Recorder, on April
22, 1908.
Total area of approximately 202 acres.
The District hereby created shall be known as the Midas Water District.
9-11-2: BASIC PURPOSE AND POWER OF DISTRICT:
   (A)   The basic purpose for which the District is created is to supply,
store, and distribute water for public and private purposes and the District
shall have the power to acquire, construct, reconstruct, improve, extend or
better a works, system, or facilities to that end.
   (B)   The District shall have and is authorized to utilize, without
limitation, all the powers necessary to achieve the stated purpose as given by
chapters 308 and 318 of the Nevada Revised Statutes.
9-11-3: PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY; ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY:
   (A)   The Board of County Commissioners finds as follows:
      1.   That there is an existing need for water supply, storage, and
distribution facilities for public and private purposes within the District and
that the public convenience and necessity require its creation;
      2.   That the creation of the District is economically sound and
feasible;
      3.   That the service plan for the District conforms to subsection 1 of
the Nevada Revised Statutes 308.030; and
      4.   That the service plan for the District does not contravene any of
the criteria enumerated in subsection 1 of the Nevada Revised Statutes 308.060.
9-11-4: DESIGNATION OF TRUSTEES:
The Board of County Commissioners does hereby elect to serve, pursuant to the
Nevada Revised Statutes 318.0953(2), ex officio, as the Board of Trustees of
the District.
9-11-5: ADOPTION OF PROVISIONS:
All terms and provisions of chapters 308 and 318 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes, pertinent, relevant and applicable to the operation of the District
are hereby ratified, confirmed and made a part hereof and nothing herein
contained shall be construed to be in derogation of said terms and provisions,
any and all such conflicts to be construed in harmony with statutory terms and
provisions.
9-11-6: INCORPORATION BY REFERENCE:
Elko County Commission Resolution No. 80-88, entitled "Resolution Approving
Service Plan for Midas Water General Improvement District", and the "Service
Plan for Special Water District, Community of Midas, Elko County, Nevada",
dated October 17, 1988, and prepared for the Board of Elko County Commissioners
by Galen D. Denio, P.E., pursuant to the Special District Control Law, Nevada
Revised Statutes chapter 308, are incorporated by reference as if fully set
forth herein.
9-11-7: RECITAL OF PROTESTS FILED:
Of a total of one hundred forty four (144) property owners within the District
who were notified by mail of the proceedings to organize and create the
District, eight (8) written protests against the formation of the District were
filed with the Elko County Clerk. (Ord. 1989-H, 5-17-89; eff. 5-30-89)
TITLE 10
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
10-1-1: Livestock Running at Large
10-1-2: Dump Restrictions
10-1-1: LIVESTOCK RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow his sheep, cattle,
goats, horses, mules or other livestock to be in and upon the streets, alleys
or roads of the Town of Mountain City. Any person violating any provisions
hereof shall be punished with a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars
($300.00) or by imprisonment not to exceed three (3) months, or by both such
fine and imprisonment. (Ord. dated 7-6-55)
10-1-2: DUMP RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump or deposit the dead
carcass or carcasses of any animal or fowl in the public dumps of the County,
and any person violating these provisions shall, on conviction thereof, be
punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment in the County jail not exceeding
three (3) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 1965-E, 7-7-65)
CHAPTER 2
ABANDONED, WRECKED VEHICLES
SECTION:
10-2-1: Nuisance Declared
10-2-2: Definitions
10-2-3: Application of Chapter
10-2-4: Chapter Not Exclusive
10-2-5: Enforcement of Regulations
10-2-6: Removal of Vehicles
10-2-7: Notice of Nuisance; Hearing
10-2-8: Information Forwarded to Department of Motor Vehicles
10-2-9: Cost of Removal a Lien
10-2-10: Abatement of Nuisance; Violations
10-2-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
The accumulation and storage of abandoned, wrecked, dismantled or inoperative
vehicles, or parts thereof, creates a condition tending to reduce the value of
property, promotes a blight and deterioration, invites plundering, constitutes
a nuisance attractive to and hazardous to the safety of minors, creates a
harborage for rodents and insects, is deleterious and injurious to the health
and welfare of the residents of the County, and is hereby declared a public
nuisance and a crime against the order and economy of the County.
10-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
The term "vehicle" means a device by which any person or property may be
propelled, moved or drawn upon a highway, stationary rails or cross-country,
except a device moved by human power; the term "vehicle" includes, but is not
limited to: Automobile, truck, trailer, tractor, railway car, motorcycle, self-
propelled van, dune buggy, snowmobile and all terrain vehicles.
10-2-3: APPLICATION OF CHAPTER:
This Chapter shall not apply to:
   (A)   A vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within a
building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other
public or private property.
   (B)   A vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in a lawful manner
on private property in connection with the business of a licensed dismantles,
licensed vehicle dealer, a junk dealer or when such storage or parking is
necessary to the operation of a lawfully conducted business or commercial
enterprise.
10-2-4: CHAPTER NOT EXCLUSIVE:
This Chapter is not the exclusive regulation of abandoned, wrecked, dismantled
or inoperative vehicles within the County, or any other legal entity or agency
having jurisdiction.
10-2-5: ENFORCEMENT OF REGULATIONS:
Except as otherwise provided herein, the provisions of this Chapter shall be
administered and enforced by the Planning Advisor. In the enforcement of this
Chapter, such officer and his deputies, assistants and employees may enter upon
private or public property to examine a vehicle or parts thereof, or obtain
information as to the identity of a vehicle and to remove or cause the removal
of a vehicle or part thereof declared to be a nuisance pursuant to this
Chapter.
10-2-6: REMOVAL OF VEHICLES:
When the Board of County Commissioners has contracted with or granted a
franchise to any person or persons, such person or persons shall be authorized
to enter upon private property or public property to remove or cause the
removal of a vehicle or parts thereof declared to be a nuisance pursuant to
this Chapter.
10-2-7: NOTICE OF NUISANCE; HEARING:
   (A)   Upon it being determined by the Planning Advisor that a nuisance
exists pursuant to this Chapter, a notice describing said nuisance shall be
sent via certified mail to the owner or person in custody of the real property
upon which the nuisance exists and to the last registered and legal owner of
record of the vehicle(s) unless the vehicle(s) is in such a condition that
identification numbers are not available to determine ownership. Said notice
shall require that within fifteen (15) days of receipt of notice, the vehicle
(s) or parts thereof shall be either:
      1.   Enclosed in a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible
from the street or other public or private property; or
      2.   Moved to a location upon the owner's property where it is not
visible from the street or other public or private property; or
      3.   Removed to the place of business of a licensed vehicle dismantles or
junk dealer; or
      4.   Removed to a designated County or City dumpsite; or
      5.   Legally released to the County with the assessment of the cost of
removal of the vehicle or part thereof against the property on which it is
located; or
      6.   Disclaimed by written disclaimer of ownership or responsibility
filed with the Planning Advisor, requesting a hearing on the issue.
   (B)   The hearing provided by subsection (A) 6 above shall be held within a
reasonable time before the Board of County Commissioners which shall hear all
facts and testimony on the condition of the vehicle, or parts thereof, and the
circumstances concerning its location and ownership. The Board of County
Commissioners shall not be limited by the technical rules of evidence.
Written notice of the hearing shall be given the person requesting said hearing
by certified mail posted at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing.
The Board of County Commissioners may impose such conditions and take such
other action as it deems appropriate under the circumstances to carry out the
purpose of this Chapter. It may delay the time for removal of the vehicle or
part thereof if, in its opinion, the circumstances justify. At the conclusion
of the public hearing, the Board of County Commissioners may find that a
vehicle or part thereof has been abandoned, wrecked, dismantled or is
inoperative on private or public property and order the same removed from the
property as a public nuisance and disposed of as hereinafter provided and
determine the administrative costs and the costs of removal to be charged
against the owner of the parcel of land on which the vehicle or part thereof is
located. The order requiring removal shall include a description of the vehicle
or part thereof and the correct identification number and license number of the
vehicle, if available at the site.
If it is determined at the hearing that the vehicle was placed on the land
without the consent of the landowner and that he has not subsequently
acquiesced in its presence, the Board of County Commissioners shall not assess
costs of administration or removal of the vehicle against the property upon
which the vehicle is located or otherwise attempt to collect such costs from
such landowner.
10-2-8: INFORMATION FORWARDED TO DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
Within five (5) days after the date of removal of the vehicle or part thereof,
notice shall be given to the Department of Motor Vehicles identifying the
vehicle or part thereof removed. At the same time there shall be transmitted to
the Department of Motor Vehicles any evidence of registration available,
including registration certificates, certificates of title and license plates.
10-2-9: COST OF REMOVAL A LIEN:
The cost of removal, which shall include administrative costs, shall be a lien
upon the land where the nuisance was situate.
10-2-10: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE; VIOLATIONS:
Every person who shall commit or maintain a public nuisance as hereinabove
defined or who shall wilfully omit or refuse to perform any legal duty relating
to the removal of such nuisance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
Any court or magistrate before whom there may be pending any proceeding for a
violation of this Chapter shall, in addition to any fine or other punishment
which it may impose for such violation, order such nuisance abated and all
property unlawfully used in the maintenance thereof destroyed by the Sheriff at
the cost of the defendant. (Ord. 1971-A; 5-5-71)
CHAPTER 3
WILDHORSE RESERVOIR SEWAGE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
10-3-1: Definitions
10-3-2: Criteria
10-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
HIGHWATER LINE: On Wildhorse Reservoir, the highwater line shall be a line
connecting all points around the perimeter of the lake that are at the 6206.5
feet elevation (1.5 feet above spillway crest). On tributaries, it shall be the
highest readily discernable point displaying evidence of inundation.
MAJOR TRIBUTARIES: Those streams which normally flow at their point of junction
with the highwater line for one month or more during the annual spring run-off.
SEWER SYSTEM COMPONENT: Any pipe, conduit, pump, tank, vault, leach pit, leach
field or any other structure, or device used for the collection, conveyance,
treatment or accumulation of effluent or products formed by its decomposition.
All other terms used in this Chapter shall have the meaning customarily
associated with such term.
10-3-2: CRITERIA:
   (A)   1. All components of every sewerage system shall maintain not less
than four feet (4') vertical separation between the lowest point to which earth
is disturbed during installation and the highwater line.
      2.   The vertical separation as required by (A) 1 above shall prevail for
all installations installed between one hundred fifty feet (150') and five
hundred feet (500') (horizontal distance) from the highwater line of Wildhorse
Reservoir and for one mile (straight line distance) upstream from the highwater
line of said reservoir along any of its major tributaries. No component shall
be installed less than one hundred fifty feet (150') from the highwater line.
   (B)   Nothing contained in subsection (A) shall relieve the developer from
full compliance with all other standards established by the current applicable
County Plumbing Codes for the area governed by the terms of this Chapter.
   (C)   All current County Plumbing Code requirements shall prevail for all
installations beyond five hundred feet (500'). (Ord. 1972-A; 12-9-71)
CHAPTER 4
WILDHORSE RESERVOIR GARBAGE COLLECTION FRANCHISE
(Rep. by Ord. 1997-M, 12-4-1997, eff. 12-22-1997)
CHAPTER 5
CORONERS
SECTION:
10-5-1: Certificate of Cause of Death
10-5-1: CERTIFICATE OF CAUSE OF DEATH:
   (A)   The ex-officio coroner or his duly appointed deputy may certify the
cause of death in the case of any death occurring without medical attendance.
Where there is no qualified physician in attendance, and in such cases only,
the coroner or his deputy is authorized to make the certificate and return from
the statements of relatives or other persons having adequate knowledge of the
facts. If the death was caused by unlawful or suspicious means, the coroner
shall conduct an investigation.
   (B)   In those cases in which an autopsy is performed upon the deceased, the
medical certificate of the death may be signed by the pathologist who performed
the autopsy.
   (C)   All ex-officio coroners and deputy coroners will complete a course of
instruction approved by the County Health Officer prior to ever certifying the
cause of death of any person. (Ord. 1978-E, 4-6-78, eff. 4-20-78)
CHAPTER 6
OVERNIGHT CAMPING WITHIN JARBIDGE
SECTION:
10-6-1: Overnight Camping Unlawful
10-6-2: Definition
10-8-3: Exemptions
10-6-1: OVERNIGHT CAMPING UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to camp overnight within the townsite of
Jarbidge, Nevada.
10-6-2: DEFINITION:
"Overnight camping" shall include but shall not necessarily be limited to the
following:
   (A)   Staying overnight in motor vehicles of any type.
   (B)   Staying overnight in tents, trailers, mobile homes or similar means of
shelter.
   (C)   Sleeping overnight without being in any form of shelter and
protection.
10-6-3: EXEMPTIONS:
"Overnight camping" shall not include the following:
   (A)   Staying overnight in a residence within the townsite of Jarbidge,
Nevada.
   (B)   Staying overnight by a resident of Jarbidge on his own property. (Ord.
1978-K, 6-16-78, eff. 7-4-78)
CHAPTER 7
CLEARING ARID AND SEMI-ARID LANDS
SECTION:
10-7-1: Conditions Precedent to Development
10-7-2: Violation
10-7-1: CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO DEVELOPMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person, combination of persons, association,
partnership or corporation to intentionally clear native brush or top soil from
land, the possession of which has been obtained through the Desert Land Entry
Act (43 C.F.R. 2520, et seq.) or the Carey Act (Nevada Revised Statutes 324.010
et seq.) for the purpose of preparing the said land for agricultural use in
accordance with the aforementioned acts without first having an established and
immediately usable water source, including established and installed pumping
equipment, sufficient to beneficially irrigate the land to be cleared and
without first acquiring legal access to the land to be cleared. (Ord. 1984-G,
8-9-84, eff. 9-1-84)
10-7-2: VIOLATION:
Any violation of the aforementioned Section shall constitute a misdemeanor
offense. (Ord. 1979-D, 4-4-79, eff. 5-1-79)
CHAPTER 8
DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SERVICES
SECTION:
10-8-1: Definitions
10-8-2: Department Created
10-8-3: Director; Appointment; Salary; Duties
10-8-4: Policies and Procedures
10-8-5: Appeals
10-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
COMMISSIONERS: The Board of Elko County Commissioners.
DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SERVICES: The County Department of Social Services.
DIRECTOR: The director of the County Department of Social Services. (Ord. 1990-
P, 6-20-90, eff. 7-3-90; amd. Ord. 1993-B, 3-17-93, eff. 4-1-93)
10-8-2: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is created a County Department of Social Services which shall consist of
a director and such other officers and employees as are authorized in this
Chapter. The Department of Social Services is expressly authorized to exercise
and perform those duties granted to the Board of County Commissioners under
chapter 428 of the Nevada Revised Statutes. (Ord. 1990-P, 6-20-90, eff. 7-3-90;
amd. Ord. 1993-B, 3-17-93, eff. 4-1-93)
10-8-3: DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; SALARY; DUTIES:
   (A)   The Director shall be appointed by the Board of County Commissioners.
   (B)   The Director shall serve at the pleasure of the Board of County
Commissioners and may be removed from office by the Board at any time. The
salary shall be determined by the Board of County Commissioners. The County
shall bond the Director for a minimum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
   (C)   The Director shall discharge all duties and administer all programs as
the Commissioners may delegate to the Director. Such duties and administrative
responsibilities shall be restricted to those which the various State laws
pertaining to welfare matters are the responsibility of the County and can be
lawfully delegated by the Board of County Commissioners to appointed or elected
officials of the County.
   (D)   The Director shall have the authority to:
      1.   Make decisions regarding disposition of grants and funds budgeted
for the County Department of Social Services.
      2.   Develop policy and procedures for the County Department of Social
Services, subject to approval by the Board of County Commissioners.
      3.   Make decisions and act in emergency situations without the prior
approval of the Board of County Commissioners.
      4.   Employ staff members, determine salaries and other expenses
necessary for the proper functioning of the Department; with approval of the
Board of County Commissioners. (Ord. 1990-P, 6-20-90, eff. 7-3-90; amd. Ord.
1993-B, 3-17-93, eff. 4-1-93)
10-8-4: POLICIES AND PROCEDURES:
   (A)   The Department of Social Services will be operated in accordance with
the Department's policy and procedure manual. The manual will be established to
depict:
      1.   Organization;
      2.   Case management;
      3.   Eligibility standards;
      4.   Program management;
      5.   Eligibility determination;
      6.   Services provided;
      7.   Grants.
   (B)   The policy and procedures may be modified to comply with the County
Code and the Nevada Revised Statutes. The policies and procedures of Nevada
Rural County Welfare Departments will remain uniform. Amendments should be done
uniformly to preserve consistency in benefits and service delivery. (Ord. 1990-
P, 6-20-90, eff. 7-3-90; Ord. 1993-B, 3-17-93, eff. 4-1-93)
10-8-5: APPEALS:
   (A)   A person who is denied County medical or financial assistance by the
Department of Social Services may take an appeal of such decision to the
Commissioners. The appellant must deliver to the Department of Social Services
a written notice of appeal specifying the decision or action appealed and the
grounds for the appeal. The notice of appeal must be delivered to the
Department of Social Services within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the
written notice of the Department of Social Services' decision denying a request
for assistance. (Ord. 1991-A, 2-7-91; amd. Ord. 1993-B, 3-17-93, eff. 4-1-93)
   (B)   Upon receipt of a written notice of appeal, the Director shall
forthwith cause the appeal to be placed upon the Commissioners' agenda for an
appeal hearing. Notice of the appeal hearing shall be given the appellant by
mailing a copy of a notice thereof to the appellant's last known address, at
least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing.
   (C)   At the appeal hearing, the Department of Social Services shall make
available to the Commissioners all documents constituting the record upon which
the appealed decision was based. The Commissioners may, if it appears necessary
for a clear understanding of the case, take additional evidence at the appeal
hearing.
   (D)   At the appeal hearing, the appellant shall be heard first and shall
present the reasons for the appeal. The Department of Social Services may then
present any rebuttal argument.
   (E)   The Commissioners, at the conclusion of the hearing on appeal, or
within a reasonable time thereafter, may sustain, modify, or overrule the
decision of the Department of Social Services, or may refer the matter back to
the Department of Social Services for further action in accordance with the
order of the Commissioners.
   (F)   A final decision by the Commissioners on appeal that is adverse to the
appellant must be in writing, set forth the factual basis for the decision and
the applicable laws, rules and regulations on which the decision is based. A
copy of the final decision must be personally served upon each party to the
appeal and the party's representative, if any, or served by certified mail by
mailing a copy of the final decision to the party and the party's
representative's last known address. (Ord. 1990-P, 6-20-90, eff. 7-3-90; amd.
Ord. 1993-B, 3-17-93, eff. 4-1-93)
   (G)   The appellant may petition District Court for review of the Board of
County Commissioner's decision on appeal within thirty (30) days from the
mailing of a certified, written notice of the Board's final decision to the
appellant at the appellant's last known address. (Ord. 1995-F, 5-17-95, eff. 6-
1-95)
CHAPTER 9
JACKPOT SANITARY LANDFILL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
10-9-1: Mandatory Fees
10-9-2: Use Of Funds
10-9-3: Regulations
10-9-1: MANDATORY FEES:
Any persons connected to the Jackpot Municipal Sewer System shall pay,
regardless of use or nonuse, in addition to the fees required by the Jackpot
Town Board for connection to said sewer system, a sanitary landfill fee in the
amount of ten dollars fifty cents ($10.50) for commercial users and seven
dollars ($7.00) for residential users per unit of sewer use as scheduled in
Title 9, Chapter 2 of this Code. Said fee shall be assessed and paid, together
with the sewer fee, in the manner prescribed in the Jackpot Municipal Sewer
Regulations 1 .
Exception: A commercial user of the sanitary landfill may exercise the option
to not participate in the Town of Jackpot Sanitary Landfill by providing the
following:
   (A)   Provide thirty (30) days' written notice to the Elko County Manager of
their intent to not participate in the Town of Jackpot Sanitary Landfill.
   (B)   Provide thirty (30) days' written notice to Elko County Community
Development of alternative solid waste management plan.
   (C)   Obtain approval from the Board of County Commissioners sitting as the
Town Board of the Unincorporated Town of Jackpot at the next regularly
scheduled meeting after the thirty (30) days' notice. (Ord. 1997-K, 1-7-1998,
eff. 3-1-1998)

10-9-2: USE OF FUNDS:
All funds received pursuant to this Chapter shall be used to maintain and
operate, in accordance with applicable County, State and Federal laws, a
sanitary landfill facility for and on behalf of the Unincorporated Town of
Jackpot, Nevada. (Ord. 1979-X, 12-6-1979, eff. 1-1-1980)
10-9-3: REGULATIONS:
The Town Board is authorized to make any and all necessary or proper
regulations to carry out and enforce the provisions of this Chapter, including
all matters as to notices, procedures, regulations of the disposal site and
similarly related matters. (Ord. 1979-X, 12-6-1979, eff. 1-1-1980)
CHAPTER 10
LOST OR ABANDONED PROPERTY
SECTION:
10-10-1: Custody of Lost or Abandoned Property
10-10-2: Notification of Owner
10-10-3: Claim Procedure
10-10-4: Payment of Costs
10-10-5: Sale of Lost or Abandoned Property
10-10-6: Proceeds of Sale
10-10-7: Public Use of Lost or Abandoned Property
10-10-8: Hazardous Property
10-10-9: Burning, Scavenging, and Salvaging Prohibited
10-10-10: Definitions
10-10-11: Public Nuisance Declared
10-10-12: Unlawful Dumping of Garbage, Rubbish, Waste Material and Sewage
10-10-13: Presumption, Liability for Removal
10-10-14: Placement of Garbage, Rubbish and Waste Materials in Receptacles so
as to Prevent Scattering
10-10-15: Truck Loads Causing Litter
10-10-16: Owner to Maintain Premises Free of Litter
10-10-17: Penalties
10-10-1: CUSTODY OF LOST OR ABANDONED PROPERTY:
All lost or abandoned property found upon property belonging to Elko County
shall be deposited and transferred to the custodial possession of the County
Sheriff's Department. All other lost or abandoned property turned into the
County Sheriff's Department shall become the property of the County until the
true owner is ascertained and claims the property or the procedure for disposal
of such property set forth in this Chapter has been followed.
10-10-2: NOTIFICATION OF OWNER:
The Sheriff's Department shall notify by first class mail the owner of the
property, if his or her identity and address are reasonably ascertainable, that
it possesses the property and where and when it may be claimed, and of the
provisions of Sections
10-10-4 and
10-10-5.
10-10-3: CLAIM PROCEDURE:
If the owner appears to claim the property, he or she must establish ownership
of the property to the satisfaction of the County Sheriff's Department, and in
addition to any other proof of ownership, shall sign a declaration of ownership
under penalty of perjury.
10-10-4: PAYMENT OF COSTS:
Before releasing the property to its owner, the owner shall pay to the County
Sheriff's Department the sum of one dollar ($1.00) per day for each day the
property was in possession of the County Sheriff's Department, beginning ten
(10) days after notification required by Section
10-10-2, to defray costs of storage and care of the property. Refusal to pay
such costs shall constitute a waiver of any claims to ownership.
10-10-5: SALE OF LOST OR ABANDONED PROPERTY:
Any lost or abandoned property which has been in the possession of the County
Sheriff's Department for more than six (6) months shall be subject to sale by
the Sheriff at public auction for cash on not less than five (5) nor more than
ten (10) days' notice; provided, however, that whenever the Sheriff's
Department has knowledge of the name and address of the owner or one entitled
to possession or can reasonably ascertain such, a copy of such notice of sale
shall be mailed to such owner or one entitled to possession, with postage
prepaid, at least five (5) days prior to such sale; as many items of personal
property may be noticed for sale and sold at the same sale as the Sheriff's
Department may deem advisable, and said property may be sold singly or in lots
or as a whole as the Sheriff's Department may determine. The Sheriff shall give
a bill of sale to the highest bidder upon payment of the amount bid or upon
payment of bid price.
10-10-6: PROCEEDS OF SALE:
The proceeds of said sale shall be applied first to all costs assessed or
incurred against the personal property so sold including any storage charges as
keepers' fee and expenses of sale incurred by the Sheriff's Department and the
balance of such proceeds, if any, shall be kept by the Sheriff's Department in
a separate fund for a period of one year from the date of sale. Any person
claiming title to, or ownership, of such proceeds by reason of ownership of
such personal property at the time of sale by the Sheriff's Department shall
make written application therefor to the Sheriff's Department. If satisfactory
proof of such title or ownership is furnished within one year of the receipt of
such proceeds, then the said proceeds shall be delivered to the claimant.
If no claim and proof is made before the expiration of one year from the
receipt of the proceeds, the same shall be paid by the Sheriff to the County
Treasurer, who shall credit the same to the general fund of the County, and no
claims therefor shall be thereafter considered.
10-10-7: PUBLIC USE OF LOST OR ABANDONED PROPERTY:
Any lost or abandoned property which has come into the possession of the
Sheriff's Department and has been held for a minimum period of six (6) months,
may be put to a public use, rather than be sold at public auction. Prior to
such public use, however, the County Commissioners must, by resolution,
describe the property to be subject to public use, and specifically authorize
the utilization of such property for such public use.
10-10-8: HAZARDOUS PROPERTY:
Any property which comes into possession of the Sheriff's Department and which,
in the judgment of the person in charge of the property control section of the
Sheriff's Department, is dangerous to person or property and cannot reasonably
be safely stored by the Sheriff's Department shall be destroyed or rendered
safe upon their coming into possession of the Sheriff's Department. (Ord. 1982-
C, 4-8-82, eff. 5-1-82)
10-10-9: BURNING, SCAVENGING AND SALVAGING PROHIBITED:
   (A)   As used in this Section the words "disposal site" and "solid waste"
have the following meanings:
DISPOSAL SITE: Any place operated by the County or by an unincorporated town
within the County at which solid waste is dumped, abandoned, accepted or
disposed of by incineration, land filling, composting or any other method.
SOLID WASTE: All putrescible and nonputrescible refuse in solid or semisolid
form, including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, junk vehicles, ashes or
incinerator residue, street refuse, dead animals, demolition waste,
construction waste, solid or semisolid commercial and industrial waste. The
term does not include hazardous waste managed pursuant to NRS 459.400 to
459.600 inclusive.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to burn, scavenge or salvage at a
disposal site.
   (C)   All solid waste dumped or otherwise disposed of at a disposal site for
any length of time, no matter how short, is deemed abandoned and becomes the
property of the operator of the site.
   (D)   The governing body of the disposal site operator may by resolution
adopt such rules and regulations as may be desirable and appropriate for the
management of the site.
   (E)   Disposal sites shall be posted with a sign identifying them as such
and bearing the words "No burning, scavenging or salvaging."
   (F)   A violation of this Section shall be punished as a misdemeanor under
Section
7-1-25 of this Code. (Ord. 1988-F, 7-20-88, eff. 8-1-88)
10-10-10: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever used in Sections
10-10-11,
10-10-12 and
10-10-13 of this Code, unless the context otherwise requires or specifies, the
definitions contained in this Section shall apply:
ABANDONED VEHICLE: Any vehicle, or part thereof, which is either:
      1.   A vehicle over which the registered owner has relinquished all
further dominion and control; or
      2.   A vehicle which is inoperative under conditions indicating the owner
has no intention of restoring the vehicle to operating condition. A vehicle
without a valid registration currently in effect will be presumed to be an
abandoned vehicle. (Ord. 1988-K, 10-6-88, eff. 10-24-88)
GARBAGE: Includes kitchen and table refuse, offal, swill and other
accumulations of animal, vegetable and other matter that accompanies the
preparation and consumption, decay, or dealing in, or storage of meats, fish,
fowl, birds, fruits and vegetables, or the carcass or remains of any dead
animal. (Ord. 1989-F, 3-6-89, eff. 4-24-89)
RUBBISH: Includes wood, leaves, dead trees, branches of trees, chips, shavings,
sawdust, wooden ware, printed matter, paper, boxes, grass, rags, straw, rubber
and rubber tires, plastic and synthetic items of all types, and all other
combustible matter not included under the term "garbage".
SEWAGE: Includes sewage, sludge and cesspool, septic or holding tank effluent,
or accumulations of human or animal excreta.
WASTE MATERIAL: Includes natural soil earth, sand, clay, gravel, loam, manure,
stones, building material, bricks, plaster, cement, crockery, glass, glassware,
ashes, metals, metal containers and all other noncombustible materials.
10-10-11: PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED:
The existence of garbage, rubbish, waste material, abandoned vehicles, auto
bodies or waste matter of any kind, upon any public or private highway, street,
alley or road, or any lot or parcel of land, whether public or private is a
public nuisance and the removal thereof is necessary to protect the health and
safety of the inhabitants of Elko County. (Ord. 1988-K, 10-6-88, eff. 10-24-88)
10-10-12: UNLAWFUL DUMPING OF GARBAGE, RUBBISH, WASTE MATERIAL AND SEWAGE:
It is unlawful for any person to dump, spill, throw, place or bury, or cause
the same to be done, any garbage, rubbish, waste material, sewage or abandoned
vehicle on any public or private property, parcel of land, lot, street,
highway, gutter, alley, body of water, stream, canal or ditch within Elko
County, except at an appropriate waste disposal site operated or authorized by
the County or by an unincorporated town within the County. (Ord. 1993-G, 9-2-
93, eff. 9-16-93)
10-10-13: PRESUMPTION; LIABILITY FOR REMOVAL:
When any unlawful deposit of garbage, rubbish, waste material, or sewage as set
forth in Section
10-10-12, includes any evidence which identifies any person, firm, or
corporation, such identification will establish a presumption in any civil
action and/or criminal prosecution under Section
10-10-12 of this Code that such person, firm, or corporation is civilly and/or
criminally responsible for such deposit and such person, firm, or corporation
shall be liable for the cost of removal and disposition of the unlawful
material in addition to the penalty provided for in Section
10-10-12 of this Code. (Ord. 1988-K, 10-6-88, eff. 10-24-88)
10-10-14: PLACEMENT OF GARBAGE, RUBBISH AND WASTE MATERIALS IN RECEPTACLES SO
AS TO PREVENT SCATTERING:
Persons placing garbage, rubbish, and/or waste materials in public or private
receptacles for collection purposes shall do so in such a manner as to prevent
it from scattering, or from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any
street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. (Ord. 1993-G,
9-2-93, eff. 9-16-93)
10-10-15: TRUCK LOADS CAUSING LITTER:
No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the County
unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent the load or any
portion thereof, or any garbage, rubbish, or waste material from being blown or
deposited upon any street, alley or other public or private place. (Ord. 1993-
G, 9-2-93, eff. 9-16-93)
10-10-16: OWNER TO MAINTAIN PREMISES FREE OF LITTER:
The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times
maintain the premises free of garbage, rubbish, and/or waste material.
Provided, however, that this section does not prohibit the placing of such
materials in private receptacles for collection purposes. (Ord. 1993-G, 9-2-93,
eff. 9-16-93)
10-10-17: PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any Person violating any of the provisions of Sections
10-10-9,
10-10-12,
10-10-14,
10-10-15 or
10-10-16 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof
shall be subject to punishment by imprisonment in the County jail for a period
not to exceed six (6) months, or by a fine of not less than two hundred ninety
nine dollars ($299.00) but not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or
by both such fine and imprisonment.
   (B)   Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. (Ord. 1993-G, 9-
2-93, eff. 9-16-93)

CHAPTER 12
SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL
SECTION:
10-12-1: Definitions
10-12-2: Permits And Franchises
10-12-3: Sanitation Districts
10-12-4: Solid Waste Removal Responsibilities
10-12-5: Prohibitions
10-12-6: Right Of Further Regulation Reserved
10-12-7: Violations
10-12-8: Public Nuisance Declaration
10-12-9: Recycling And Household Waste Reduction
10-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
ABANDONED VEHICLE: Any vehicle or part thereof which is either:
   (A)   A vehicle over which the registered owner has relinquished all further
dominion and control; or
   (B)   A vehicle which is inoperative under conditions indicating the owner
has no intention of restoring the vehicle to operating condition. A vehicle
without a valid registration currently in effect will be presumed to be an
abandoned vehicle.
BULKY WASTE: Large, heavy or otherwise difficult to handle items, including,
but not limited to, stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, water heaters, washing
machines, furniture, large concrete and asphalt chunks, tree stumps, dead
animals greater than ten (10) pounds, or other waste materials with weights or
volumes greater than those allowed for containers.
COMMERCIAL UNITS: Commercial, industrial or institutional facilities. These
include, but are not limited to, hotels, motels, casinos, service marts, retail
stores, restaurants, bars, laundries, markets, etc.
COUNTY: The County of Elko, State of Nevada.
DEAD ANIMALS: Animals or portions thereof equal to or less than ten (10) pounds
which have died from any noninfectious cause (except those slaughtered or
killed for human use). Dead animals may be included as part of the normal
garbage and refuse collection only in the event that such collection is allowed
and authorized by the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection, solid waste
division.
DISPOSAL SITE: A solid waste facility including, but not limited to, sanitary
landfills, or transfer stations that are licensed, permitted or approved by all
governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction, pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 444.460.
EXTREMELY HAZARDOUS WASTE: Any hazardous waste or mixture of hazardous waste
which, if human exposure should occur, may likely result in death, disabling
personal injury or illness, during or as a proximate result of, any disposal of
such waste or mixture of wastes because of its quality, concentrations, or
chemical characteristics.
FRANCHISE: A written contract or agreement entered into between the County of
Elko and a solid waste collector in which the County grants to the collector
the right to collect and haul solid waste and/or recyclables as permitted by
law from residential and/or commercial customers in a sanitation district. A
franchise may be nonexclusive.
FRANCHISEE: Any person who has been issued a franchise by the County of Elko to
collect, transfer, or remove solid waste in a sanitation district.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Any waste material or mixture of wastes which is toxic,
corrosive, flammable, an irritant, or a strong sensitizer, which generates
pressure through decomposition, heat or other means, if such waste or mixture
of wastes may cause substantial personal injury, serious illness or harm to
wildlife, during or as proximate result of any disposal of such wastes or
mixtures of wastes. Hazardous waste is managed per Nevada Revised Statutes
459.400 to 459.600, inclusive.
MULTI-RESIDENTIAL UNITS: Permanent buildings or a commercial compound
containing three (3) or more residential units including, but not limited to,
condominiums, apartment houses, motels, hotels, mobile home parks, travel
trailer parks, and recreational vehicle parks. Ranching operations are exempt.
PERMIT DOCUMENTS: The permit requirements, permit specifications, and the
actual permit.
PERMITTEE: Any person or solid waste collector that has been issued a permit to
collect, transfer, or remove solid waste in the Owyhee, Elko or Ruby Valley
Sanitation Districts under the provisions of this Chapter. A permit is not
required for self-hauling in these districts.
PERSON: Any person, firm, business, sole proprietorship, partnership, joint
venture, trust, association, or corporation whether for profit or nonprofit.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS: Material which has been segregated from other solid waste
material for the purpose of reuse or recycling, including, but not limited to,
discarded paper, glass, cardboard, plastic, ferrous materials, yard waste or
aluminum, pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 444A.013 and Nevada
Administrative Code 444A.100.
RESIDENTIAL UNIT: A dwelling within the unincorporated area of the County
occupied by a person or group of persons comprising not more than two (2)
families. A residential unit to which solid waste collection service must be
rendered under the provisions of this Chapter shall be either a single-family
residential unit or a duplex residential. A residential unit shall be deemed
occupied when either water or residential light and power services are being
supplied thereto. A duplex is considered to be two (2) attached residential
units. This definition shall apply also to mobile home subdivisions where the
mobile home lot is individually owned.
SANITATION DISTRICTS: Areas of Elko County that have been delineated on a map
on file with the Elko County Department of Community Development and the Nevada
Division of Environmental Protection, solid waste division. These areas are
based roughly on drainage basins in the County. The districts are Salmon Falls
District, Salt Lake Basin District, Owyhee District, Midas District, Ruby
Valley District, and Elko District.
SEWAGE: Includes sewage, sludge and cesspool, septic or holding tank effluent
or accumulations of human or animal excreta.
SOLID WASTE: For the purposes of this Chapter, shall mean garbage, rubbish or
construction waste as hereinafter defined pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes
444.490.
   (A)   Garbage: Includes all kitchen and table food waste, animal waste,
vegetable waste and all household waste or residue resulting from the
preparation, storage, cooking, handling, or treatment of food and shall also
include putrescible waste as defined in Nevada Administrative Code 444.578.
   (B)   Rubbish: All nonputrescible waste matter or debris, manure, including
combustible and noncombustible materials that result from normal household,
community, and business activities including grass clippings, tree trimmings,
litter, wood, glass, cans, bedding, crockery, plastics and similar materials,
as defined in Nevada Administrative Code 444.612, but not including bulky
wastes, construction or demolition wastes.
   (C)   Construction Waste: All nonhazardous waste material and rubble
resulting from the construction, alteration, repair, removal or demolition of
buildings or from the production or development of real property which is
customarily handled and transported by means of roll-off boxes, trucks or
containers.
SOLID WASTE AUTHORITY: An official from the Nevada Division of Environmental
Protection, solid waste division.
SOLID WASTE COLLECTOR: Any person who operates collection routes for the
removal of solid waste from residential, multi-residential, commercial or
industrial premises.
STORAGE BIN: A portable waste container which is used for the collection of
solid waste for transport to a solid waste disposal site.
TRANSFER VEHICLE: A vehicle or roll-off unit used to transport solid waste from
a collection point to a permitted landfill or processing facility. (Ord. 2000-
B, 2-2-2000, eff. 3-1-2000)
10-12-2: PERMITS AND FRANCHISES:
   (A)   Permits: Permits to collect and haul solid waste and/or recyclables as
permitted by law in the unincorporated areas of Elko County may be issued to
qualified parties as provided in subsection (C) of this Section.
   (B)   Franchises: At its discretion, the Board of Commissioners may grant
franchises to qualified parties to collect and haul solid waste and/or
recyclables as permitted by law in the unincorporated areas of Elko County on
such terms and conditions as may be agreed to by the County and by the party or
parties receiving the franchise or franchises. Franchises will be applied to
the Salmon Falls Sanitation District, the Salt Lake Basin District and the
Midas Sanitation District. Franchises as granted by the Board may be
nonexclusive, exclusive, or partly exclusive and partly nonexclusive, pursuant
to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 709.
   (C)   Issuance Of Permits:
      1.   The Board of Commissioners hereby establishes a system of permits in
the Owyhee, Elko and Ruby Valley Sanitation Districts to regulate the
collection, transfer, and removal of solid waste by granting permits to
qualified applicants who meet the standards set forth in this Chapter, and to
revoke permits where the permittee has failed to meet those standards or has
violated the laws or ordinances applicable to solid waste, collection,
transfer, and removal. No permit is required for self-haulers.
      2.   Any permit issued under this Chapter may be revoked or suspended by
the Board of Commissioners following written recommendation from the Community
Development Department or the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection.
   (D)   Applications For Permits And Franchises:
      1.   The franchises for the Salmon Falls, Salt Lake Basin and Midas
Sanitation Districts may be by competitive bid and the contract for service in
this area shall be for a period of five (5) years.
      2.   Solid waste collectors who are lawfully providing waste collection,
transfer or removal services in the Sanitation Districts of Midas and Salmon
Falls, shall be granted a new franchise by the County Commissioners to continue
such services for those Districts provided that such collectors are furnishing
adequate service or are under an existing contract for services with the
County.
   (E)   Revocation Of Permit: A permit may be revoked or suspended by the
Board of Commissioners whenever the permittee has violated a material provision
of this Chapter, or State rules or regulations. In such instance, a written
notice of intended revocation or suspension as proposed shall first be
delivered in person or by certified mail to the business address of the
permittee. The written notice shall state the grounds for the proposed
revocation or suspension.
   (F)   Appeals: The applicant or permittee may appeal such proposed denial,
suspension or revocation by filing a written request for a hearing before the
board of commissioners not more than fifteen (15) calendar days after notice of
the proposed denial, suspension or revocation has been given. Upon receipt of a
written request for a hearing, the chairman shall set the matter for public
hearing on a date not more than sixty (60) calendar days following receipt of
such written request and shall give the applicant or permittee and the board
fifteen (15) working days after the close of the hearing to comply with the
decision. Such decision shall be final. Where the permit is suspended or
revoked, the permittee shall terminate its operations as determined by the
board of commissioners. (Ord. 2000-B, 2-2-2000, eff. 3-1-2000)
10-12-3: SANITATION DISTRICTS:
